subsection.text: In this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means a county of the State and, unless expressly provided otherwise, Baltimore City.
“Governmental unit” means:

paragraph.text: the State;
a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State; or
a unit of the State government or of a political subdivision.

subsection.text: “Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, or commonwealth of the United States;
except as provided in § 8–101(w) of this article, a territory of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

subsection.text: A requirement in this article that a document be under oath means that the document shall be supported by a signed statement made under the penalties of perjury that the contents of the document are true to the best of the knowledge, information, and belief of the individual making the statement.
The oath or affirmation shall be made:

paragraph.text: before an individual authorized to administer oaths, who shall certify in writing to have administered the oath or taken the affirmation; or
by a signed statement that:

subparagraph.text: is in the document or attached to and made part of the document; and
is made expressly under the penalties for perjury.

subsection.text: If the procedures provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section are used, the affidavit subjects the individual making it to the penalties for perjury to the same extent as an oath or affirmation made before an individual authorized to administer oaths.
In this section, “employer” has the same meaning as under the State workers’ compensation laws.
Before a governmental unit issues any license or permit to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer may employ any individual, the employer shall file with the governmental unit:

paragraph.text: a certificate of compliance with the State workers’ compensation laws; or
the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.
“Division” means the Division of Labor and Industry.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
There is a Division of Labor and Industry in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
The Division exercises its rights, powers, and duties subject to the authority of the Secretary as set forth in Article 41 of the Code or elsewhere in State law.
The head of the Division is the Commissioner.
The Secretary shall appoint the Commissioner with the approval of the Governor.
The Commissioner holds office at the pleasure of the Secretary.
The Commissioner shall devote full time to the duties of office.
The Commissioner is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: There is a Deputy Commissioner of Labor and Industry who shall be appointed by the Commissioner with the approval of the Secretary.
The Deputy Commissioner is in the management service in the State Personnel Management System and serves at the pleasure of the Commissioner.
The Deputy Commissioner is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
In addition to any powers and duties set forth elsewhere, the Deputy Commissioner has the powers and duties of the Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: to the extent delegated by the Commissioner;
if the office of the Commissioner is vacant; or
if for any reason the Commissioner is absent or unable to perform the duties of office.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall appoint an Assistant Commissioner for Occupational Safety and Health, subject to the approval of the Secretary.
The Assistant Commissioner is in the management service in the State Personnel Management System and serves at the pleasure of the Commissioner.
The Assistant Commissioner is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
The Commissioner shall appoint a Chief Elevator Inspector.
The Chief Elevator Inspector:

subparagraph.text: is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; and
is subject to the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern skilled service employees.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall appoint a Chief Inspector for Railroad Safety and Health.
The Chief Inspector:

subparagraph.text: is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; and
is subject to the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern skilled service employees.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the Governor, the Commissioner may appoint a Chief Mediator who shall be a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System.
The Chief Mediator:

subparagraph.text: is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; but
may not receive additional compensation for serving on a board of arbitration.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall appoint:

subparagraph.text: safety inspectors who are qualified and trained in occupational safety; and

safety inspectors who are qualified technically to inspect amusement rides and amusement attractions, elevators, and worker and material hoists on construction projects and who shall be responsible for those inspections.

paragraph.text: Each safety inspector:

subparagraph.text: is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; and
is subject to the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern skilled service employees, with the exception of special appointments.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the Governor and the Secretary, the Commissioner may employ, in accordance with the State budget, other staff needed to perform the duties of the Commissioner.

Except as provided in this section or otherwise by law, all other staff is in the skilled service or professional service, with the exception of special appointments, in the State Personnel Management System.

section.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: try to promote harmony between industry and labor;
try to promote and develop the welfare of wage earners; and
accept grants of money from the federal government or any of its units or agents for a matter within the jurisdiction of the Division.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall adopt regulations that govern procedure for boards of arbitration under Title 4, Subtitle 1 of this article.

Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, and in addition to authority to adopt regulations that is set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner may adopt regulations that are necessary to carry out:

paragraph.text: Title 3, Subtitle 3 of this article;
Title 3, Subtitle 5 of this article;
Title 4, Subtitle 2, Parts I through III of this article;
Title 5 of this article;
Title 6 of this article; and
Title 7 of this article.
After a public hearing, the Commissioner may adopt regulations that are necessary to carry out Title 3, Subtitle 4 of this article.
Unless the Commissioner provides otherwise, a regulation that the Commissioner adopts under this subsection takes effect on publication.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may adopt regulations that set forth the conditions under which an employer may require an employee to construct, erect, install, maintain, or repair a line that conducts electricity and that has a nominal voltage exceeding:

paragraph.text: 24,940 volts between a pair of conductors; or
14,400 volts between a conductor and a ground.

subsection.text: In addition to any other units, the Division shall include the units enumerated in this section.

paragraph.text: There is an Employment Standards Service Unit in the Division.
Under the direction of the Commissioner, the Employment Standards Service Unit shall:

subparagraph.text: enforce Title 3, Subtitle 2 of this article;
carry out Title 3, Subtitle 3 of this article;
enforce Title 3, Subtitle 4 of this article; and
enforce Title 3, Subtitle 5 of this article.

subsection.text: There is a State Mediation and Conciliation Service in the Division.

paragraph.text: There is a research and information unit in the Division.
Under the direction of the Commissioner, the research and information unit shall collect, organize, and report statistical information on matters within the jurisdiction of the Division.

subsection.text: There is a Safety Engineering and Education Service in the Division.

paragraph.text: There is a Prevailing Wage Unit in the Division.
Under the direction of the Commissioner, the Prevailing Wage Unit shall administer and enforce Title 17, Subtitle 2 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the funding provisions of § 3–919 of this article, for fiscal year 2007 and for each subsequent fiscal year, the Governor shall include in the annual budget bill submitted to the General Assembly an appropriation for the Division of Labor and Industry sufficient to implement the provisions of this section, including amounts not less than:

paragraph.text: $315,000 for implementation of the Employment Standards Service Unit in the Division; and
$385,000 for implementation of the Prevailing Wage Unit in the Division.

subsection.text: As soon after January 1 of each year as reasonably possible, the Commissioner shall submit an annual report to the Governor, to the Secretary, and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The report shall describe the activities of the Division during the preceding year.
The report shall include a description of its investigations under § 5-205(i) of this article.

section.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2014.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

paragraph.text: “Employ” means to engage an individual to work.
“Employ” includes:

subparagraph.text: allowing an individual to work; and
instructing an individual to be present at a work site.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: enforce Subtitle 2 of this title;
carry out Subtitle 3 of this title;
enforce Subtitle 4 of this title; and
enforce Subtitle 9 of this title.

subsection.text: If the Governor declares an emergency or disaster, then, with the consent of the Governor, the Commissioner may suspend enforcement of any provision of Subtitle 2 of this title until the emergency or disaster ends.
The Commissioner may conduct an investigation under Subtitle 2 of this title, on the Commissioner’s own initiative or may require a written complaint.
The Commissioner may conduct an investigation under Subtitle 4 of this title, on the Commissioner’s own initiative or on receipt of a written complaint.
The Commissioner may conduct an investigation to determine whether Subtitle 5 of this title has been violated on receipt of a written complaint of an employee.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may investigate whether § 3–701 of this title has been violated on receipt of a written complaint of an applicant for employment.
The Commissioner may investigate whether § 3–702 of this title has been violated on receipt of a written complaint of an applicant for employment or an employee.
The Commissioner may investigate whether § 3–710 of this title has been violated on receipt of a written complaint of an employee as provided in § 3–710(d)(1) of this title.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may investigate whether Subtitle 9 of this title has been violated:

paragraph.text: on the Commissioner’s own initiative;
on receipt of a written complaint signed by the person submitting the complaint; or
on referral from another unit of State government.

section.text: The Commissioner may delegate any power or duty of the Commissioner under Subtitles 2, 4, 5, and 9 of this title.
In this subtitle, “minor” means an individual who is under the age of 18 years.

The policy of the State is to encourage the development of minors by allowing them to engage in occupations that prepare them for responsible citizenship, yet to protect them from occupations that will be injurious to their mental, moral, or physical welfare.
This subtitle does not apply to an activity that a minor performs if the activity:

paragraph.text: is performed outside the school hours set for that minor;
does not involve manufacturing or mining;
is not a hazardous occupation restricted under § 3-213(c)(1) or (2) of this subtitle for that minor; and
is limited to:

subparagraph.text: farm work that is performed on a farm;
domestic work that is performed in or about a home;
work that is performed in a business that a parent of the minor or a person standing in place of the parent owns or operates;
caddying on a golf course;
instructing on an instructional sailboat;
delivery of newspapers to consumers;
making an evergreen wreath in or about a home;
work performed as a counselor, assistant counselor, or instructor in a youth camp certified under the Maryland Youth Camp Act; or
work that is performed as an unpaid volunteer in a charitable or not for profit organization, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: a parent of the minor or a person standing in the place of the parent consents in writing; and
for hazardous work in a volunteer fire department or company or volunteer rescue squad, the minor:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: is at least 16 years old; and
has completed or is taking a course of study about fire fighting or rescue.

section.text: For purposes of this subtitle and during reasonable business hours, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: enter and inspect a place of employment;
inspect the employment records of an employee; or
question any employee.

section.text: Unless an employer possesses a work or special permit for a minor, the minor may not work for the employer.

subsection.text: A work permit shall be issued:

paragraph.text: by the Commissioner; or
in accordance with the requirements of the Commissioner, by a county superintendent of schools or designee of the superintendent.

subsection.text: Before issuing a work permit, the issuing officer shall confirm the age of the minor for whom the permit is sought by examining:

paragraph.text: a baptismal certificate for the minor;
a birth certificate or other official government document that attests to the age of the minor; or
a school record for the minor.

subsection.text: The official to whom an application for a work permit is submitted shall issue the work permit, by signing and dating the application, if:

paragraph.text: the document submitted under subsection (b) of this section attests to the age stated on the application; and
the employment is allowed under this subtitle for the minor for whom the permit is sought.
An official may issue a work permit that authorizes a minor to be employed in an occupation that otherwise would be restricted under § 3-213 of this subtitle, if the minor:

subparagraph.text: is exempted, under § 7-301(d)(2)(i) of the Education Article, from attendance in public school because the emotional, mental, or physical condition of the minor makes instruction detrimental to the progress of the minor;
is to be employed only in office work;
is to be employed in work that is performed outside of all rooms where goods are manufactured or processed; or

is to be employed in work that a county school system obtains and supervises as part of a work-study, student-learner, or similar program for which the employment is an integral part of the course of study.

paragraph.text: An official shall issue a work permit that authorizes a minor to be employed:

subparagraph.text: in an occupation that otherwise would be restricted under § 3-213 of this subtitle if the minor is granted an exception by the Commissioner because, after investigation, the Commissioner determines that neither the work nor the work site where the work is to be performed is hazardous to the minor; or
in an occupation that otherwise would be restricted under § 3-213(c)(1) or (2) of this subtitle, if the minor:

sub-subparagraph.text: has completed a course of study in that occupation at an accredited school and has been graduated from the school; or
is granted an exception by the Commissioner because employment in that occupation is part of a work-study, student-learner, or apprentice program under a federal, State, or local governmental agency.

subsection.text: Subject to this section, the Commissioner may issue a special permit for a minor of any age to be employed as an entertainer, model, or performer.
An applicant for a special permit shall submit to the Commissioner a completed application on the form that the Commissioner provides.
The Commissioner shall issue a special permit if, after investigation, the Commissioner is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the employment will not be detrimental to the health or welfare of the minor;
the minor will be supervised adequately; and
the education of the minor will not be neglected.

subsection.text: A special permit shall contain notarized signatures that show the consent of:

paragraph.text: a parent of the minor or a person standing in place of the parent; and
the employer.

section.text: A work permit or special permit authorizes a minor to work for an employer as specified in the permit.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a minor under the age of 14 years may not be employed or allowed to be employed.

paragraph.text: A minor may not be employed or allowed to be employed for more than 5 consecutive hours without a nonworking period of at least one-half hour.
Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, in a calendar day:

subparagraph.text: the total school and work hours of a minor may not exceed 12 hours; and
the minor shall have at least 8 consecutive hours that are not school or work hours.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may grant to a minor an exception to the restrictions in subsection (a)(2) of this section if the Commissioner determines that there will be no hazard to the health or welfare of the minor.

A minor who is 17 years old and serves as an election judge, under § 10-202 of the Election Law Article, may work more than 12 hours on election day only, subject to consent from at least one parent or guardian.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a minor under the age of 16 years may not be employed or allowed to be employed:

subparagraph.text: before 7:00 a.m.;
from the day after Labor Day through the day before Memorial Day, after 8:00 p.m.;
from Memorial Day through Labor Day, after 9:00 p.m.; or
more than:

sub-subparagraph.text: 4 hours on a day when school is in session;
8 hours on a day when school is not in session;
23 hours in a week when school is in session for 5 days; or
40 hours in a week when school is not in session.

paragraph.text: The hours of work allowed under paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection do not include any hours that a minor works in a bona fide work-study or student-learner program while school normally is in session.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may grant to a minor an exception to the restrictions under this section if the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: receives the written consent of a parent of the minor or a person standing in the place of the parent; and
determines that:

subparagraph.text: there will be no hazard to the health or welfare of the minor; and
granting the exception will not impede the minor in fulfilling school graduation requirements.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a minor who:

paragraph.text: is a child of the manager, operator, or owner of the business establishment from or to which a check, money, or negotiable instrument is being transported; or
is transporting a check, money, or negotiable instrument that the minor received as payment for merchandise that the minor delivered or for a service that the minor performed.
A minor may not be employed, between 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., to transport to or from a business establishment checks, money, or negotiable instruments, including payroll funds or business receipts.
A minor may not be employed, between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., to transport to or from a business establishment checks, money, or negotiable instruments that have a value in excess of $100.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a minor may not be employed or allowed to work:

paragraph.text: in, about, or in connection with the manufacturing of a hazardous substance;
in, about, or in connection with:

subparagraph.text: a blast furnace;
a distillery where an alcoholic beverage is manufactured, bottled, wrapped, or packed;
a railroad;
an engineer, fireman, or pilot on a vessel that is engaged in commerce; or
a dock or wharf other than a marina where pleasure vessels are sold or served; or

paragraph.text: in, about, or in connection with:

subparagraph.text: the erection or repair of an electrical wire;
the cleaning, oiling, or wiping of machinery; or
an occupation that is prohibited by law.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a minor under the age of 16 may not be employed or allowed to work:

paragraph.text: during the school hours set for that minor;
about or in connection with an acid, dye, gas, lye, or paint;
at, about, or in connection with:

subparagraph.text: an airport;
a brickyard;
a lumberyard;
a workroom or work site where goods are manufactured or processed;
scaffolding; or
a vessel when engaged in navigation or commerce; or

paragraph.text: in, about, or in connection with:

subparagraph.text: construction;
an occupation that causes dust in an injurious quantity;
a manufacturing occupation;
a mechanical occupation;
a processing occupation; or
the adjustment, cleaning, or operation of power-driven machinery except:

sub-subparagraph.text: an office machine; or
machinery used in a school or government institution as part of vocational training.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may prohibit minors being employed in an occupation if:

paragraph.text: after a public hearing, the Commissioner determines that employment in the occupation should be prohibited to minors;
the Commissioner adopts by reference a determination by the United States Secretary of Labor under the federal Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 that the occupation is hazardous; or
after investigation, the Commissioner determines that the occupation is injurious to:

subparagraph.text: the health or welfare of minors; or
the morals of minors under the age of 16 years.

section.text: Each employer shall keep posted conspicuously in each place where a minor is employed a printed notice of the provisions of this subtitle, in a form that the Commissioner requires.
After review, the Commissioner may revoke a work permit or special permit if the permit is not issued in accordance with the requirements of the Commissioner.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: interfere with or hinder the performance of any duty of the Commissioner under this subtitle; or
knowingly give false information to the Commissioner.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly:

paragraph.text: employ a minor in violation of a provision of this subtitle; or
allow a minor to be employed in violation of a provision of this subtitle.

A person who violates any provision of subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or both.

A person who violates any provision of subsection (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Employer” means:

subparagraph.text: a person engaged in a business, industry, profession, trade, or other enterprise in the State;
the State and its units;
a county and its units; and
a municipal government in the State.

paragraph.text: “Employer” includes a person who acts directly or indirectly in the interest of another employer with an employee.
“Wage” means all compensation for employment.
“Wage” includes board, lodging, or other advantage provided to an employee for the convenience of the employer.

section.text: This subtitle applies to an employer of both men and women in a lawful enterprise.
In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: use informal methods of conference, conciliation, and persuasion to eliminate pay practices that are unlawful under this subtitle; and
supervise the payment of a wage owing to an employee under this subtitle.

subsection.text: An employer may not discriminate between employees in any occupation by paying a wage to employees of one sex at a rate less than the rate paid to employees of the opposite sex if both employees work in the same establishment and perform work of comparable character or work on the same operation, in the same business, or of the same type.
Subsection (a) of this section does not prohibit a variation in a wage that is based on:

paragraph.text: a seniority system that does not discriminate on the basis of sex;
a merit increase system that does not discriminate on the basis of sex;
jobs that require different abilities or skills;
jobs that require the regular performance of different duties or services; or
work that is performed on different shifts or at different times of day.

subsection.text: An employer who is paying a wage in violation of this subtitle may not reduce another wage to comply with this subtitle.
Each employer shall keep each record that the Commissioner requires on:

paragraph.text: wages of employees;
job classifications of employees;
racial classification of employees;
gender of employees; and
other conditions of employment.

subsection.text: An employer shall keep the records required under this section for the period of time that the Commissioner requires.
On the basis of the records required under this section, an employer shall make each report that the Commissioner requires.
The Commissioner may analyze the records required under this section to study pay disparity issues.

paragraph.text: Each employer shall keep each record that the Commissioner requires on:

subparagraph.text: wages of employees;
job classifications of employees; and
other conditions of employment.

paragraph.text: An employer shall keep the records required under this subsection for the period of time that the Commissioner requires.

subsection.text: On the basis of the records required under this section, an employer shall make each report that the Commissioner requires.
On request of an employer, the Commissioner shall provide without charge a copy of this subtitle to the employer.
Each employer shall keep posted conspicuously in each place of employment a copy of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If an employer violates this subtitle, an affected employee may bring an action against the employer to recover the difference between the wages paid to male and female employees who do the same type work and an additional equal amount as liquidated damages.
An employee may bring an action on behalf of the employee and other employees similarly affected.

subsection.text: On the written request of an employee who is entitled to bring an action under this section, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: take an assignment of the claim in trust for the employee;
ask the Attorney General to bring an action in accordance with this section on behalf of the employee; and
consolidate 2 or more claims against an employer.

subsection.text: An action under this section shall be filed within 3 years of the act on which the action is based.
The agreement of an employee to work for less than the wage to which the employee is entitled under this subtitle is not a defense to an action under this section.
If a court determines that an employee is entitled to judgment in an action under this section, the court shall allow against the employer reasonable counsel fees and other costs of the action.
An employer may not:

paragraph.text: willfully violate any provision of this subtitle;
hinder, delay, or otherwise interfere with the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner in the enforcement of this subtitle;
refuse entry to the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner into a place of employment that the Commissioner is authorized under this subtitle to inspect; or
discharge or otherwise discriminate against an employee because the employee:

subparagraph.text: makes a complaint to the employer, the Commissioner, or another person;
brings an action under this subtitle or a proceeding that relates to the subject of this subtitle or causes the action or proceeding to be brought; or
has testified or will testify in an action under this subtitle or a proceeding that relates to the subject of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An employee may not:

paragraph.text: make a groundless or malicious complaint to the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner;
in bad faith, bring an action under this subtitle;
in bad faith, bring a proceeding that relates to the subject of this subtitle; or
in bad faith, testify in an action under this subtitle or a proceeding that relates to the subject of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may bring an action for injunctive relief and damages against a person who violates subsection (a)(1) or (4) or subsection (b)(1), (3), or (4) of this section.
An employer who violates any provision of subsection (a)(2) or (3) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $300.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Employer” includes a person who acts directly or indirectly in the interest of another employer with an employee.
“Federal Act” means the federal Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938.
“Wage” means all compensation that is due to an employee for employment.
The General Assembly finds that wages in some occupations in the State have been insufficient to provide adequate maintenance and to protect health.
The purpose of this subtitle is to set minimum wage standards in the State to:

paragraph.text: provide a maintenance level that is consistent with the needs of the population for their efficiency, general well-being, and health;
safeguard employers and employees against unfair competition;
increase the stability of industry;
increase the buying power of employees; and
decrease the need to spend public money for the relief of employees.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is employed in a capacity that the Commissioner defines, by regulation, to be administrative, executive, or professional;
is employed in a nonadministrative capacity at an organized camp, including a resident or day camp;
is under the age of 16 years and is employed no more than 20 hours in a week;
is employed as an outside salesman;
is compensated on a commission basis;
is at least 62 years old and is employed no more than 25 hours in a week;
is a child, parent, spouse, or other member of the immediate family of the employer;
is employed in a motion picture or drive-in theater;
is employed as part of the training in a special education program for emotionally, mentally, or physically handicapped students under a public school system;
is employed by an employer who is engaged in canning, freezing, packing, or first processing of perishable or seasonal fresh fruits, vegetables, or horticultural commodities, poultry, or seafood;
engages in the activities of a charitable, educational, not for profit, or religious organization if:

subparagraph.text: the service is provided gratuitously; and
there is, in fact, no employer-employee relationship; or

paragraph.text: is employed in a cafe, drive-in, drugstore, restaurant, tavern, or other similar establishment that:

subparagraph.text: sells food and drink for consumption on the premises; and
has an annual gross income of $250,000 or less.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is employed in agriculture if, during each quarter of the preceding calendar year, the employer used no more than 500 agricultural-worker days;
is engaged principally in the range production of livestock; or

is employed as a hand-harvest laborer and is paid on a piece-rate basis in an operation that, in the region of employment, has been and customarily and generally is recognized as having been paid on that basis, if:

subparagraph.text: the individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: commutes daily from the permanent residence of the individual to the farm where the individual is employed; and
during the preceding calendar year, was employed in agriculture less than 13 weeks; or

subparagraph.text: the individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: is under the age of 17;
is employed on the same farm as a parent of the individual or a person standing in the place of the parent; and
is paid at the same rate that an employee who is at least 17 years old is paid on the same farm.

section.text: This subtitle does not diminish:

paragraph.text: the right of employees to bargain collectively with their employers through representatives whom the employees choose to establish wages or other conditions of employment in excess of the applicable minimum under this subtitle; or
a right of an employee that is granted under the federal Act.

section.text: An agreement to work for less than the wage required under this subtitle is void.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may ascertain what wage is paid in any occupation in the State.

paragraph.text: In an investigation under this subtitle, the Commissioner shall try to negotiate with an employer to obtain the testimony or documentary evidence that is needed to determine whether a violation exists.

If the Commissioner is unable to obtain evidence by negotiation, the Commissioner may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of documentary evidence that relates to the subject matter of the complaint.
Each application for a subpoena under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: be under oath; and
describe in detail:

sub-subparagraph.text: the nature, purpose, and scope of the investigation;
each witness to be subpoenaed; and
each record to be inspected.

paragraph.text: A subpoena may not be issued unless the application is approved by the Attorney General as to form and substance.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on a complaint filed by the Commissioner, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

section.text: In addition to any regulation specifically required by this subtitle, regulations that the Commissioner adopts to carry out this subtitle may include:

paragraph.text: definitions of the terms “administrative capacity”, “executive capacity”, “professional capacity”, and “outside salesman”;
a scale of wages that is suitable for learners and apprentices but is at least 80% of the minimum wage under this subtitle; and
a wage for a special case or class of case if the Commissioner finds the wage appropriate to:

subparagraph.text: avoid undue hardship;
prevent the curtailment of employment opportunity; and
safeguard the minimum wage under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this section, “employer” includes a governmental unit.
Except as provided in § 3-414 of this subtitle, each employer shall pay:

paragraph.text: to each employee who is subject to both the federal Act and this subtitle, at least the greater of:

subparagraph.text: the minimum wage for that employee under the federal Act; or
a wage that equals a rate of $6.15 per hour; and

paragraph.text: each other employee who is subject to this subtitle, at least:

subparagraph.text: the greater of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the highest minimum wage under the federal Act; or
a wage that equals a rate of $6.15 per hour; or

subparagraph.text: a training wage under regulations that the Commissioner adopts that include the conditions and limitations authorized under the federal Fair Labor Standards Amendments of 1989.

subsection.text: In this section, “federal certificate” means a certificate that the United States Department of Labor issues to a work activities center or other sheltered workshop to allow the workshop to pay an individual less than the wage otherwise required for that individual under the federal Act.
This section does not apply to a blind individual who works in a sheltered workshop of Blind Industries and Services of Maryland.

Subject to the limitations in this section, the Commissioner may authorize a work activities center or other sheltered workshop to pay a mentally or physically disabled employee of the workshop less than the minimum wage otherwise required under this subtitle for the employee.

paragraph.text: To authorize a work activities center or other sheltered workshop to pay less than the minimum wage, the Commissioner shall:

subparagraph.text: issue a State certificate that sets wages for employees of the workshop;
accept a federal certificate for the workshop; or
grant an exception for the workshop but only if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Commissioner has not issued a State certificate for the workshop;
the workshop is not eligible for a federal certificate; and
the Commissioner investigates and holds a hearing on the exception.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall accept a federal certificate if a work activities center or other sheltered workshop submits that certificate to the Commissioner within 10 days after the workshop receives the certificate.
Each certificate that the Commissioner issues under this section shall state the period for which the certificate is in effect.

The acceptance of a federal certificate does not apply automatically to an individual whom a work activities center or other sheltered workshop continues to employ after the individual completes a training program that the workshop runs.
The Commissioner may revoke acceptance of a federal certificate if:

subparagraph.text: the United States Department of Labor revokes the federal certificate; or
at any time before revocation by the Department of Labor and after an investigation and hearing, the Commissioner finds good cause to revoke the acceptance.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall send notice of a hearing under this subsection, by certified mail, to the holder of the federal certificate at least 30 days before the hearing.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, each employer shall pay an overtime wage of at least 1.5 times the usual hourly wage, computed in accordance with § 3-420 of this subtitle.
This section does not apply to an employer that is:

paragraph.text: subject to 49 U.S.C. § 10501;
an establishment that is a hotel or motel;
an establishment that is a restaurant;
considered a gasoline service station because the employer is engaged primarily in selling gasoline and lubricating oil, even if the employer sells other merchandise or performs minor repair work;
a bona fide private country club;

a not for profit entity and is engaged primarily in providing temporary at-home care services, such as companionship or delivery of prepared meals, to aged or sick individuals, individuals with disabilities, or individuals with a mental disorder;
a not for profit concert promoter, legitimate theater, music festival, music pavilion, or theatrical show; or
an amusement or recreational establishment, including a swimming pool, if the establishment:

subparagraph.text: operates for no more than 7 months in a calendar year; or
for any 6 months during the preceding calendar year, has average receipts in excess of one-third of the average receipts for the other 6 months.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to an employer with respect to:

paragraph.text: an employee for whom the United States Secretary of Transportation may set qualifications and maximum hours of service under 49 U.S.C. § 31502;

a mechanic, partsperson, or salesperson who primarily sells or services automobiles, farm equipment, trailers, or trucks, if the employer is engaged primarily in selling those vehicles to ultimate buyers and is not a manufacturer; or
a driver if the employer is engaged in the business of operating taxicabs.

subsection.text: In this section, “board, lodging, or other advantage” means a facility or service that an employer customarily provides to an employee.

Unless a collective bargaining agreement excludes board, lodging, or other advantage from the wage of an employee, an employer may include, as part of the wage, the cost that the employer incurs in providing the advantage to the employee.
An employer shall compute the cost of board, lodging, or other advantage in accordance with the regulations that the Commissioner adopts.
The Commissioner may provide, by regulation, for computation of the cost of board, lodging, or other advantage on the basis of:

paragraph.text: the actual cost; or
the reasonable cost of the board, lodging, or other advantage for a defined class of employees and in a defined area, based on:

subparagraph.text: the average cost to the employer or groups of employers who are situated similarly;
the average value to groups of employees; or
any other appropriate measure of fair value.

paragraph.text: This section applies to each employee who:

subparagraph.text: is engaged in an occupation in which the employee customarily and regularly receives more than $30 each month in tips;
has been informed by the employer about the provisions of this section; and
has kept all of the tips that the employee received.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection, this section does not prohibit the pooling of tips.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this section, an employer may include, as part of the wage of an employee to whom this section applies:

paragraph.text: an amount that the employer sets to represent the tips of the employee; or
if the employee or representative of the employee satisfies the Commissioner that the employee received a lesser amount in tips, the lesser amount.

subsection.text: The tip credit amount that the employer may include under subsection (b) of this section may not exceed 50% of the minimum wage established under § 3-413 of this subtitle for the employee.

Except as otherwise provided in this section, an employer shall compute the wage for overtime under § 3-415 of this subtitle on the basis of each hour over 40 hours that an employee works during 1 workweek.

Notwithstanding § 3-415(b)(8) of this subtitle, an employer that is not a not for profit organization and is a concert promoter, legitimate theater, music festival, music pavilion, or theatrical show shall pay overtime for a craft or trade employee as required in subsection (a) of this section.
The wage for overtime may be computed on the basis of each hour over 60 hours that an employee works during 1 workweek for an employee who:

paragraph.text: is engaged in agriculture; and
is exempt from the overtime provisions of the federal Act.

subsection.text: The wage for overtime may be computed on the basis of each hour over 48 hours that an employee works during 1 workweek:

paragraph.text: for an employee of a bowling establishment; and
for an employee of an institution that:

subparagraph.text: is not a hospital; but
is engaged primarily in the care of individuals who:

sub-subparagraph.text: are aged, intellectually disabled, or sick or have a mental disorder; and
reside at the institution.

subsection.text: In this section, “nurse” means a licensed practical nurse or a registered nurse as defined in § 8-101 of the Health Occupations Article.
Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, an employer may not require a nurse to work more than the regularly scheduled hours according to the predetermined work schedule.
A nurse may be required to work overtime if:

paragraph.text: the work is a consequence of an emergency situation which could not have been reasonably anticipated;
the emergency situation is nonrecurring and is not caused by or aggravated by the employer’s inattention or lack of reasonable contingency planning;
the employer has exhausted all good faith, reasonable attempts to obtain voluntary workers during the succeeding shifts;
the nurse has critical skills and expertise that are required for the work;
the standard of care for a patient assignment requires continuity of care through completion of a case, treatment, or procedure; and

subparagraph.text: the employer has informed the nurse of the basis for the employer’s direction; and
that basis satisfies the other requirements for mandatory overtime listed under this subsection.

subsection.text: In addition to the provisions of subsection (c) of this section, a nurse may be required to work overtime if:

paragraph.text: a condition of employment includes on-call rotation; or
the nurse works in community-based care.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to prohibit a nurse from voluntarily agreeing to work more than the number of scheduled hours provided in this section.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, a nurse may not be considered responsible for the care of a patient beyond the nurse’s predetermined work schedule if the nurse:

subparagraph.text: has notified another appropriate nurse of the patient’s status; and
has transferred responsibility for the patient’s care to another appropriate nurse or properly designated individual.

paragraph.text: The employer shall exhaust all good faith, reasonable attempts to ensure that appropriate staff is available to accept responsibility for a patient’s care beyond a nurse’s predetermined work schedule.

subsection.text: On request by an employer, the Commissioner shall provide without charge a copy of any summary or regulation to the employer.
Each employer shall keep posted conspicuously in each place of employment:

paragraph.text: a summary of this subtitle that the Commissioner approves; and
a copy or summary of each regulation that is adopted to carry out this subtitle.

section.text: Each employer shall keep, for at least 3 years, in or about the place of employment, a record of:

paragraph.text: the name, address, and occupation of each employee;
the rate of pay of each employee;
the amount that is paid each pay period to each employee;
the hours that each employee works each day and workweek; and
other information that the Commissioner requires, by regulation, as reasonable to enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall enter a place of employment to:

paragraph.text: question employees to determine whether an employer has been and is complying with this subtitle and regulations adopted to carry out this subtitle;
inspect and copy each record that an employer keeps on wages and hours of employees; and
require each employer:

subparagraph.text: to attest to the truthfulness of each record that is copied and to sign the copy; or
at the option of the employer, to submit a complete, written statement about the wages, hours, name, and address of each employee, on forms that the Commissioner provides or approves.

subsection.text: Each record or statement that the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner obtains under subsection (a) of this section is confidential and may be shown only to the Commissioner, a court, or a member of the Committee.

paragraph.text: A person aggrieved by a regulation or order to pay wages that the Commissioner adopts under this subtitle may file a complaint in circuit court for the county within 60 days after the date of publication of the regulation or order to pay wages to have it modified or set aside.
A copy of the complaint shall be served on the Commissioner.

subsection.text: Unless the court specifically orders otherwise, the commencement of proceedings under this section may not operate as a stay of the regulation or order to pay wages.

paragraph.text: The court shall determine whether a regulation or order to pay wages is in accordance with law.
If a finding of fact is supported by substantial evidence, the finding is conclusive.

subsection.text: If an employer pays an employee less than the wage required under this subtitle, the employee may bring an action against the employer to recover the difference between the wage paid to the employee and the wage required under this subtitle.
On the written request of an employee who is entitled to bring an action under this section, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: take an assignment of the claim in trust for the employee;
ask the Attorney General to bring an action in accordance with this section on behalf of the employee; and
consolidate 2 or more claims against an employer.

subsection.text: The agreement of an employee to work for less than the wage to which the employee is entitled under this subtitle is not a defense to an action under this section.
If a court determines that an employee is entitled to recovery in an action under this section, the court may allow against the employer reasonable counsel fees and other costs.
In this section, “complaint” includes a written or oral complaint, claim, or assertion of right by an employee, regarding the payment of wages under this subtitle, that is made to:

paragraph.text: the employer or a supervisor, manager, or foreman employed by the employer whether it is made through the employer’s internal grievance process or otherwise; or
the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner.
An employer may not:

subparagraph.text: pay or agree to pay less than the wage required under this subtitle;
hinder or delay the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner in the enforcement of this subtitle;
take adverse action against an employee because the employee:

sub-subparagraph.text: makes a complaint that the employee has not been paid in accordance with this subtitle;
brings an action under this subtitle or a proceeding that relates to the subject of this subtitle; or
has testified in an action under this subtitle or a proceeding related to the subject of this subtitle; or

subparagraph.text: violate any other provision of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Adverse action prohibited under paragraph (1) of this subsection includes:

subparagraph.text: discharge;
demotion;
threatening the employee with discharge or demotion; and

any other retaliatory action that results in a change to the terms or conditions of employment that would dissuade a reasonable employee from making a complaint, bringing an action, or testifying in an action under this subtitle.

subsection.text: An employee may not:

paragraph.text: make a groundless or malicious complaint to the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner;
in bad faith, bring an action under this subtitle or a proceeding related to the subject of this subtitle; or
in bad faith, testify in an action under this subtitle or a proceeding related to the subject of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.

An employer may not be convicted under this section unless the evidence demonstrates that the employer had knowledge of the relevant complaint, testimony, or action for which the prosecution for retaliation is sought.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the Maryland Wage and Hour Law.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Employer” includes any person who employs an individual in the State or a successor of the person.

paragraph.text: “Wage” means all compensation that is due to an employee for employment.
“Wage” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bonus;
a commission;
a fringe benefit;
overtime wages; or
any other remuneration promised for service.

paragraph.text: Each employer:

subparagraph.text: shall set regular pay periods; and
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, shall pay each employee at least once in every 2 weeks or twice in each month.

paragraph.text: An employer may pay an administrative, executive, or professional employee less frequently than required under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection.

subsection.text: If the regular payday of an employee is a nonworkday, an employer shall pay the employee on the preceding workday.
Each employer shall pay a wage:

paragraph.text: in United States currency; or
by a check that, on demand, is convertible at face value into United States currency.
In this subsection, “employer” includes a governmental unit.

An employer may not print or cause to be printed an employee’s Social Security number on the employee’s wage payment check, an attachment to an employee’s wage payment check, a notice of direct deposit of an employee’s wage, or a notice of credit of an employee’s wage to a debit card or card account.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit the:

paragraph.text: direct deposit of the wage of an employee into a personal bank account of the employee in accordance with an authorization of the employee; or
credit of the wage of an employee to a debit card or card account from which the employee is able to access the funds through withdrawal, purchase, or transfer if:

subparagraph.text: authorized by the employee; and
any fees applicable to the debit card or card account are disclosed to the employee in writing in at least 12 point font.

subsection.text: An agreement to work for less than the wage required under this subtitle is void.

section.text: An employer may not make a deduction from the wage of an employee unless the deduction is:

paragraph.text: ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction;
authorized expressly in writing by the employee;
allowed by the Commissioner because the employee has received full consideration for the deduction; or
otherwise made in accordance with any law or any rule or regulation issued by a governmental unit.

subsection.text: An employer shall give to each employee:

paragraph.text: at the time of hiring, notice of:

subparagraph.text: the rate of pay of the employee;
the regular paydays that the employer sets; and
leave benefits;

paragraph.text: for each pay period, a statement of the gross earnings of the employee and deductions from those gross earnings; and
at least 1 pay period in advance, notice of any change in a payday or wage.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit an employer from increasing a wage without advance notice.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each employer shall pay an employee or the authorized representative of an employee all wages due for work that the employee performed before the termination of employment, on or before the day on which the employee would have been paid the wages if the employment had not been terminated.
An employer is not required to pay accrued leave to an employee if:

paragraph.text: the employer has a written policy that limits the compensation of accrued leave to employees;
the employer notified the employee of the employer’s leave benefits in accordance with § 3–504(a)(1) of this subtitle; and
the employee is not entitled to payment for accrued leave at termination under the terms of the employer’s written policy.

section.text: To collect wages that employers unlawfully withhold, the Commissioner may enter into a reciprocal agreement with a labor department or other similar unit that has jurisdiction in another state over wage collection.

subsection.text: Whenever the Commissioner determines that this subtitle has been violated, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: may try to resolve any issue involved in the violation informally by mediation;
with the written consent of the employee, may ask the Attorney General to bring an action in accordance with this section on behalf of the employee; and
may bring an action on behalf of an employee in the county where the violation allegedly occurred.

If, in an action under subsection (a) of this section, a court finds that an employer withheld the wage of an employee in violation of this subtitle and not as a result of a bona fide dispute, the court may award the employee an amount not exceeding 3 times the wage, and reasonable counsel fees and other costs.
If wages of an employee are recovered under this section, they shall be paid to the employee without cost to the employee.

subsection.text: On receipt of a complaint for failure to pay wages that do not exceed $3,000, the Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: send a copy of the complaint to the employer alleged to have failed to pay wages; and
require a written response to the complaint within 15 days.
The Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: shall review the complaint and any response to it; and
may investigate the claim.

paragraph.text: On the basis of the review and any investigation, the Commissioner may:

subparagraph.text: issue an order to pay wages under subsection (c) of this section if the Commissioner determines that this subtitle has been violated; or
dismiss the claim.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may issue an order to pay wages that:

subparagraph.text: describes the alleged violation;
directs payment of wages to the complainant; and
if appropriate, orders the payment of interest at the rate of 5% per year accruing from the date the wages are owed.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall send the order to pay wages to the complainant and to the employer at the employer’s last known business address by both regular mail and certified mail, return receipt requested.

Within 30 days after receipt of the order to pay wages, the employer may request a de novo administrative hearing, which shall be conducted in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
On receipt of a request for a hearing, the Commissioner shall schedule a hearing.
If a hearing is not requested, the order to pay wages shall become a final order of the Commissioner.

subparagraph.text: If a petition for review is not filed within 30 days of the issuance of the final order, the Commissioner may proceed in District Court of the county where the employer resides or has a place of business to enforce payment.
In a proceeding under this subsection, the Commissioner is entitled to judgment in the amount of the order to pay wages and any interest due on a showing that:

sub-subparagraph.text: the order to pay wages and interest, if any, was assessed against the employer;
no appeal is pending;
the ordered wages and interest, if any, are wholly or partly unpaid; and
the employer was duly served with a copy of the order to pay wages and interest, if any, in accordance with this section.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any remedy available under § 3–507 of this subtitle, if an employer fails to pay an employee in accordance with § 3–502 or § 3–505 of this subtitle, after 2 weeks have elapsed from the date on which the employer is required to have paid the wages, the employee may bring an action against the employer to recover the unpaid wages.

If, in an action under subsection (a) of this section, a court finds that an employer withheld the wage of an employee in violation of this subtitle and not as a result of a bona fide dispute, the court may award the employee an amount not exceeding 3 times the wage, and reasonable counsel fees and other costs.
An employer may not willfully violate this subtitle.

An employee may not knowingly make to a governmental unit or official of a governmental unit a false statement with respect to any investigation or proceeding under this subtitle, with the intent that the governmental unit or official consider or otherwise act in connection with the statement.

paragraph.text: An employer who violates subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.
An employee who violates subsection (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means compensation that:

paragraph.text: is due to a sales representative from a principal; and
accrues at:

subparagraph.text: a specified amount for each order or sale; or
a rate expressed as a percentage of the dollar amount that a sales representative:

sub-subparagraph.text: takes in orders for the principal;
makes in sales for the principal; or
earns in profits for the principal.

subsection.text: “Principal” means a sales corporation, partnership, proprietorship, or other business entity that:

paragraph.text: distributes, imports, manufactures, or produces a product for wholesale;
enters into a contract with a sales representative to solicit a wholesale order for the product; and
pays the sales representative wholly or partly by commission.
“Sales representative” means a person who:

subparagraph.text: enters into a contract with a principal to solicit in the State a wholesale order; and
is paid wholly or partly by commission.

paragraph.text: “Sales representative” does not include a person who:

subparagraph.text: buys a product or places an order for a product for resale by that person; or
sells or takes an order for the sale of a product to an ultimate buyer.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to an individual who is considered under the Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law to be employed by a principal.
A provision of a contract that is made between a sales representative and a principal is void if the provision purports to waive any provision of this subtitle by:

paragraph.text: an express waiver; or
a contract subject to the laws of another state.

section.text: Each principal shall pay to a sales representative all commissions that are due under a contract that is terminated, within 45 days after payment would have been due if the contract had not terminated.

paragraph.text: Subject to the requirement of paragraph (2) of this subsection, if a principal violates § 3-604 of this subtitle, a sales representative whom the violation affects is entitled to bring an action against the principal to recover up to 3 times the amount of all commissions that the principal owes to the sales representative.
At least 10 days before an action is brought under this subsection, the sales representative shall give the principal written notice of intent to bring the action.

subsection.text: If a court determines that a sales representative is entitled to judgment in an action under this section, the court shall allow against the principal reasonable counsel fees and court costs.

section.text: For purposes of personal jurisdiction under § 6-103 of the Courts Article, a principal who contracts with a sales representative to solicit wholesale orders for a product in the State is considered to be transacting business in the State.

subsection.text: If a principal makes a revocable offer of a commission to a sales representative who is not an employee of the principal, the sales representative is entitled to the commission agreed on if:

paragraph.text: the principal revokes the offer of commission and the sales representative establishes that the revocation was for the purpose of avoiding payment of the commission; or

subparagraph.text: the revocation occurs after the sales representative has obtained a written order for the principal’s product because of the efforts of the sales representative; and
the principal’s product that is the subject of the order is shipped to and paid for by a customer.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to:

paragraph.text: impair the application of § 2-201 or § 2-209 of the Commercial Law Article;
abrogate any rule of agency law; or
unconstitutionally impair the obligations of contracts.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit a proper medical evaluation by a physician to assess the ability of an applicant to perform a job.

An employer may not require an applicant for employment to answer an oral or written question that relates to a physical, psychiatric, or psychological disability, illness, handicap, or treatment unless the disability, illness, handicap, or treatment has a direct, material, and timely relationship to the capacity or fitness of the applicant to perform the job properly.
If an employer violates any provision of subsection (b) of this section, an applicant for employment may:

paragraph.text: submit to the Commissioner a written complaint; or
bring an action for injunctive relief, damages, or other relief.

subsection.text: Whenever the Commissioner determines that this section has been violated, the Commissioner may try to resolve any issue involved in the violation informally by mediation.
In this section, “employer” means:

paragraph.text: a person engaged in a business, industry, profession, trade, or other enterprise in the State;
the State;
a county; and
a municipal corporation in the State.
This section does not apply to the federal government or any of its units.
This section does not apply to an individual who is an employee of or applies for assignment to the Internal Investigative Unit of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
This section does not apply to an individual who applies for employment or is employed:

subparagraph.text: as a law enforcement officer, as defined in § 3–101 of the Public Safety Article;
as an employee of a law enforcement agency of the State, a county, or a municipal corporation;
as a communications officer of the Calvert County Control Center;
as a correctional officer of the Calvert County Detention Center or in any other capacity that involves direct personal contact with an inmate in the Detention Center;
as a correctional officer of the Washington County Detention Center or in any other capacity that involves direct personal contact with an inmate in the Center; or
as a correctional officer of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Baltimore City Jail;
the Baltimore County Detention Center;
the Cecil County Detention Center;
the Charles County Detention Center;
the Frederick County Adult Detention Center;
the Harford County Detention Center; or
the St. Mary’s County Detention Center.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to an applicant for employment as a correctional officer of a State or local correctional facility.

This section does not apply to an applicant for employment with either the Anne Arundel County Department of Detention Facilities or the Caroline County Department of Corrections in any capacity that involves direct contact with an inmate in either the Anne Arundel County Department of Detention Facilities or the Caroline County Department of Corrections.
This section does not apply to an applicant for employment with the Washington County Emergency Communications Center.

subsection.text: An employer may not require or demand, as a condition of employment, prospective employment, or continued employment, that an individual submit to or take a polygraph examination or similar test.

paragraph.text: Each application for employment shall set out, in bold–faced upper case type, the following notice:

“Under Maryland law, an employer may not require or demand, as a condition of employment, prospective employment, or continued employment, that an individual submit to or take a polygraph examination or similar test. An employer who violates this law is guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine not exceeding $100.”
Each application shall provide a space for an applicant to sign an acknowledgment of the notice required under this subsection.

subsection.text: An applicant shall sign the acknowledgment of the notice required under subsection (d) of this section.
If an employer violates subsection (c) or (d) of this section, an applicant for employment or prospective employment or an employee may submit to the Commissioner a written complaint.

paragraph.text: Whenever the Commissioner determines that this section has been violated, the Commissioner may:

subparagraph.text: try to resolve any issue involved in the violation informally by mediation; or
ask the Attorney General to bring an action on behalf of the applicant or employee.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may bring an action under this section in the county where the violation allegedly occurred, for injunctive relief, damages, or other relief.

subsection.text: An employer who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.

section.text: An employer may not discharge an employee for participation in an activity of a civil air patrol, civil defense, volunteer fire department, or volunteer rescue squad if:

paragraph.text: the activity is in response to an emergency that the Governor declares on the request of the governing body of a county or municipal corporation; and
the employee submits written proof that the participation of the employee was required.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Managerial employee” means an employee who:

subparagraph.text: is not covered by a collective bargaining agreement;
as primary duty of the employee, manages an enterprise or a unit of the enterprise that customarily is considered a department or subdivision of the enterprise;
customarily and regularly supervises at least 2 other employees in the enterprise or unit;
customarily and regularly exercises discretionary powers; and
may hire or fire another employee or makes recommendations that affect the hiring, advancement, firing, or any other change in status of another employee.

paragraph.text: “Part–time employee” means an employee who is employed for a workweek of less than 25 hours.

“Professional employee” means an employee whose primary duty is to work in a field that requires advanced knowledge that customarily is acquired by a prolonged course of specialized instruction and study.
This subsection does not apply during an emergency that a federal, State, or local governmental authority declares.
An employee in a retail establishment may choose, as a day of rest, Sunday or the sabbath of the employee unless:

subparagraph.text: outside Wicomico County, the employee is a managerial employee, professional employee, or part–time employee; and
in Wicomico County, the employee is a managerial employee or professional employee.

paragraph.text: An employee who chooses a day of rest:

subparagraph.text: shall give written notice to the employer; and
during the course of employment, may change the day of rest by giving written notice of the change to the employer at least 30 days before its effective date.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a managerial employee or professional employee or, outside Wicomico County, a part–time employee.

If an employer compels an employee to work on the day of rest that the employee chooses under subsection (b) of this section, the employee is entitled to bring an action against the employer to recover 3 times the regular rate of pay of the employee for each hour the employee works on that day.

subsection.text: This section may not be applied to abridge any right that a collective bargaining agreement grants to a part–time employee or other employee.
This section does not affect the laws that relate to:

paragraph.text: the sale of alcoholic beverages on Sunday; or
service of process on Sunday.

subsection.text: An employer may not:

paragraph.text: discharge, discipline, discriminate against, or otherwise penalize an employee who chooses a day of rest; or
require an applicant for employment who seeks a workweek of at least 25 hours to answer any question to identify the day that the applicant chooses as a day of rest.

This subsection does not apply to an agent or supervisory employee of an employer who violates any provision of this section if the employer authorizes, directs, or otherwise causes the agent or supervisory employee to violate the provision.
Outside Wicomico County, an employer who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine of not less than $250 or more than $500.
In Wicomico County, a person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction, for each employee who is caused, directed, permitted, or authorized to work:

subparagraph.text: for a first conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $500; and
for a second conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.

subsection.text: In Wicomico County, the State’s Attorney may file a complaint to enjoin a violation of this section.

section.text: A pension plan may not reduce a payment to an individual entitled to receive the payment because Social Security payments to that individual increase.
Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, Subtitles 2 and 4 of this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2014.

subsection.text: This section applies to a proceeding before an administrative or executive board or any similar body provided by an employer, employee organization, or union to hear employee grievances.

paragraph.text: At any proceeding, a deaf employee may request an interpreter.
The request must be in writing and submitted at least 5 days before the proceeding begins.

subsection.text: The employer, employee organization, or union shall notify the deaf employee in writing of the right granted by this section as soon as it is possible or at least 8 days before the hearing begins.

paragraph.text: If an interpreter is requested under this section, the employer, employee organization, or union shall request the Department of Disabilities to assist in locating a qualified interpreter to assist at the hearing.
The Department of Disabilities shall promptly assist in locating an interpreter.

subsection.text: The interpreter shall facilitate communication between the affected parties, subject to the code of ethics of the National Registry of Interpreters for the Deaf.
The cost of the interpreter’s services shall be divided equally between the employer and the union or employee organization.

An application for renewal of a license, certificate, permit, or other authorization that an individual is required by law to hold to engage in a profession or trade is considered timely if the application is submitted within 1 year after the end of the individual’s active service in the armed forces of the United States.
An individual applying to work in a trade or profession is entitled to credit toward a period of service as an apprentice in, or in preparation for, the profession or trade if:

paragraph.text: the period is required by law for the profession or trade;
the applicant performed work or received training pertaining to the profession or trade while in the armed forces of the United States; and
the applicant submits evidence of time and nature of the work or training satisfactory to the entity that has approval authority under the law.

subsection.text: This section shall be construed liberally.

section.text: An employee has the duties and rights set forth:

paragraph.text: with respect to jury service in a circuit court of this State, in Title 8 of the Courts Article; and
with respect to jury service in a federal court, in 28 U.S.C. § 1861 et seq.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Employer” means a person:

subparagraph.text: engaged in a retail establishment business in the State that has 50 or more retail employees for each working day in each of 20 or more calendar weeks in the current or preceding calendar year; or

that owns one or more retail establishment franchises with the same trade name with 50 or more retail employees in the State for each working day in each of 20 or more calendar weeks in the current or preceding calendar year.

paragraph.text: “Franchise” has the meaning stated in § 14–201 of the Business Regulation Article.

subparagraph.text: “Retail establishment” means a place of business with the primary purpose of selling goods to a consumer who is present at the place of business at the time of sale.
“Retail establishment” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: a wholesaler, as defined in § 11–401(i) of the Commercial Law Article; or
a restaurant.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to an employee:

paragraph.text: covered by a collective bargaining agreement or employment policy that includes shift breaks equal to or greater than those provided under this section;
exempt from overtime pay requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act;
who works for a unit of the State, a county, or a municipality;
who works in a corporate office or other office location; or
who works for at least 4 consecutive hours for an employer at a single location with 5 or fewer employees.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection or subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, an employer may not employ an employee at a retail establishment for 4 to 6 consecutive hours without providing a nonworking shift break of at least 15 minutes.
An employee is not entitled to a 15 minute shift break under this paragraph if the employee is entitled to a 30 minute shift break under paragraph (2) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: An employer may not employ an employee at a retail establishment for more than 6 consecutive hours without providing a nonworking shift break of at least 30 minutes.

If an employee works 8 consecutive hours in a single shift, the employer shall provide an additional nonworking shift break of at least 15 minutes for every additional 4 consecutive hours the employer employs the employee in the shift.
If an employee’s work hours do not exceed 6 consecutive hours, the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection may be waived by written agreement between the employer and employee.
A shift break required under this subsection may be considered a working shift break if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the type of work prevents an employee from being relieved of work during the nonworking shift break; or
the employee is allowed to consume a meal while working and the working shift break is counted towards the employee’s work hours; and

subparagraph.text: the employer and employee mutually agree in writing to the working shift break.

paragraph.text: If an employer violates subsection (c) of this section, an employee of the employer may file a complaint with the Commissioner.
If the Commissioner receives a complaint under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commissioner shall:

subparagraph.text: try to resolve the issue informally; or
determine whether the employer has violated this section.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner determines that the employer has violated this section, the Commissioner shall:
