subparagraph.text: issue an order compelling compliance with this section; and
in the Commissioner’s discretion, assess a civil penalty of:

sub-subparagraph.text: up to $300 for each employee for whom the employer is not in compliance with this section; or

up to $600 for each employee for whom the employer is not in compliance with this section if the violation occurred within 3 years after an employee filed a previous complaint that led to a determination that a violation had occurred.

paragraph.text: The provisions of paragraphs (2)(ii) and (3) of this subsection are subject to the notice and hearing requirements of Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

subparagraph.text: In determining whether there is a violation of this section, the Commissioner shall consider if there was a threat to public health or safety at the time the violation is alleged to have occurred.
In determining the amount of any civil penalty to be imposed, the Commissioner shall consider the:

sub-subparagraph.text: seriousness of the violation;
size of the employer’s business;
employer’s good faith in complying with this section; and
employer’s history of violations under this section.

paragraph.text: If the employer fails to comply with an order issued for a violation under paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Commissioner may bring an action to enforce the order and civil penalty in the circuit court in the county where the employer is located.

If the employer fails to comply with an order issued for a subsequent violation against the same employee under paragraph (3) of this subsection within 3 years after the employee filed a complaint that is determined to be a violation under this subsection, the employee may bring an action to enforce the order in the circuit court in the county where the employer is located.
If an employee prevails in an action brought under paragraph (7) of this subsection, the employee may be entitled to:

subparagraph.text: three times the value of the employee’s hourly wage for each shift break violation of this section occurring after the most recent violation against the same employee; and
reasonable attorney’s fees and other costs of the employee.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to an employer that is:

paragraph.text: required to inquire into an applicant’s or employee’s credit report or credit history under federal law or any provision of State law for the purpose of employment;
a financial institution that accepts deposits that are insured by a federal agency, or an affiliate or subsidiary of the financial institution;
a credit union share guaranty corporation that is approved by the Maryland Commissioner of Financial Regulation; or
an entity, or an affiliate of the entity, that is registered as an investment advisor with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an employer may not use an applicant’s or employee’s credit report or credit history in determining whether to:

paragraph.text: deny employment to the applicant;
discharge the employee; or
determine compensation or the terms, conditions, or privileges of employment.
An employer may request or use an applicant’s or employee’s credit report or credit history if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the applicant has received an offer of employment; and
the credit report or credit history will be used for a purpose other than a purpose prohibited by subsection (b) of this section; or

subparagraph.text: the employer has a bona fide purpose for requesting or using information in the credit report or credit history that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: substantially job–related; and
disclosed in writing to the employee or applicant.

paragraph.text: For the purposes of this subsection, a position for which an employer has a bona fide purpose that is substantially job–related for requesting or using information in a credit report or credit history includes a position that:

subparagraph.text: is managerial and involves setting the direction or control of a business, or a department, division, unit, or agency of a business;

involves access to personal information, as defined in § 14–3501 of the Commercial Law Article, of a customer, employee, or employer, except for personal information customarily provided in a retail transaction;
involves a fiduciary responsibility to the employer, including the authority to issue payments, collect debts, transfer money, or enter into contracts;
is provided an expense account or a corporate debit or credit card; or
has access to:

sub-subparagraph.text: information, including a formula, pattern, compilation, program, device, method, technique, or process, that:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain economic value from the disclosure or use of the information; and
is the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its secrecy; or

sub-subparagraph.text: other confidential business information.

paragraph.text: If an employer violates subsection (b) of this section, the applicant or employee may file a written complaint with the Commissioner.
If the Commissioner receives a written complaint under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commissioner shall investigate the matter promptly.
If the Commissioner determines that the employer has willfully or negligently violated subsection (b) or (c) of this section, the Commissioner shall try to resolve the matter informally.
If the Commissioner is unable to resolve the matter informally, the Commissioner may:

subparagraph.text: assess a civil penalty of:

sub-subparagraph.text: up to $500 for an initial violation of subsection (b) or (c) of this section; or
up to $2,500 for a repeat violation of subsection (b) or (c) of this section; and

subparagraph.text: send an order to pay the civil penalty to the complainant and the employer.

Within 30 days after an employer receives an order to pay a civil penalty under paragraph (4) of this section, the employer may request a de novo administrative hearing, subject to the requirements of Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
On receipt of a request for a hearing under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the Commissioner shall schedule a hearing.
If a hearing is not requested under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the order to pay a civil penalty becomes a final order of the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: If an employer fails to comply with a final order to pay a civil penalty, the Commissioner or the complainant may bring an action to enforce the order to pay a civil penalty in the circuit court in the county where the employer or the complainant is located.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to prohibit an employer from performing an employment–related background investigation that:

paragraph.text: includes use of a consumer report or investigative consumer report;
is authorized under the federal Fair Credit Reporting Act; and
does not involve investigation of credit information.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Applicant” means an applicant for employment.

subparagraph.text: “Electronic communications device” means any device that uses electronic signals to create, transmit, and receive information.
“Electronic communications device” includes computers, telephones, personal digital assistants, and other similar devices.
“Employer” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: a person engaged in a business, an industry, a profession, a trade, or other enterprise in the State; or
a unit of State or local government.

subparagraph.text: “Employer” includes an agent, a representative, and a designee of the employer.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, an employer may not request or require that an employee or applicant disclose any user name, password, or other means for accessing a personal account or service through an electronic communications device.

An employer may require an employee to disclose any user name, password, or other means for accessing nonpersonal accounts or services that provide access to the employer’s internal computer or information systems.

subsection.text: An employer may not:

paragraph.text: discharge, discipline, or otherwise penalize or threaten to discharge, discipline, or otherwise penalize an employee for an employee’s refusal to disclose any information specified in subsection (b)(1) of this section; or
fail or refuse to hire any applicant as a result of the applicant’s refusal to disclose any information specified in subsection (b)(1) of this section.

subsection.text: An employee may not download unauthorized employer proprietary information or financial data to an employee’s personal Web site, an Internet Web site, a Web–based account, or a similar account.
This section does not prevent an employer:

paragraph.text: based on the receipt of information about the use of a personal Web site, Internet Web site, Web–based account, or similar account by an employee for business purposes, from conducting an investigation for the purpose of ensuring compliance with applicable securities or financial law, or regulatory requirements; or

based on the receipt of information about the unauthorized downloading of an employer’s proprietary information or financial data to a personal Web site, Internet Web site, Web–based account, or similar account by an employee, from investigating an employee’s actions under subsection (d) of this section.
In this section, “employer” means a person engaged in a business, industry, profession, trade, or other enterprise in the State.
“Employer” includes:

subparagraph.text: a unit of State or local government that employs individuals who are not subject to the provisions of Title 9, Subtitle 5 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; and
a person who acts directly or indirectly in the interest of another employer with an employee.

subsection.text: This section applies to an employer who provides leave with pay to an employee following the birth of the employee’s child.

An employer who provides leave with pay to an employee following the birth of the employee’s child shall provide the same leave with pay to an employee when a child is placed with the employee for adoption.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Child” means an adopted, biological, or foster child, a stepchild, or a legal ward who is:

subparagraph.text: under the age of 18 years; or
at least 18 years old and incapable of self–care due to a mental or physical disability.
“Employer” means a person that is engaged in a business, industry, profession, trade, or other enterprise in the State.
“Employer” includes a person who acts directly or indirectly in the interest of another employer with an employee.

paragraph.text: “Immediate family” means a child, spouse, or parent.

subparagraph.text: “Leave with pay” means paid time away from work that is earned and available to an employee:

sub-subparagraph.text: based on hours worked; or
as an annual grant of a fixed number of hours or days of leave for performance of service.

subparagraph.text: “Leave with pay” includes sick leave, vacation time, paid time off, and compensatory time.
“Leave with pay” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: a benefit provided under an employee welfare benefit plan subject to the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974;
an insurance benefit, including benefits from an employer’s self–insured plan;
workers’ compensation;
unemployment compensation;
a disability benefit; or
a similar benefit.

paragraph.text: “Parent” means an adoptive, biological, or foster parent, a stepparent, a legal guardian, or a person standing in loco parentis.
This section applies to an employee who is primarily employed in the State.
This section applies to an employer that:

subparagraph.text: provides leave with pay under the terms of a collective bargaining agreement or an employment policy; and
employs 15 or more employees for each working day in each of 20 or more calendar weeks in the current or preceding calendar year.

subsection.text: The purpose of this section is to allow an employee of an employer to use leave with pay to care for an immediate family member who is ill under the same conditions and policy rules that would apply if the employee took leave for the employee’s own illness.
An employee of an employer may use leave with pay for the illness of the employee’s immediate family.

paragraph.text: An employee of an employer:

subparagraph.text: may only use leave with pay under this section that has been earned; and
who earns more than one type of leave with pay may elect the type and amount of leave with pay to be used under this section.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, an employee of an employer who uses leave under this section shall comply with the terms of a collective bargaining agreement or employment policy.

If the terms of a collective bargaining agreement with an employer or an employment policy of an employer provide a leave with pay benefit that is equal to or greater than the benefit provided under this section, the collective bargaining agreement or employment policy prevails.

subsection.text: An employer may not discharge, demote, suspend, discipline, or otherwise discriminate against an employee or threaten to take any of these actions against an employee because the employee:

paragraph.text: has taken leave authorized under this section;
has opposed a practice made unlawful by this section; or
has made a charge, testified, assisted, or participated in an investigation, proceeding, or hearing under this section.

subsection.text: This section does not:

paragraph.text: extend the maximum period of leave an employee has under the federal Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993; or
limit the period of leave to which an employee is entitled under the federal Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Construction services” includes the following services provided in connection with real property:

paragraph.text: building;
reconstructing;
improving;
enlarging;
painting;
altering;
maintaining; and
repairing.

subsection.text: “Employer” means any person that employs an individual in the State.
“Exempt person” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: performs services in a personal capacity and employs no individuals other than:

subparagraph.text: a spouse of the exempt person;
children of the exempt person; or
parents of the exempt person;

paragraph.text: performs services free from direction and control over the means and manner of providing the services, subject only to the right of the person or entity for whom services are provided to specify the desired result;
furnishes the tools and equipment necessary to provide the service;
operates a business that is considered inseparable from the individual for purposes of taxes, profits, and liabilities:

subparagraph.text: in which the individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: owns all of the assets and profits of the business; and

has sole, unlimited, personal liability for all of the debts and liabilities of the business, unless the business is organized as a single–owned corporate entity, to which sole, unlimited personal liability does not apply; and

subparagraph.text: for which:

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual does not pay taxes for the business separately but reports business income and losses on the individual’s personal tax return; and

if the business is organized as a corporate entity and the individual otherwise qualifies as an exempt person under this subsection, the individual files a separate federal informational tax return for the entity as required by law;

paragraph.text: exercises complete control over the management and operations of the business; and
exercises the right and opportunity on a continuing basis to perform the services of the business for multiple entities at the individual’s sole choice and discretion.

subsection.text: “Knowingly” means having actual knowledge, deliberate ignorance, or reckless disregard for the truth.
“Landscaping services” includes the following services:

paragraph.text: garden maintenance and planting;
lawn care including fertilizing, mowing, mulching, seeding, and spraying;
seeding and mowing of highway strips;
sod laying;
turf installation, except artificial;
ornamental bush planting, pruning, bracing, spraying, and removal; and
ornamental tree planting, pruning, bracing, spraying, and removal.
“Place of business” means the office or headquarters of the employer.
“Place of business” does not include a work site at which the employer has been contracted to perform services.

subsection.text: “Public body” means:

paragraph.text: the State;
a unit of State government or an instrumentality of the State; or
any political subdivision, agency, person, or entity that is a party to a contract for which 50% or more of the money used is State money.

section.text: This subtitle applies only to the following industries:

paragraph.text: construction services; and
landscaping services.

subsection.text: An employer may not fail to properly classify an individual who performs work for remuneration paid by the employer.

An employer has failed to properly classify an individual when an employer–employee relationship exists as determined under subsection (c) of this section but the employer has not classified the individual as an employee.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in § 3–903.1 of this subtitle, for purposes of enforcement of this subtitle only, work performed by an individual for remuneration paid by an employer shall be presumed to create an employer–employee relationship, unless:

subparagraph.text: the individual is an exempt person; or
an employer demonstrates that:

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual who performs the work is free from control and direction over its performance both in fact and under the contract;
the individual customarily is engaged in an independent business or occupation of the same nature as that involved in the work; and
the work is:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: outside of the usual course of business of the person for whom the work is performed; or
performed outside of any place of business of the person for whom the work is performed.

paragraph.text: Work is outside of the usual course of business of the person for whom it is performed under paragraph (1) of this subsection if:

subparagraph.text: the individual performs the work off the employer’s premises;
the individual performs work that is not integrated into the employer’s operation; or
the work performed is unrelated to the employer’s business.

paragraph.text: By contract, an employer may engage another business entity, which may have its own employees, to do the same type of work in which the employer engages, at the same location where the employer is working, without establishing an employer–employee relationship between the two contracting entities.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall adopt regulations to explain further and provide specific examples of the application of subsection (c) of this section.

section.text: The presumption that an employer–employee relationship exists under § 3–903(c)(1) of this subtitle does not apply if:

paragraph.text: an employer produces for inspection by the Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: a written contract, signed by the employer and business entity, that:

sub-subparagraph.text: describes the nature of the work to be performed by the business entity;
describes the remuneration to be paid for the work performed by the business entity; and
includes an acknowledgment by the business entity of the business entity’s obligations under this article to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: withhold, report, and remit payroll taxes on behalf of all employees working for the business entity;
pay unemployment insurance taxes for all employees working for the business entity; and
maintain workers’ compensation insurance;

subparagraph.text: an affidavit signed by the business entity indicating that the business entity is an independent contractor who is available to work for other business entities;
a current certificate of status of the business entity, issued by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation, indicating that the business entity is in good standing; and
proof that the business entity holds all occupational licenses required by State and local authorities for the work performed; and

paragraph.text: the employer provided to each individual classified as an independent contractor or exempt person a written notice under § 3–914 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An employer may not knowingly fail to properly classify an individual who performs work for remuneration paid by the employer.
An employer has knowingly failed to properly classify an individual when:

paragraph.text: an employer–employee relationship exists as determined under § 3–903(c) of this subtitle; and
the employer has knowingly failed to properly classify the individual as an employee.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall consider, as strong evidence that the employer did not knowingly fail to properly classify an individual, whether:

paragraph.text: before a complaint was filed against the employer or the Commissioner began an investigation of the employer, the employer:

subparagraph.text: sought and obtained evidence that the individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: is an exempt person; or
as an independent contractor:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: withholds, reports, and remits payroll taxes on behalf of all individuals working for the independent contractor;
pays unemployment insurance taxes for all individuals working for the independent contractor; and
maintains workers’ compensation insurance; and

subparagraph.text: provided to the exempt person or independent contractor a written notice as required by § 3–914 of this subtitle; or

paragraph.text: the employer:

sub-subparagraph.text: classifies all workers who perform the same or substantially the same tasks for the employer as independent contractors; and
reports the income of the workers to the Internal Revenue Service as required by federal law; and

subparagraph.text: has received a determination from the Internal Revenue Service that the individual or a worker who performs the same or substantially the same task as the individual is an independent contractor.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall adopt regulations to provide guidance as to what constitutes the evidence relevant to the determination of whether an employer knowingly failed to properly classify an employee.
The Commissioner shall investigate as necessary to determine compliance with this subtitle and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Any written or oral complaint or statement made by a person as part of an investigation under this section is confidential and may not be disclosed without the consent of the person until the investigation is concluded and a citation is issued.

Any written or oral statement made by an individual alleged to be employed by the respondent as part of an investigation under this section is confidential and may not be disclosed without the consent of the individual.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may enter a place of business or work site to:

paragraph.text: observe work being performed;
interview individuals on the work site, including those identified as employees and independent contractors; and
review and copy records.
The Commissioner may require each employer to:

subparagraph.text: subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, identify and produce for copying or inspection all records relevant to the classification of each individual;

attest to the truthfulness of each record that is copied in accordance with subsection (c)(3) of this section or each copy of a record that is provided to the Commissioner under item (i) of this paragraph and to sign the copy; or
at the option of the employer, submit a written statement about the classification of each employee on the form provided by the Commissioner, with any relevant records attached.

paragraph.text: An employer may comply with a requirement to produce records under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection by producing copies of the records.

subsection.text: An employer that fails to produce records for copying or inspection or a written statement under subsection (d) of this section within 30 business days after the Commissioner’s request, or an extension of time mutually agreed on by both parties, shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $500 per day for each day the records are not produced.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may issue a subpoena for testimony and the production of records.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, the Commissioner may file a complaint in the circuit court for the county where the person resides, is employed, or has a place of business, requesting an order directing compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: After the employer has provided all the records requested under § 3–905(d) of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall issue a citation to the employer or close the investigation within 90 days.
Each citation shall:

paragraph.text: describe in detail the nature of the alleged violation;
cite the provision of this subtitle or any regulation that the employer is alleged to have violated; and
state the civil penalty, if any, that the Commissioner proposes to assess.

subsection.text: Within a reasonable time after issuance of a citation, the Commissioner shall send by certified mail to the employer:

paragraph.text: a copy of the citation; and
notice of the opportunity to request a hearing.

subsection.text: Within 15 days after an employer receives a notice under subsection (c) of this section, the employer may submit a written request for a hearing on the citation and proposed penalty.
If a hearing is not requested within 15 days, the citation, including any penalties, shall become a final order of the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: If the employer requests a hearing, the Commissioner shall delegate to the Office of Administrative Hearings the authority to hold a hearing and issue findings of fact, conclusions of law, and an order, and assess a penalty under § 3–909 of this subtitle in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The employer is entitled to a hearing within 90 days after a timely request is made under this subsection, unless the employer waives that right.

subsection.text: Within 15 days after a request, in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article and the applicable regulations of the Department and the Office of Administrative Hearings, the Commissioner shall provide copies of all relevant evidence, including a list of potential witnesses, on which the Commissioner intends to rely at any administrative hearing under this subtitle.
The Commissioner has the burden of proof to show that an employer has knowingly failed to properly classify an individual as an employee.
A decision of an administrative law judge issued in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article shall become a final order of the Commissioner.
Any party aggrieved by a final order of the Commissioner under subsection (i) of this section may seek judicial review and appeal under §§ 10–222 and 10–223 of the State Government Article.

If, after investigation, the Commissioner determines that an employer failed to properly classify an individual as an employee in violation of § 3–903 of this subtitle, or knowingly failed to properly classify as an employee an employee in violation of § 3–904 of this subtitle, and issues a citation, the Commissioner shall notify the Comptroller, the Office of Unemployment Insurance, the Insurance Administration, and the Workers’ Compensation Commission to enable these agencies to assure an employer’s compliance with their laws, utilizing their own definitions, standards, and procedures.

paragraph.text: An employer found in violation of § 3–903 of this subtitle by a final order of a court or an administrative unit shall be required, within 45 days after the final order:

subparagraph.text: to pay restitution to any individual not properly classified; and
to otherwise come into compliance with all applicable labor laws, including those related to income tax withholding, unemployment insurance, wage laws, and workers’ compensation.

paragraph.text: The requirement for compliance with applicable labor laws under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection may include requiring the employer to enter into an agreement, within 45 days after the final order, with a governmental unit for payment of any amounts owed by the employer to the unit.
The requirement for compliance with applicable labor laws under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: may not require payments for more than a 12–month period; and
may not require payments due for a period before the 12–month period before the citation was issued.

subsection.text: An employer found in violation of § 3–904 of this subtitle by a final order of a court or an administrative unit shall be required, within 45 days after the final order:

paragraph.text: to pay restitution to any individual not properly classified; and
to otherwise come into compliance with all applicable labor laws, including those related to income tax withholding, unemployment insurance, wage laws, and workers’ compensation.

subsection.text: An employer in violation of § 3–903 of this subtitle who comes into timely compliance with all applicable labor laws as required by § 3–907(b) of this subtitle may not be assessed a civil penalty.

paragraph.text: An employer in violation of § 3–903 of this subtitle who fails to come into timely compliance with all applicable labor laws as required by § 3–907(b) of this subtitle shall be assessed a civil penalty of up to $1,000 for each employee for whom the employer is not in compliance.
In determining the amount of the penalty, the Commissioner shall consider the factors set forth in § 3–909(b) of this subtitle.

An employer may be assessed civil penalties under this section by only one final order of a court or administrative unit for the same actions constituting noncompliance with applicable labor laws as required by § 3–907(b) and (c) of this subtitle.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, an employer may be ordered to make restitution, pay any interest due, and otherwise comply with all applicable laws and regulations by multiple final orders of a court and all relevant administrative units, including the Comptroller, the Office of Unemployment Insurance, the Insurance Administration, and the Workers’ Compensation Commission.

subsection.text: Any penalty issued under this section against an employer shall be in effect against any successor corporation or business entity that:

paragraph.text: has one or more of the same principals or officers as the employer against whom the penalty was assessed; and
is engaged in the same or equivalent trade or activity.

subsection.text: An employer found to have knowingly failed to properly classify an individual in violation of § 3–904 of this subtitle shall be assessed a civil penalty of up to $5,000 for each employee who was not properly classified.
In determining the amount of the penalty, the Commissioner or the administrative law judge shall consider:

paragraph.text: the gravity of the violation;
the size of the employer’s business;
the employer’s good faith;
the employer’s history of violations under this subtitle; and
whether the employer:

subparagraph.text: has been found, by a court or an administrative unit, to have deprived the employee of any rights to which the employee would have been entitled under a State protective labor law, including but not limited to:

sub-subparagraph.text: any provision of this article;
the State prevailing wage law, under §§17–221 and 17–222 of the State Finance and Procurement Article; or
the living wage law, under § 18–108 of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and

subparagraph.text: has made restitution and come into compliance with all such State protective labor laws with respect to the employee.

subsection.text: If the court or an administrative unit determines that an individual or class of individuals is entitled to restitution as a result of the employer’s violation of § 3–904 of this subtitle, the court or administrative unit:

paragraph.text: shall award each individual any restitution to which the individual may be entitled; and
may award each individual an additional amount up to three times the amount of such restitution.

subsection.text: An employer in violation of § 3–904 of this subtitle may be assessed double the administrative penalties set forth in subsection (a) of this section if the employer has been found previously to have violated this subtitle by a final order of a court or an administrative unit.

An employer who has been found by a final order of a court or an administrative unit to have violated § 3–904 of this subtitle three or more times may be assessed an administrative penalty of up to $20,000 for each employee.

paragraph.text: An employer may be assessed civil penalties under this section or § 8–201.1 or § 9–402.1 of this article by only one final order of a court or administrative unit for the same actions constituting a violation of this subtitle.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, an employer may be ordered to make restitution, pay any interest due, and otherwise comply with all applicable laws and regulations by orders of a court and all relevant administrative units, including the Comptroller, the Office of Unemployment Insurance, the Insurance Administration, and the Workers’ Compensation Commission.

subsection.text: Any penalty issued under this section against an employer shall be in effect against any successor corporation or business entity that:

paragraph.text: has one or more of the same principals or officers as the employer against whom the penalty was assessed, unless the principal or officer did not or with the exercise of reasonable diligence could not know of the violation for which the penalty was imposed; and
is engaged in the same or equivalent trade or activity.

section.text: As authorized by State and federal law, units within the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the Department of Budget and Management, the Secretary of State, the Comptroller, the Maryland Insurance Administration, and other State agencies shall cooperate and share information concerning any suspected failure to properly classify an individual as an employee.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an individual who has not been properly classified as an employee may bring a civil action for economic damages against the employer for any violation of this subtitle.
An individual may not bring a civil action under this section if a final order of an administrative unit or of a court has been issued under § 3–906 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An action filed under this section shall be filed within 3 years after the date the cause of action accrues.
If the court determines that an individual or class of individuals is entitled to judgment in an action against an employer filed in accordance with this section, the court may award each individual:

paragraph.text: any damages to which the individual may be entitled under subsection (a) of this section;
an additional amount up to three times the amount of any such damages, if the employer knowingly failed to properly classify the individual;
reasonable counsel fees and other costs of the action; and
any other appropriate relief.

subsection.text: An employer may not discriminate in any manner or take adverse action against an individual because the individual:

paragraph.text: files a complaint with the employer or the Commissioner alleging that the employer violated any provision of this subtitle or any regulation adopted under this subtitle;
brings an action under this subtitle or a proceeding involving a violation of this subtitle; or
testifies in an action authorized under this subtitle or a proceeding involving a violation of this subtitle.

An individual who believes that an employer has discriminated in any manner or taken adverse action against the individual in violation of subsection (a) of this section may submit to the Commissioner a written complaint that alleges the discrimination and that includes the signature of the individual.
An individual shall file a complaint under this subsection within 180 days after the alleged discrimination occurs.
On receipt of a complaint under subsection (c) of this section, the Commissioner may investigate.
The Commissioner shall provide the employer with an opportunity to respond to the allegations in the complaint.

If, after investigation and consideration of any response from the employer, the Commissioner determines that an employer or other person has violated subsection (a) of this section, the Commissioner shall file a complaint to enjoin the violation, to reinstate the employee to the former position with back pay, and to award any other appropriate damages or other relief in the circuit court for:

subparagraph.text: the county in which the alleged violation occurred;
the county in which the employer has its principal office; or
Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: Within 120 days after the Commissioner receives a complaint, the Commissioner shall notify the employee of the determination under this subsection.

subsection.text: Where, after investigation, the Commissioner issues a citation for a knowing violation of this subtitle or regulations adopted under this subtitle by an employer engaged in work on a contract with a public body, the Commissioner shall promptly notify the public body.

paragraph.text: On notification, the public body shall withhold from payment due the employer an amount that is sufficient to:

subparagraph.text: pay restitution to each employee for the full amount of wages due; and
pay any benefits, taxes, or other contributions that are required by law to be paid on behalf of the employee.

paragraph.text: The public body shall release:

subparagraph.text: on issuance of a favorable final order of a court or an administrative unit, the full amount of the withheld funds; and
on an adverse final order of a court or an administrative unit, the balance of the withheld funds after all obligations are satisfied under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: An employer shall keep, for at least 3 years, in or about its place of business, records of the employer containing the following information:

paragraph.text: the name, address, occupation, and classification of each employee or independent contractor;
the rate of pay of each employee or method of payment for the independent contractor;
the amount that is paid each pay period to each employee or, if applicable, independent contractor;
the hours that each employee or independent contractor works each day and each workweek;
for all individuals who are not classified as employees, evidence that each individual is an exempt person or an independent contractor or its employee; and
other information that the Commissioner requires, by regulation, as necessary to enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: An employer shall provide each individual classified as an independent contractor or exempt person with written notice of the classification of the individual at the time the individual is hired.
The written notice shall:

paragraph.text: include an explanation of the implications of the individual’s classification as an independent contractor or exempt person rather than as an employee; and
be provided in English and Spanish.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall adopt regulations establishing the specific requirements for the contents and form of the notice.

A person may not knowingly incorporate or form, or assist in the incorporation or formation of, a corporation, partnership, limited liability corporation, or other entity, or pay or collect a fee for use of a foreign or domestic corporation, partnership, limited liability corporation, or other entity for the purpose of facilitating, or evading detection of, a violation of this subtitle.
A person may not knowingly conspire with, aid and abet, assist, advise, or facilitate an employer with the intent of violating this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person that violates this section shall be subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $20,000.
A person that violates this section may not be subject to a civil penalty under this section if the person:

subparagraph.text: holds a professional license as a lawyer or a certified public accountant; and
was performing an activity in the ordinary course of that person’s license when the violation occurred.

paragraph.text: If the person is exempt from sanction under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commissioner shall promptly refer the person for investigation and possible sanction to the unit of State government that has regulatory jurisdiction over the business activities of that person.

subsection.text: The procedures governing investigations, citations, and administrative and judicial review of an alleged violation under this section shall be the same as those set forth in §§ 3–905 and 3–906 of this subtitle.
A person may be assessed civil penalties under this section by only one final order of a court or administrative unit for the same actions constituting the violation.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: make or cause to be made a groundless or malicious complaint to the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner;
in bad faith, bring an action under this subtitle or a proceeding related to the subject of this subtitle; or
in bad faith, testify in an action under this subtitle or a proceeding related to the subject of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall investigate any allegations that a person has violated any provision of this section.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner determines that a person has violated any provision of this section, that person may be subject to an administrative penalty of up to $1,000, assessed by the Commissioner.
A sanction under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be subject to the notice and hearing requirements of § 3–906 of this subtitle.
If the person found in violation of this section is a person alleged to be employed by the respondent, the Commissioner shall disclose the identity of the complainant.

subsection.text: Any person who must defend an action taken as a result of a groundless or malicious complaint may be entitled to recover attorneys’ fees.

section.text: The Commissioner shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.
Each civil penalty under this subtitle shall be paid into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The proposed budget of the Division of Labor and Industry shall include an appropriation from the Workers’ Compensation Commission to cover the cost of administering this subtitle.
The Workers’ Compensation Commission shall pay the cost of administering this subtitle from money that the Commission receives under § 9–316 of this article.
The Commissioner shall prepare an annual report for the Secretary on the administration and enforcement of this subtitle, that shall include:

paragraph.text: the number and nature of complaints received;
the number of investigations conducted;
the number of citations issued;
the number of informal resolutions of the citations;
the number of final administrative orders, with a description, that shall include:

subparagraph.text: whether the alleged violation was found; and
whether the order affirmed or overturned a proposed decision of the Office of Administrative Hearings;

paragraph.text: the number of orders of the Commissioner reviewed by the Secretary and whether they were affirmed or overturned; and
the number of requests for judicial review of administrative orders and whether the orders were affirmed or overturned.

subsection.text: The Commissioner’s report shall be a public record.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Civil Air Patrol leave” means leave requested by an employee who:

paragraph.text: is a volunteer member of the civilian auxiliary of the United States Air Force known as the Civil Air Patrol; and
has been authorized by the United States Air Force, the Governor, or a political subdivision of the State to respond to an emergency mission.

subsection.text: “Employee” means any individual who performs services for, or under the control of, a provider of wages or remuneration.
“Employee benefits” means all benefits other than wages given by an employer.
“Employer” means any person that employs more than 15 employees.

An employer may not discriminate against or discharge from employment an employee who has been employed for a minimum of 90 days and is a member of the Civil Air Patrol because of membership in the Civil Air Patrol.

An employer may not hinder or prevent an employee who has been employed for a minimum of 90 days from performing service as part of the Maryland Wing of the Civil Air Patrol during an emergency mission if the member is entitled to leave under this subtitle.
An employer shall provide no less than 15 days per calendar year of unpaid Civil Air Patrol leave to an employee responding to an emergency mission of the Maryland Wing of the Civil Air Patrol.

paragraph.text: An employee shall give the employer as much notice as possible of the intended dates of the beginning and end of leave.
After arriving at an emergency location, the employee shall notify the employer with an estimate of the amount of time needed to complete the emergency mission.
The employee shall report to the employer necessary changes in the time required to complete the mission.
The employer may require verification of the eligibility of the employee for the Civil Air Patrol leave requested or taken.
If the employee fails to provide the required certification, the employer may deny the Civil Air Patrol leave.
An employee taking leave under this subtitle may not be required to exhaust all available leave before using Civil Air Patrol leave.
Nothing in this subtitle prevents an employer from providing paid leave for leave under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The employer shall restore the employee to the position held when the leave began or to a position with equivalent seniority status, benefits, pay, and conditions of employment when the employee returns to work.
An employer may decline to restore an employee as required in this subtitle because of circumstances unrelated to the provisions of this subtitle.
An employer and an employee may negotiate for the employer to pay for the benefits of the employee during the leave.
The use of Civil Air Patrol leave under this subtitle may not result in the loss of an employee benefit accrued before the first date of leave.
An employee using leave under Title 13 of the Public Safety Article may not concurrently use leave granted under this subtitle.

This subtitle does not affect the obligation of an employer to comply with a collective bargaining agreement or an employee benefit plan that provides greater leave rights to employees than the rights provided under this subtitle.
The grant of leave under this subtitle may not be diminished by a collective bargaining agreement or an employee benefit plan entered into on or after January 1, 2010.
This subtitle does not affect or diminish the contract rights or seniority status of an employee not entitled to Civil Air Patrol leave.
An employer may not interfere with the use of Civil Air Patrol leave allowed under this subtitle.
An employer may not discharge, fine, suspend, expel, discipline, or in any other manner discriminate against an employee who:

paragraph.text: complies with the provisions of this subtitle; or
opposes a practice not in compliance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: An employee may bring a civil action in the appropriate State court to enforce this subtitle.
The court may enjoin an act or a practice that violates this subtitle and may order equitable relief to redress the violation or to enforce this subtitle.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means a board of arbitration formed under this subtitle to settle a labor dispute.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.
“Mediation Service” means the State Mediation and Conciliation Service.

This subtitle does not preclude or otherwise affect any agreement for arbitration of a dispute in a manner different from that for which this subtitle provides, whether the agreement is made by the disputants directly or through persons who have written authorization to do so.
This subtitle does not affect any provision of the Maryland Uniform Arbitration Act.
Under the supervision of the Commissioner, the Mediation Service shall carry out this subtitle.
The Commissioner may assign staff to help the Chief Mediator to carry out this subtitle.
The Commissioner may charge a fee to cover the cost of providing services requested under this subtitle.

section.text: To the extent possible, the Mediation Service shall:

paragraph.text: promote voluntary mediation or arbitration of disputes between employers and employees; and
discourage resort to a legal proceeding or to a blacklist, boycott, discrimination, or lockout in or arising out of a dispute between employers and employees.

subsection.text: Subject to the approval of the Governor, the Mediation Service may:

paragraph.text: appoint a board of arbitration to settle a dispute; and
provide:

subparagraph.text: as the Mediation Service considers proper, for compensation of up to $5 for each day that a member of a board is engaged in its duties; and
for other necessary expenses of a board.

subsection.text: The Chief Mediator may serve on a board.
To the same extent as a court of the State in a civil case, the Mediation Service or a board may:

paragraph.text: conduct an investigation;
hold hearings;
administer oaths; and
issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of books, papers, and other documents.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this section, on petition of the Mediation Service or board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.
A board shall petition the circuit court for the county where the board is meeting.

subsection.text: Documents and testimony obtained under this subtitle shall be kept in the offices of the Mediation Service.
Information that the Commissioner, the Mediation Service, or a member of a board obtains under this subtitle is confidential, if the information:

paragraph.text: is of a personal nature;
relates to the private business of a person; or
may disclose the profits or methods for doing business of a person.

subsection.text: This section applies to a dispute only if the employer involved in the dispute has at least 10 employees.
Whenever a disputant or other reliable source informs the Mediation Service that a dispute might result in a lockout or strike, the Mediation Service:

paragraph.text: may investigate and try to mediate the dispute; and
if the Mediation Service is unable to mediate, may try to obtain the consent of the disputants for formation of a board.

Whenever the Mediation Service is unable to mediate a dispute and a disputant refuses consent for formation of a board or for arbitration by the Chief Mediator, the Mediation Service shall investigate thoroughly the cause of the dispute.
In an investigation under this subsection, the Mediation Service may depose a disputant.
After an investigation under this subsection, the Mediation Service:

subparagraph.text: shall decide which disputant is mainly responsible or blameworthy for continuance of the dispute; and
over the official signature of the Commissioner or Chief Mediator, shall publish in a daily newspaper a report that assigns responsibility or blame for the continuance of the dispute.

subsection.text: The Mediation Service or a board shall make and publish findings about a dispute for settlement of the dispute.
A determination and award of a board is final and binds the disputants.

section.text: Within 5 days after the National Labor Relations Board or other public or private unit certifies or recognizes a bargaining representative, the bargaining representative shall submit to the Mediation Service a report that contains:

paragraph.text: notice of the certification or recognition;
the name and address of the employer;
the total number of employees in the business establishment;
the total number of employees in the bargaining unit; and
if known, the date on which negotiations to establish a collective bargaining agreement are to begin.

section.text: On or before January 10 of each year, each bargaining representative shall submit to the Mediation Service a report that states, for each collective bargaining agreement that is to terminate during the year:

paragraph.text: the name and address of the employer;
the total number of employees in the business establishment;
the total number of employees in the bargaining unit; and
the date on which the collective bargaining agreement terminates.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.
“Consent election” means an election that is conducted under a consent election agreement and in accordance with Part II of this subtitle to determine a bargaining representative.
“Mediation Service” means the State Mediation and Conciliation Service.
Under the supervision of the Commissioner, the Mediation Service shall carry out this subtitle.
The Commissioner may assign staff to help the Chief Mediator to carry out this subtitle.

section.text: To the extent practicable, procedural regulations that the Commissioner adopts to carry out Parts I through III of this subtitle shall conform to the procedural regulations of the National Labor Relations Board for the conduct of consent elections, intervention, and decertification.

subsection.text: In this Part II of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Challenged ballot” means the ballot of an individual whose eligibility to vote in a consent election is challenged.
“Petition” means a petition for permission to enter into an agreement under which the Mediation Service will conduct a consent election.

A labor organization or individual that purports to represent a substantial number of employees whom a petition affects and an employer may submit to the Mediation Service a petition for permission to enter into a consent election agreement leading to a determination by the Mediation Service of the facts ascertained after the consent election.
A petition shall be in the form that the Mediation Service requires.

paragraph.text: Whenever a petition is submitted in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the Mediation Service shall set a period during which a labor organization may submit an objection to the petition.
The Mediation Service shall set a period that:

subparagraph.text: is sufficient to inform interested persons about the nature and purpose of the petition; and
does not expire until at least 1 week after the date on which the Mediation Service causes notice of the petition to be posted.

paragraph.text: The Mediation Service shall cause notice of a petition to be posted, at each place of employment that the petition affects, for the period set under subsection (c) of this section.
The notice shall state that a labor organization may object to the petition within the period set under subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: Unless the Mediation Service receives a timely objection to a petition, the Mediation Service shall approve the petition to enter into a consent election agreement.

paragraph.text: The Mediation Service shall investigate each timely objection to a petition from a labor organization that purports to represent a substantial number of employees whom the petition affects.

If, after the investigation, the Mediation Service determines that the labor organization seems to represent a substantial number of employees whom the petition affects, the Mediation Service shall place the name of the labor organization on the official ballot to be used in the consent election.

section.text: Each consent election agreement shall describe:

paragraph.text: the appropriate bargaining unit for the consent election;
the payroll period to be used to determine the employees within the appropriate bargaining unit who are eligible to vote; and
the date, time, and place of the consent election.

subsection.text: The Mediation Service shall conduct each consent election by secret ballot.

paragraph.text: If at least two labor organizations are to be on the ballot for a consent election, a labor organization promptly may ask the Mediation Service to allow its name to be removed from the ballot.
A decision of the Mediation Service under this subsection is final.

subsection.text: Subject to any limitation that the Mediation Service sets, each party to a consent election may designate one or more observers to represent the party during the consent election.

paragraph.text: For good cause, a party to a consent election or the Mediation Service may challenge the eligibility of an individual to vote in the consent election.
The Mediation Service shall impound each challenged ballot.

section.text: On conclusion of a consent election, the Mediation Service shall provide each party to the consent election with a tally of ballots.
The Mediation Service:

paragraph.text: shall determine whether the number of challenged ballots is sufficient to affect the result of the consent election; and
if the number is sufficient, shall investigate the eligibility of each individual whose ballot was challenged.
Within 5 days after the Mediation Service provides the tally of ballots for a consent election, a party to the consent election may object to:

subparagraph.text: the conduct of the consent election; or
other conduct affecting the result of the consent election.

paragraph.text: A party shall object in a timely manner, even if the number of challenged ballots is not sufficient to affect the result of the consent election.

subsection.text: An objection under this section shall:

paragraph.text: be in writing; and
state concisely each reason for the objection.

subsection.text: Each party who makes an objection shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Mediation Service:

subparagraph.text: 4 copies of the objection; and
proof of service under item (2) of this subsection; and

paragraph.text: serve immediately a copy of the objection on each other party.

subsection.text: The Mediation Service shall investigate each objection submitted in accordance with this section.

section.text: After investigation of a consent election under § 4-212 or § 4-213 of this subtitle, the Mediation Service shall:

paragraph.text: prepare a report, including any recommendation, on the investigation; and
serve the report on each party to the consent election.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after the Mediation Service issues a report on a challenged ballot or objection under § 4-214 of this subtitle, a party to the consent election may make an exception to the report.
Each party who makes an exception shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Mediation Service:

subparagraph.text: 4 copies of the exception; and
proof of service under item (2) of this subsection; and

paragraph.text: serve immediately a copy of the exception on each other party.

subsection.text: Whenever the Mediation Service receives a timely exception to a report on a challenged ballot or an objection, the Mediation Service shall determine whether the exception raises a substantial and material issue with respect to the conduct or result of the consent election.

paragraph.text: If the Mediation Service determines that an exception raises a substantial and material issue, the Mediation Service may hold a hearing on the exception.
The Mediation Service shall serve notice of the hearing on each party.

Unless a run-off election is to be held or an investigation is to be made under § 4-212 or § 4-213 of this subtitle, immediately after the period for filing an objection has passed, the Mediation Service shall certify to each party to a consent election the result of the consent election.
If a labor organization wins a consent election, the certification of the result of the consent election shall include a certification of the organization as bargaining representative.
The rulings and determinations of the Mediation Service under this subsection are final.

subsection.text: Unless the Mediation Service certifies the result in accordance with subsection (a) of this section or receives a timely exception under § 4-215 of this subtitle that, the Mediation Service determines, raises a substantial and material issue with respect to the conduct or result of a consent election, the Mediation Service immediately shall:

paragraph.text: decide the matter on the record; or
dispose otherwise of the case.

subsection.text: An employee, an employer, or a labor organization may submit to the Mediation Service a petition for decertification of an organization that:

paragraph.text: the Mediation Service has certified as a bargaining representative after a consent election; or
an employer currently recognizes as the bargaining representative without a consent election.

subsection.text: A petition for decertification of an organization as bargaining representative for a bargaining unit:

paragraph.text: shall be supported by at least 30% of the employees in the bargaining unit; and
may not be submitted within 1 year after certification of the bargaining representative as a result of a consent election.

The Mediation Service shall investigate each petition submitted in accordance with this section to determine whether there is reasonable doubt that the bargaining representative in fact represents a majority of the employees in the bargaining unit.
If, after the investigation, the Mediation Service determines that there is reasonable doubt, the Mediation Service shall order an election to resolve the issue.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Injunctive relief” means:

paragraph.text: a permanent injunction;
a temporary injunction; or
a temporary restraining order.

subsection.text: “Labor dispute” includes any controversy, regardless of whether the disputants stand in the proximate relation of employee or employer, concerning:

paragraph.text: terms or conditions of employment;
employment relations;
the association or representation of persons in negotiating, setting, maintaining, or changing terms or conditions of employment; or
any other controversy arising out of the respective interests of employee or employer.

subsection.text: “Person participating or interested in a labor dispute” means a person against whom relief is sought if the person:

paragraph.text: is engaged in the industry, craft, trade, or occupation in which the dispute occurs; or
is an agent, member, or officer of an association of employees or employers engaged in the industry, craft, trade, or occupation in which the dispute occurs.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: governmental authority has allowed and encouraged employers to organize in corporate and other forms of capital control; and

in dealing with these employers, an individual worker who is not represented by an organization is helpless to exercise liberty of contract or to protect personal freedom of labor and, thus, to obtain acceptable terms and conditions of employment.

subsection.text: The policy of the State is that:

paragraph.text: negotiation of terms and conditions of employment should result from voluntary agreement between employees and employer; and
therefore, each individual worker must be:

subparagraph.text: fully free to associate, organize, and designate a representative, as the worker chooses, for negotiation of terms and conditions of employment; and
free from coercion, interference, or restraint by an employer or an agent of an employer in:

sub-subparagraph.text: designation of a representative;
self-organization; and
other concerted activity for the purpose of collective bargaining or other mutual aid or protection.

section.text: This subtitle shall be interpreted and applied in accordance with the policy stated in § 4-302 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this section, “promise” means any undertaking, whether express or implied or oral or written.

A promise made between an employee or prospective employee and an employer, prospective employer, or any other individual, association, company, corporation, or firm is against the policy of the State if the promise requires either party:

paragraph.text: to join or remain a member of an employer or labor organization;
not to join or not to remain a member of an employer or labor organization; or
to withdraw from an employment relation if the party joins or remains a member of an employer or labor organization.

subsection.text: A court may not grant, on the basis of a promise described in this section, any relief against:

paragraph.text: a party to the promise; or
another person who, without the act or threat of fraud or violence, advises, induces, or urges a party to disregard the promise.

section.text: A court does not have jurisdiction to grant injunctive relief that specifically or generally:

paragraph.text: prohibits a person from ceasing or refusing to perform work or to remain in a relation of employment, regardless of a promise to do the work or to remain in the relation;
prohibits a person from becoming or remaining a member of an employer organization or labor organization, regardless of a promise described in § 4–304 of this subtitle;
prohibits a person from paying or giving to, or withholding from, another person any thing of value, including money or strike or unemployment benefits or insurance;
prohibits a person from helping, by lawful means, another person to bring or defend against an action in a court of any state or the United States;

prohibits a person from publicizing or obtaining or communicating information about the existence of or a fact involved in a labor dispute by any method that does not involve the act or threat of a breach of the peace, fraud, or violence, including:

subparagraph.text: advertising;
speaking; and
patrolling, with intimidation or coercion, a public street or other place where a person lawfully may be;

paragraph.text: prohibits a person from ceasing:

subparagraph.text: to patronize another person; or
to employ another person;

paragraph.text: prohibits a person from assembling peaceably to do or to organize an act listed in items (1) through (6) of this section;
prohibits a person from advising or giving another person notice of an intent to do an act listed in items (1) through (7) of this section;
prohibits a person from agreeing with another person to do or not to do an act listed in items (1) through (8) of this section;

prohibits a person from advising, inducing, or urging another person, without the act or threat of fraud or violence, to do an act listed in items (1) through (9) of this section, regardless of a promise described in § 4–304 of this subtitle; or
on the ground that the persons are engaged in an unlawful conspiracy, prohibits a person from doing an act listed in items (1) through (10) of this section in concert with another person.

section.text: A case shall be held to involve or grow out of a labor dispute when the case involves:

paragraph.text: persons who are engaged in a single industry, trade, craft, or occupation, employees of the same employer, or members of the same or an affiliated organization of employees or employers, regardless of whether the dispute is between:

subparagraph.text: 1 or more employees or associations of employees and 1 or more employers or associations of employers;
1 or more employees or associations of employees and 1 or more employees or associations of employees; or
1 or more employers or associations of employers and 1 or more employers or associations of employers; or

paragraph.text: a conflicting or competing interest in a labor dispute of a person participating or interested in the labor dispute.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that a procedure that allows a plaintiff to obtain sweeping injunctive relief without giving to each defendant notice of and a hearing based wholly or partly on examination and cross-examination of witnesses in open court, rather than on affidavits alone, is peculiarly subject to abuse in later litigation because:

paragraph.text: injunctive relief necessarily alters, rather than maintains, the status quo;

determination of issues of veracity and of probability of fact from affidavits of the opposing parties that are contradictory and, under the circumstances, untrustworthy rather than from oral examination in open court is subject to grave error;
erroneous issuance of injunctive relief usually is irreparable to the defendant; and
delay incident to appeals frequently makes ultimate correction of error unavailing in a particular case.

section.text: This Part III of this subtitle shall be interpreted and applied in accordance with the policy stated in § 4-311 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A court may not grant injunctive relief in a labor dispute:

paragraph.text: if the plaintiff has failed to comply with each obligation imposed by law that is involved in the labor dispute; or
except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, if the plaintiff has failed to make every reasonable effort to settle the labor dispute:

subparagraph.text: by negotiation; or
with the help of available dispute resolution mechanisms, governmental mediation, or voluntary arbitration.

subsection.text: If irreparable injury is threatened, a court may grant injunctive relief before another tribunal acts to settle the labor dispute.

section.text: In addition to any other limitation under this Part III of this subtitle, a court may not issue a temporary or permanent injunction in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute unless:

paragraph.text: each known person against whom relief is sought and each public officer who has a duty to protect the property of the plaintiff is given, in the manner that the court directs, personal notice that the court will hold a hearing on issuance of a temporary or permanent injunction;
at the hearing, the court takes, in open court, testimony offered against the temporary or permanent injunction and affords the opportunity for cross-examination; and
as a result of the hearing, the court finds that:

subparagraph.text: an unlawful act:

sub-subparagraph.text: has been threatened and, unless restrained, will be committed; or
has been committed and, unless restrained, will be continued;

subparagraph.text: unless it grants the relief requested, the property of the plaintiff will be injured substantially and irreparably;
greater injury will be inflicted on the plaintiff for each item of relief that the court denies than will be inflicted on the defendant if the court grants the item;
it is not granting any item of relief for which a court lacks jurisdiction under § 4-307 of this subtitle;
the plaintiff has no adequate remedy at law; and
each public officer who has a duty to protect the property of the plaintiff has failed or is unable to give adequate protection.

subsection.text: If, in addition to meeting the requirements for an injunction under § 4-314 of this subtitle, a plaintiff alleges that, unless a temporary restraining order is issued before a court holds a hearing on issuance of other injunctive relief in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute, substantial and irreparable injury to the property of the plaintiff is unavoidable, the court may issue a temporary restraining order in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: The court shall pass a show cause order that gives each party whom the plaintiff seeks to have restrained a reasonable period of at least 48 hours in which to show cause why the court should not issue a temporary restraining order.
A show cause order shall be served on each party whom the plaintiff seeks to have restrained as provided in the show cause order.

On expiration of the period to show cause, the court may issue a temporary restraining order if on the basis of testimony or, in the discretion of the court, an affidavit, the court finds that issuance of a temporary injunction would be justified if a hearing were held.
A temporary restraining order issued under this section is effective for the period that the court sets but not more than 5 days.

If a hearing for a temporary injunction begins before the expiration of the period set under this subsection, the court may continue the temporary restraining order until the court decides whether to issue the temporary injunction.

Unless the court continues a temporary restraining order in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection, then on expiration of the period set under this subsection, the order is void and may not be renewed or extended.

subsection.text: Before a court issues a temporary restraining order or temporary injunction in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute, the plaintiff shall post bond with the court.

paragraph.text: Bond under this section shall be in an amount sufficient to compensate each person who is enjoined for any loss, expense, or damages that improvident or erroneous issuance of the temporary restraining order or temporary injunction causes.

The amount shall include reasonable counsel fees and other reasonable costs that a defendant incurs in defending against other injunctive relief in the same case if the court denies the injunctive relief.

subsection.text: Bond under this section signifies an agreement between the plaintiff and surety to submit to the jurisdiction of the court for the purpose of being liable on the bond.
This section does not prevent a party who has a claim on or under a bond from bringing an action to pursue an ordinary remedy in court.
A court may not grant injunctive relief in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute until the court makes and files, in the record of the case, findings of fact.
Injunctive relief in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute shall prohibit an act only if:

paragraph.text: the complaint in the labor case expressly complains of the specific act; and
the findings of fact expressly include the specific act.

subsection.text: Injunctive relief in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute is binding only on a person:

paragraph.text: who receives, by personal service or otherwise, actual notice of the injunctive relief; and
who is:

subparagraph.text: a party to the case;
an agent or employee of a party or lawyer who represents a party; or
a person in active concert and participation with a party.

section.text: A party may appeal to the Court of Special Appeals from the issuance or denial of a temporary injunction in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute.
An organization or officer or member of an organization participating or interested in a labor dispute has immunity from liability in accordance with § 5-414 of the Courts Article.

subsection.text: A person who is charged with constructive criminal contempt for a violation of injunctive relief in a case that involves or grows out of a labor dispute is entitled:

paragraph.text: to pretrial release as provided for defendants in criminal cases;
to notice of the accusation;
to a reasonable time to make a defense; and

except for an officer of the court who is charged with disobedience, misbehavior, or other misconduct in respect to process of the court, on demand, to a speedy and public trial by an impartial jury from the judicial district where the contempt is alleged to have been committed.

Whenever the charge of constructive criminal contempt arises from an attack on the character or conduct of a judge, the defendant is entitled to recusal of the judge if the defendant files a demand for recusal before the hearing on the charge.
Whenever a defendant files a timely demand for recusal:

subparagraph.text: the judge may not proceed further; and
the presiding judge of the court shall designate another judge as a replacement.

paragraph.text: A person who is guilty of constructive criminal contempt in a labor case is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment not exceeding 15 days or both.
A person who is imprisoned for failure to pay a fine imposed under this subsection shall be discharged:

subparagraph.text: after 15 days; or
if also imprisoned for a definite period, 15 days after the end of the period.

subsection.text: Each employer who, under a collective bargaining agreement, deducts dues from an employee’s pay for payment to a union shall make the payment within 30 days after it is required.

Each employer or union official who, under a collective bargaining or other agreement with an employee, agrees to make a payment into a health or welfare fund, a pension fund, a vacation plan, or any other similar fund or plan for employees shall make the payment within 30 days after it is required.

paragraph.text: An employer or union official who knowingly fails to make a payment under subsection (a) or (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
If the employer is a corporation, each corporate officer who exercises executive functions is guilty of a misdemeanor.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a refusal to leave property based on a bona fide claim of ownership of or other right to the property.

An employee or former employee may not remain on property that is under the legal control of an employer after the employer or an agent of the employer gives the employee or former employee notice to leave if remaining deprives or is intended to deprive the employer of the substantial control, possession, or use of the property.
A person who violates any provision of subsection (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50.
An organization that is responsible for a violation of this section is liable financially to the owner of the property for the loss of revenue or from damage that results from the violation.

A person who is not directly interested in a strike may not provide, obtain, recruit, or refer, for employment in place of a striker, an individual who customarily and repeatedly offers to be employed in place of strikers.
