paragraph.text: An employee may not:

subparagraph.text: make a groundless or malicious complaint to the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner;
in bad faith, bring an action under this subtitle; or
in bad faith, testify in an action under this subtitle or a proceeding that relates to the subject of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may bring an action for injunctive relief and damages against a person who violates the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may require, by regulation, that an employer:

paragraph.text: measure or monitor employee exposure to a potentially toxic material or harmful physical agent; and
keep an accurate record of employee exposure to a toxic material or harmful physical agent that the employer is required to measure or monitor.

subsection.text: An employer shall give an employee or representative of an employee an opportunity to observe each measurement or monitoring under this section.

If an employee is exposed to a potentially toxic material or harmful physical agent in a concentration or level that exceeds the level allowed under an applicable occupational safety and health standard, the employer of the employee:

paragraph.text: promptly shall give the employee notice; and
shall inform the employee of each corrective action being taken.
Each employee or former employee shall have access to each record that indicates exposure of the employee or former employee to a toxic material or harmful agent.
Each employee or representative of an employee shall have access to each record kept under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may require, by regulation, that an employer keep:

paragraph.text: an accurate record of:

subparagraph.text: each work-related death;
each work-related illness; and

each work-related injury other than a minor injury that requires only first aid treatment and does not involve loss of consciousness, medical treatment, restriction of motion or work, or transfer to another job; and

paragraph.text: each other record about an activity of the employer under this title that the Commissioner considers appropriate or necessary to develop information about the causes and prevention of occupational accidents, illnesses, and injuries.

subsection.text: Each employer shall make available to the Commissioner each record that the employer is required to keep under subsection (a)(2) of this section.

paragraph.text: An employer shall report orally to the Commissioner an employment accident within 8 hours after it occurs if the accident results in:

subparagraph.text: the death of an employee; or
hospitalization of at least three employees.

paragraph.text: Each employer shall send to the Commissioner a copy of each report of an accident or injury that the employer:

subparagraph.text: is required, under Title 9 of this article, to send to the Workers’ Compensation Commission; or
submits to the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may require, by regulation, that an employer keep each record about an activity of the employer that relates to this title as the Commissioner considers appropriate or necessary to enforce this title.
Each employer shall make available to the Commissioner each record that the employer is required to keep under this section.

section.text: The Commissioner may require, by regulation, that an employer submit reports on the basis of the records that the employer keeps under this title.
The penalties in this subtitle do not apply to a public body.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make a false certification, false representation, or false statement in an application, plan, record, report, or other document that is filed or required to be kept under this title.

A person who violates any provision of subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.
Unless the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner gives written approval, a person may not give advance notice of an inspection to be made under this title.
A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

section.text: If an employer willfully violates any provision of this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation adopted to carry out this title and the violation caused death to an employee, on conviction the employer is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first offense, a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both; or
for a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $20,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

For the purpose of this subsection, a violation is considered to be a serious violation if there is a substantial probability that death or serious physical harm could result from a condition that exists or a practice, means, method, operation, or process that has been adopted or is in use, unless the employer did not and with the exercise of reasonable diligence could not know of the violation.

The Commissioner shall assess a civil penalty against an employer who receives a citation for a serious violation of this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation adopted to carry out this title.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall assess a civil penalty against an employer who violates a requirement for posting imposed under this title.
The Commissioner may assess a civil penalty against an employer who:

paragraph.text: willfully or repeatedly violates this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation adopted to carry out this title; or

receives a citation for a violation of a provision of this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation adopted to carry out this title and there is a specific determination that the violation is not of a serious nature.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may assess a civil penalty against an employer who does not correct a violation for which a citation is issued within the period set under this title for correction.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a civil penalty under § 5-809 of this subtitle may not exceed:

subparagraph.text: $7,000 for each violation; and
if an employer does not correct a violation within the period allowed for correction, $7,000 for each day that the violation continues.

paragraph.text: A civil penalty for a willful or repeated violation of a provision of this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation adopted to carry out this title may not exceed $70,000 for each violation.
A civil penalty for a willful violation of a provision of this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation adopted to carry out this title may not be less than $5,000.

subsection.text: Before the Commissioner assesses a civil penalty under § 5-809 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall consider the appropriateness of the penalty in relation to:

paragraph.text: the size of the business of the employer against whom the penalty is to be assessed;
the gravity of the violation for which the penalty is to be assessed;
the good faith of the employer;
the history of violations by the employer;
the injury and illness experience of the employer;
the existence and quality of a safety and training program;
the actual harm to human health including injury or illness;
the extent to which the current violation is part of a recurrent pattern of the same or similar type of violation; and
the extent to which the existence of the violation was known to the employer but remained not corrected.

subsection.text: If a civil penalty that is assessed under this title is not paid in full within 30 days after the penalty becomes final, the Commissioner or the Central Collection Unit may proceed in the District Court to enforce payment.
In a proceeding under this subsection, the Commissioner or the Central Collection Unit is entitled to judgment in the amount of the civil penalty that remains unpaid on a showing that:

paragraph.text: the penalty was assessed against the defendant;
the penalty has become final;
no appeal is pending;
the penalty is wholly or partly unpaid; and
the defendant:

subparagraph.text: was duly served with a copy of the citation in accordance with the applicable regulations of the Commissioner; or
contested the citation for which the penalty was assessed.

section.text: Each civil penalty under this title shall be paid into the General Fund of the State.
This title may be cited as the “Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act”.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

paragraph.text: “Employee” includes each person in the service of a railroad who performs for the railroad any work defined as work of an employee in accordance with orders and decisions of the federal Department of Transportation and over whom the railroad maintains continuing authority to supervise and direct the manner of the work.
“Employee” does not include any person who performs work for a rapid rail transit system or light rail system operating in the State.

“Railroad” includes each common carrier by rail and all branches, bridges, cars, extensions, ferries, plants, spurs, stations, subways, switches, terminal facilities, tracks, tunnels, and all equipment used on or in connection with them.
“Railroad” does not include a rapid rail transit system or light rail system operating in the State.

subsection.text: “Railroad company” means:

paragraph.text: the operator of a railroad operating in the State; and
the State or any political subdivision of the State, while operating a railroad.
“Working day” means any day that occurs Monday through Friday unless the day is designated as a holiday for employees of the State.
“Working day” does not include a Saturday or Sunday.

section.text: It is the intent and purpose of this title to promote safety and health in all areas of railroad operations, to reduce railroad related accidents, to reduce deaths and injuries to all persons, to reduce damage to property caused by accidents involving railroads, and to the extent possible, to assure the safety and health of all persons and the protection of property by providing for:

paragraph.text: an effective enforcement and compliance program;
development and adoption of safety and health standards and regulations; and

appropriate reporting procedures with respect to safety and health in railroad operations to help achieve the objective of this title and to describe accurately the nature of railroad safety and health hazards and problems.

section.text: This title does not apply to any acceptable working conditions defined in a collective bargaining agreement.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: administer and enforce the provisions of this title;
adopt regulations to establish rules of procedure for hearings held in accordance with this title;
establish record keeping and reporting procedures necessary to carry out the duties created under this title;
accept and receive from any agency or agent of the federal government grants of money appropriated under any act of the United States Congress relating to railroad safety and health; and
have exclusive jurisdiction involving all areas of railroad safety and health as provided under this title.

To carry out this title, the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner may administer an oath, certify to an official act, take or cause to be taken a deposition of a witness, or issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of papers, books, documents, records, and testimony.

If a person fails to comply with a lawfully issued subpoena, on application of the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner in a contempt proceeding, a court of competent jurisdiction may compel the person to comply.

subsection.text: To assist in carrying out this title, the Commissioner may accept and use any service, facility, or employee of any unit of the State or political subdivision, with the consent of the unit or subdivision and with or without reimbursement.
The Commissioner may assign any function or duty under this title to the Chief Inspector for Railroad Safety and Health.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, the Commissioner has no jurisdiction in any area of railroad safety and health under this title relating to any rapid rail transit system or light rail system operating in the State.

section.text: For any construction within 8 feet 6 inches laterally from the center line of a railroad track or within 22 feet above the top of the rail, the application for a building permit must be accompanied by a clearance certificate from the Commissioner to show that the proposed construction complies with requirements relating to distance from and height over a railroad track.

paragraph.text: The proposed budget of the Division of Labor and Industry shall include an appropriation from the Public Service Commission to cover the cost of administering this title.

Unless the Board of Public Works exercises the option under subsection (b) of this section, the Public Service Commission shall pay the cost of administering this title from money the Public Service Commission receives under § 2–110 of the Public Utilities Article.

The Board of Public Works may adopt a regulation to assess, fairly and as equally as possible, each railroad company operating in the State the cost of the State’s share of activities under this title.
The amount to be paid by the Public Service Commission may not exceed $1 million in any fiscal year.

section.text: On request of the Commissioner, the Attorney General may proceed in a State or federal court or before any other federal unit:

paragraph.text: to enforce a decision of the Commissioner under this title;
subject to § 3-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, to collect a civil penalty that is assessed by order of the Commissioner under this title; or
to enforce any other order of the Commissioner under this title.

subsection.text: As necessary, the Commissioner shall adopt appropriate health and safety standards and other regulations relating to:

paragraph.text: sanitation on railroad property as it affects the health of railroad employees, including clerical employees, engine workers, express employees, freight house employees, highway crossing watchmen, maintenance of way employees, platform employees, train workers, and yard workers; and
all other areas of railroad safety and health.
To adopt a railroad health and safety standard or other regulation, the Commissioner shall comply with this section and Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article.
An economic impact statement prepared in accordance with § 10-111(c) of the State Government Article shall:

subparagraph.text: include direct and indirect effects of the regulation on the railroad industry, the public, and railroad employees; and
set forth any alternative approach available.

paragraph.text: If acceptable alternative approaches are available in adoption of a regulation, the Commissioner shall adopt the approach that has the least burdensome economic impact on the railroad industry, the public, and railroad employees.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, railroad health and safety standards and other regulations that the Commissioner adopts shall be effective as provided in § 10-117 of the State Government Article.

The Commissioner may delay the effective date of a regulation for not more than 90 days to ensure that railroad companies have an opportunity to familiarize their agents and employees with the requirements of the regulation.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this title but subject to the limitations on emergency adoption in Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article, the Commissioner may adopt immediately an emergency health and safety standard that the Commissioner determines is needed to protect the public and employees from the grave danger of exposure to an agent or condition determined to be toxic or physically harmful.
An emergency health and safety standard adopted under this subsection remains in effect until the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: expiration of a period that the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review sets;
expiration of a period, not exceeding 6 months, that the Commissioner sets; or
replacement of the emergency health and safety standard by another regulation adopted in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: On request of a railroad company:

subparagraph.text: the Commissioner shall hold a hearing and receive evidence pertaining to any emergency temporary health and safety standard; and
within 10 days after the request for a hearing, the Commissioner shall revoke, modify, or continue the standard.

paragraph.text: If a railroad company is aggrieved by an emergency temporary standard:

subparagraph.text: the railroad company shall have the right to an immediate appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction; and
the court shall hear and decide the appeal.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall keep in the office of the Commissioner a set of the current regulations adopted to carry out this title.
The Commissioner may set a fee for the cost to prepare and mail a copy of the current regulations.
On request and payment of the fee, if any, the Commissioner shall send a person a copy of the current regulations.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a locomotive that is used only for yard-switching service.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may adopt regulations that regulate the sanitary condition of locomotives.

Regulations adopted under this subsection shall require basic health and safety standards, in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, for drinking water and toilet and hand towel facilities.

subsection.text: Before adoption of regulations under subsection (b) of this section, the Commissioner shall announce and hold a public hearing.
A railroad company may not transport an employee to or from work on a caboose or locomotive unless the railroad company provides a fixed seat with a back support for the employee.
To protect the health and safety of employees, a railroad company shall:

paragraph.text: install and maintain water or chemical toilet facilities on each caboose used for service beyond a 15-mile radius from a point of dispatchment within the State for use by employees, unless the caboose is a temporary substitute for one regularly used for the service; and
enclose all toilet fixtures, within the caboose, in a separate compartment of sufficient dimensions that is ventilated properly.
This subsection does not apply to any caboose:

subparagraph.text: operated on tracks of less than standard gauge;
normally used only during daylight hours;
operated only within a 20-mile radius from point of dispatchment; or
temporarily substituted for a regular caboose.

paragraph.text: To protect the health and safety of employees, the Commissioner shall require each railroad company to install and maintain:

subparagraph.text: two or more electric marker lights on the rear of each caboose in service; and
one electric light for clerical work within each caboose in service, for which the railroad company shall determine the source of electricity and type of appliance.

subsection.text: A railroad company may not have a common towel or common drinking cup available for use on property of the railroad company.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to designated cleanout and repair tracks.

To provide employees a reasonably safe place to work, each railroad company shall keep and maintain free from debris and vegetation that unreasonably affects employee safety the margins alongside yard tracks and sidetracks where employees are required to walk frequently in the course of their duties.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner finds any condition in or on a yard track or sidetrack or in a walkway that constitutes an immediate danger to the health or safety of the public or any railroad employee, or any condition in a sidetrack or switch that constitutes a danger to the health or safety of a railroad employee, the yard track, sidetrack, or switch may be closed immediately until the condition is corrected.

paragraph.text: This section and § 5.5-123(c) of this title shall be enforced by the Commissioner on a complaint and after a hearing.
Each day of noncompliance with an order that the Commissioner issues under this section shall be regarded as a separate violation.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall allow variances in accordance with this section.
Any affected railroad company may apply in writing to the Commissioner for an order for a variance from any regulation or health and safety standard adopted under this title.
After a hearing, the Commissioner may grant a variance from the regulations and standards adopted under this title, if:

paragraph.text: that action is necessary to prevent undue operational or economic hardship; or

subparagraph.text: existing conditions prevent practical compliance; and
the Commissioner determines the reasonable safety of the public and employees of the railroad company can be assured.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall conduct inspections and investigations in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this section apply to each railroad establishment, site, plant, workplace, place of employment, environment, or other area.
The Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner may enter a railroad area without delay at any reasonable time to:

subparagraph.text: inspect the railroad area;
investigate all pertinent apparatus, conditions, devices, equipment, materials, and structures at the railroad area; and
question any agent or employee of the railroad, if the railroad and an employee representative receive notice of and an opportunity to attend the questioning session.

subsection.text: The provisions of § 12-101 of the Public Safety Article concerning administrative search warrants apply to this title.
A person may not give advance notice of any inspection to be conducted under this title without the written approval of the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner.
An employee of a railroad company or representative of employees may request inspection of a railroad if the employee or representative believes, in good faith, that:

paragraph.text: there is imminent danger to employees; or
due to a violation of a health and safety standard adopted under this title, there is a threat of severe physical harm to an employee.

subsection.text: To request an inspection, an employee or representative of employees shall sign and submit to the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner a written notice that describes, with reasonable particularity, the grounds for the notice.
On receipt of a notice made in accordance with this section, the Commissioner shall determine whether there are reasonable grounds to believe that imminent danger or a threat exists.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner determines that there are reasonable grounds, the Commissioner shall conduct an investigation as soon as practicable to determine whether the danger or threat exists.
If the Commissioner determines that there are no reasonable grounds, the Commissioner shall give the person who submitted the request written notice of that determination.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a copy of the notice under subsection (b) of this section shall be given to the railroad company or representative of the railroad company no later than at the time of the inspection.

On request of the person who submits a notice under subsection (b) of this section, the name of the person and the name of each employee to whom the notice refers may not appear in the copy of the notice to be given to the railroad company and in each other record to be disclosed under this title.

If an employee or representative of the employee files a complaint with the Commissioner charging the employer with a violation of a regulation adopted by the Commissioner under § 5.5-108 of this title, or the Commissioner issues a complaint, the Commissioner shall serve the employer with a copy of the complaint.
Within 20 days after receipt of the complaint, the employer shall file a written answer with the Commissioner.
Within 10 days after an answer is filed, the Commissioner shall set a date for a hearing on the complaint.
The Commissioner may allow any interested person or organization to intervene.
A party to the hearing may appear and be heard in person or by a representative and may examine and cross-examine witnesses or present evidence.
On motion of a party, the Commissioner may allow a continuance for not more than 30 days.

subsection.text: In this section, “apparatus” means any machinery, device, or equipment or any part of any machinery, device, or equipment.

The Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner shall give written notice to a railroad company or the railroad company’s agent in charge of the operation, if, after an inspection or investigation of the railroad, the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner determines that:

paragraph.text: an apparatus violates a health and safety standard adopted under this title; and
there is a substantial probability that death or serious physical harm to an individual or damage to property could result from continued use of the apparatus.
A copy of a notice under subsection (b) of this section:

subparagraph.text: shall be attached to the apparatus; and
may not be removed until the apparatus is made safe and each required safeguard is provided.

paragraph.text: Except for use that is necessary to repair the apparatus and to provide any required safeguards, the apparatus may not be used while a notice under this section is posted on the apparatus.
Only the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner may remove the notice.
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Commissioner under this section may appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the Maryland Rules.
An action under this subsection shall be brought in the court of competent jurisdiction where the apparatus is located.
In a proceeding under this subsection, a court may not stay an order of the Commissioner unless:

subparagraph.text: the court gives the Commissioner notice and an opportunity for a hearing; and
the aggrieved person posts security.

paragraph.text: The court shall expedite the hearing of any action brought under this subsection.

subsection.text: If, after an inspection or investigation, the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner is of the opinion that a railroad company has violated this title or a regulation or health and safety standard adopted or order issued to carry out this title, the Commissioner or authorized representative of the Commissioner shall, with reasonable promptness, issue a citation to the railroad company.
Each citation under this section shall:

paragraph.text: describe, with particularity, the nature of the alleged violation;
refer to the provision of this title, order, regulation, or health and safety standard that the railroad company is alleged to have violated; and
set a reasonable period for abatement and correction of the alleged violation.

subsection.text: In accordance with any regulation that the Commissioner adopts to carry out this title, a railroad company that is issued a citation shall prominently post the citation or a copy of it as set forth in regulations adopted by the Commissioner.
No citation may be issued after 6 months after the occurrence of a violation.

Within a reasonable time after issuance of a citation under § 5.5-116 of this title, the Commissioner shall send by certified mail to the railroad company at its principal place of business a notice that:

paragraph.text: states that the citation has been issued and any civil penalty that will be assessed under this title; and

informs the railroad company that, within 15 working days after receipt of the notice, the railroad company may submit to the Commissioner a written notice of contest on the citation or civil penalty.

subsection.text: A citation and any penalty that the Commissioner proposes to assess shall be considered a final order of the Commissioner unless within 15 working days after receipt of a notice under subsection (a) of this section the railroad company notifies the Commissioner of an intent to contest the citation or any penalty.
A railroad company shall correct each violation for which the Commissioner issues a citation within the period set for correction in a final order under this title.

If the Commissioner has reason to believe that a railroad company has failed to correct a violation within the time allowed, the Commissioner shall send by certified mail to the railroad company a notice that:

paragraph.text: states that the railroad company has failed to correct the violation;
states the civil penalty, if any, that the Commissioner intends to assess under § 5.5-121 of this title for the failure; and
informs the railroad company that, within 15 working days after receipt of the notice, the railroad company may submit to the Commissioner a written notice of contest on the notice or civil penalty.

subsection.text: Unless a railroad company notifies the Commissioner within 15 days after receipt of the notification issued by the Commissioner of an intent to contest as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the notice, including any civil penalty, is a final order.

The Commissioner shall grant a hearing, if practicable, within 30 days after receipt of a notice that a railroad company or representative of a railroad company submits under § 5.5-116 or § 5.5-117 of this title.
The Commissioner shall give notice and hold a hearing under this title in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: When the Commissioner appoints an administrative law judge to hold a hearing under this section, the administrative law judge shall prepare a record that includes testimony.
A written report that an administrative law judge submits shall become a final order of the Commissioner unless, within 15 working days after submission of the report, the:

subparagraph.text: Commissioner orders a review of the proceeding; or
railroad company or any affected person submits to the Commissioner a written request for a review of the proceeding.

paragraph.text: After review of a proceeding under subsection (b) of this section, with or without a hearing, the Commissioner shall pass an order that, based on findings of fact, affirms, modifies, or vacates the citation or proposed penalty or directs other appropriate relief.
An order of the Commissioner under paragraph (1) of this subsection is final on the date of issuance of the order.

subsection.text: After an opportunity for a hearing under this section, the Commissioner may pass an order that affirms or modifies a requirement of a citation for abatement of a violation on a showing by the affected railroad company that it:

paragraph.text: made a good faith effort to comply with the requirement; and
has not complied because of a factor beyond the reasonable control of the railroad company.

subsection.text: A person adversely affected or aggrieved by any order that the Commissioner passes under this title or any regulation or health and safety standard that the Commissioner adopts to carry out this title may appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the Maryland Rules.
In a proceeding under this section, a court may not stay an order, regulation, or health and safety standard of the Commissioner unless:

paragraph.text: the court gives the Commissioner notice and an opportunity for a hearing; and
the aggrieved person posts security and meets each other condition that the court considers proper.

subsection.text: A regulation or health and safety standard that the Commissioner adopts to carry out this title may not be held invalid because of a technical defect if there is substantial compliance with this title.

paragraph.text: At any appropriate time, the Commissioner may file a complaint to enforce any order that the Commissioner passes under this title or regulation or health and safety standard that the Commissioner adopts to carry out this title.
A complaint filed under this subsection shall be filed in a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the Maryland Administrative Procedure Act and the Maryland Rules.

subsection.text: A court expeditiously shall hear a complaint under this section.

If the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner concludes that a condition or practice in the operation of any railroad creates an imminent danger that reasonably could be expected to cause death or serious physical harm to an individual or serious physical damage to property, the authorized representative:

paragraph.text: shall give notice of the danger to the railroad company and each employee whom the danger affects; and
may recommend that the Commissioner seek to enjoin the condition or practice.
On a complaint filed by the Commissioner, a circuit court:

subparagraph.text: may enjoin a condition or practice at a railroad company if the condition or practice creates an imminent danger that reasonably could be expected to cause death or serious physical harm to an individual or serious physical damage to property; and
may grant an injunction or temporary restraining order, pending the outcome of enforcement procedures under this title.

paragraph.text: A temporary restraining order that is passed without notice may not be in effect for more than 7 days.
An injunction under this subsection may require each act needed to:

subparagraph.text: avoid, correct, or remove the imminent danger; or
prohibit the employment or presence of any individual in a location or under a condition where the imminent danger exists other than an individual who needs to be present to:

sub-subparagraph.text: remove the imminent danger; or
where operations must be stopped, stop an operation in an orderly and safe manner.

paragraph.text: A railroad company shall promptly report, in writing or orally, to the Commissioner, after the occurrence of an accident resulting in:

subparagraph.text: a serious injury or fatality to an individual; or
damage to property exceeding $2,900, or any other sum as determined by federal regulations, incurred during the operation of the railroad in the State.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall investigate the occurrence promptly after receiving notification of the accident.

subsection.text: A railroad company shall promptly submit to the Commissioner copies of all accident and incident reports filed with the Federal Railroad Administration of accidents and incidents occurring in the State.

A person who violates any regulation adopted by the Commissioner under § 5.5-109 of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction for each offense is subject to a fine not exceeding the lesser of the penalty provided by the regulation or $100.

If a railroad company willfully violates any provision of this title or any order, regulation, or health and safety standard adopted under this title, and the violation caused death to an individual, on conviction the railroad company is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first offense, a fine not exceeding $25,000; or
for a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $50,000.

A person may not knowingly make a false certification, false representation, or false statement in an application, plan, record, report, or other document that is filed or required to be kept under this title.
A person who violates paragraph (1) of this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

Unless the Commissioner or an authorized representative of the Commissioner authorizes advance notice of an inspection, a person may not give advance notice of an inspection to be conducted under this title.
A person who violates paragraph (1) of this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall impose civil penalties under this title.

paragraph.text: For the purpose of this subsection, a violation is considered to be a serious violation if there is substantial probability that death or serious physical harm could result from a condition that exists or a practice, means, method, or operation that is in use by the railroad company, unless the railroad company did not know and with the exercise of reasonable diligence could not have known of the violation.
The Commissioner may assess a civil penalty against a railroad company that:

subparagraph.text: willfully violates this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation or health and safety standard adopted to carry out this title and the violation is specifically determined to be of a serious nature, an amount not exceeding $10,000 for each violation;

receives a citation for a violation of a provision of this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation or health and safety standard adopted to carry out this title and the violation is specifically determined to be of a serious nature, an amount not exceeding $1,000 for each violation; or

receives a citation for a violation of a provision of this title, an order passed under this title, or a regulation or health and safety standard adopted to carry out this title and the violation is specifically determined not to be of a serious nature, an amount not exceeding $500 for each violation.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may assess a civil penalty not exceeding $100 against a railroad company for each violation of a requirement for posting imposed under this title.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may assess a civil penalty of not less than $100 and not exceeding $500 against a railroad company that violates a maintenance requirement for yard track margins and sidetracks for employee safety under § 5.5-111 of this title.
Each day of noncompliance with any order that the Commissioner issues under § 5.5-111 of this title shall be considered a separate violation.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall assess against an agent of a railroad company a civil penalty of $100 for each employee that the agent requires to ride more than 5 miles without a seat as required under § 5.5-110(a) of this title, regardless of whether the employee is in active service.

If a railroad company does not correct a violation for which a citation has been issued within the period set for correction in accordance with § 5.5-116 of this title, the Commissioner may impose a civil penalty not exceeding $100 for each day that the violation continues.
Before the Commissioner assesses a civil penalty under this section, the Commissioner shall consider the appropriateness of the penalty in relation to:

paragraph.text: the size of the railroad company;
the gravity of the violation for which the penalty is to be assessed;
the good faith of the railroad company; and
the history of violations by the railroad company.
Each civil penalty under this section shall be payable into the General Fund of the State 90 days after the violation becomes final and nonreviewable.
The Commissioner shall reduce the penalty by 50% if during the 90-day period:

subparagraph.text: the railroad company had no reportable accidents attributable to a State or federal regulation; or
the railroad has not committed a willful or serious violation as described in this section.

section.text: In this title, “high voltage line” means an electric line that:

paragraph.text: is installed above ground level; and
has a voltage of more than 750 volts:

subparagraph.text: between conductors; or
from a conductor to a ground.

section.text: This title does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the maintenance or repair of an electric power plant or system that a private company or corporation owns or operates for production of electricity for its own use; or

the construction, maintenance, or operation of a high voltage line and its support structures and associated equipment by a public utility that the Public Service Commission regulates or an agent or contractor of the utility.

section.text: Until determined otherwise from the owner or operator of an electric line that is above ground level, the electric line is presumed:

paragraph.text: to be energized on and at all times after installation or erection; and
to have a voltage of more than 750 volts.

section.text: The Division of Labor and Industry shall administer and enforce this title.

subsection.text: Whenever an individual who is authorized to inspect property in the State is denied access after the individual makes a proper request for access to inspect to the owner, lessee, or other person in charge of the property, the individual may apply to the District Court for an administrative search warrant under this title.
Each application under this section shall:

paragraph.text: state the nature, purpose, and scope of the inspection; and
show that:

subparagraph.text: the applicant:

sub-subparagraph.text: is authorized by law to make the inspection; and
requested access at a reasonable time;

subparagraph.text: access was denied; and
the inspection is for a purpose related to safety or health.

subsection.text: An application may not be submitted to the District Court unless approved by the Attorney General.
On application in accordance with this section, the District Court may issue an administrative search warrant.

section.text: If any part of an individual or object will come within 10 feet of a high voltage line while performing the activity, a person shall comply with § 6-107 of this title before the person may perform, or require or allow an employee to perform, any of the following activities:

paragraph.text: moving all or any part of a building or other structure;
trimming a tree or doing any similar activity; or
erecting, operating, storing, transporting, or otherwise handling any object, including:

subparagraph.text: an antenna;
an antenna support;
equipment;
a flagpole;
machinery;
material;
tools; or
other apparatus.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, whenever an activity listed under § 6–106 of this title is to be performed within 10 feet of a high voltage line, the person responsible for performing the activity shall:

paragraph.text: promptly notify the owner or operator of the high voltage line of the activity to be performed;
make any appropriate arrangements with the owner or operator of the high voltage line to carry out any safety measures required by item (3) of this subsection; and

with any necessary cooperation from and subject to any necessary agreement with the owner or operator of the high voltage line, ensure that the high voltage line has been effectively guarded against accidental contact by:

subparagraph.text: installing physical barriers to prevent physical contact with the high voltage line;
relocating the high voltage line; or
de–energizing and grounding the high voltage line.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only when a local government performs maintenance on street lighting equipment owned by the local government.
Whenever an activity listed under § 6–106 of this title is to be performed within 10 feet of a high voltage line, the person responsible for performing the activity shall:

subparagraph.text: comply with the National Electrical Safety Code; and
be qualified as defined in the National Electrical Safety Code.

subsection.text: The owner or operator of a high voltage line shall perform any act that is reasonably necessary to carry out the safety measures required by § 6-107 of this title to guard effectively against accidental contact with the high voltage line:

paragraph.text: after notification from a person who intends to perform an activity listed under § 6-106 of this subtitle within 10 feet of a high voltage line;
after the person who intends to perform the activity has made any appropriate arrangements; and
within a reasonable time.

subsection.text: This section does not require an owner or operator of a high voltage line to:

paragraph.text: bear the expense of any safety measure required by this title; or
de-energize or ground any high voltage line if doing so would:

subparagraph.text: substantially interfere with service to the public; or
endanger the health, safety, or welfare of the public.

subsection.text: “Equipment” includes a crane, derrick, pile driver, power shovel, trimming rig, or similar apparatus.
This section applies to any equipment if all or any part of the equipment may be used near any high voltage line.
The owner, lessee, or user of any equipment to which this section applies shall become acquainted and acquaint its employees with this title and regulations adopted to carry out this title.

paragraph.text: The owner, lessee, or user of any equipment to which this section applies shall keep a warning sign posted:

subparagraph.text: on the equipment in clear view of its operator while at the controls of the equipment;
on the outside of the equipment in clear view of each individual helping the operator from outside of the equipment; and
on the boom of each crane or derrick so that, when the boom is raised, the sign is at the eye level of the operator.

paragraph.text: Each sign shall state, in lettering that is legible from a distance of at least 12 feet: “Unlawful to operate this equipment within 10 feet of any electric wire”.
Each sign shall be permanent and weather resistant.

section.text: A person who fails to comply with or violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agricultural operation” means:

paragraph.text: a person:

subparagraph.text: who performs a farm labor contracting service; and
who:

sub-subparagraph.text: owns or operates a farm;
owns or operates a cannery, packing shed, or other processing establishment; or
produces or conditions seed; or

paragraph.text: a not-for-profit or cooperative association that:

subparagraph.text: performs a farm labor contracting service;
consists of owners or operators of farms; and
is incorporated or qualified under the laws of the State.

subsection.text: “Agricultural work” means employment:

paragraph.text: on a farm, in any activity that relates to the maintenance, management, or operation of the farm or its tools or other equipment, including cultivation of soil, raising of bees, or the growing, harvesting, or producing of an agricultural or horticultural commodity; or

by the owner or operator of a farm, to dry, to freeze, to grade, to pack, to package, to plant, to process, or otherwise to handle an agricultural or horticultural commodity in its unmanufactured state before delivery for storage.

subsection.text: “Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

paragraph.text: “Farm” means an area that is used primarily to raise an agricultural or horticultural commodity.
“Farm” includes:

subparagraph.text: a dairy farm;
a fruit farm;
a furbearing animal farm;
a greenhouse;
a nursery;
an orchard;
a poultry farm;
a ranch;
a stock farm; and
a truck farm.

subsection.text: “Farm labor contractor” means a person, other than an agricultural operation or an employee of an agricultural operation, who performs a farm labor contracting service for consideration.
“License” means a license issued by the Commissioner to perform farm labor contracting services for consideration.
“Licensed farm labor contractor” means an individual who is licensed by the Commissioner to perform farm labor contracting services for consideration.

paragraph.text: “Migrant agricultural worker” means, except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an individual who:

subparagraph.text: is employed to perform agricultural work of a seasonal or other temporary nature; and
in the course of employment:

sub-subparagraph.text: is absent overnight from the permanent place of residence of the individual; or
as part of a day-haul operation, is transported or caused to be transported by a farm labor contractor or an agent of a farm labor contractor to or from the place of employment.

paragraph.text: “Migrant agricultural worker” does not include:

subparagraph.text: an immediate family member of the owner or operator of a farm or a cannery, packing shed, or other processing establishment;
an immediate family member of an individual who produces or conditions seeds;
an immediate family member of a farm labor contractor; or
a nonimmigrant alien, as defined in 8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(15)(H)(ii)(a), who is authorized under federal law to work in agricultural employment in the United States.

subsection.text: “Perform a farm labor contracting service” means to recruit, to employ, to hire, to provide, to solicit, to transport, or to provide housing for a migrant agricultural worker.
This title does not apply:

paragraph.text: to a common carrier or an employee of a common carrier solely because it transports a migrant agricultural worker;
to a custom grain combine, hay harvesting, or sheep shearing operation or to an employee of the operation while the employee is performing a farm labor contracting service only for the operation;

to an individual who performs farm labor contracting services, or an employee of the individual while the employee is performing a farm labor contracting service only for the individual, within a 25-mile intrastate radius of the permanent place of residence of the individual and not exceeding 13 weeks a year;
to an agricultural operation when engaging a farm labor contractor through the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation; or
to an individual who performs farm labor contracting services only for a farm or a cannery, packing shed, seed conditioning establishment, or other processing establishment, if:

subparagraph.text: the individual or an immediate family member of the individual exclusively owns and operates the farm or establishment; and
only the individual and immediate family members of the individual perform farm labor contracting services for the farm or establishment.

subsection.text: This title does not apply:

paragraph.text: to any person other than a farm labor contractor to whom no more than 10 migrant agricultural workers are provided at any time during the current and preceding calendar years;
to an individual while acting as an employee of an agricultural operation that is excluded under item (1) of this subsection; or

to a custom operation for poultry harvesting, breeding, debeaking, sexing, or health service or to an employee of the operation while the employee is performing a farm labor contracting service only for the operation, unless the operation regularly requires an employee to be absent during nonworking hours from the domicile of the employee.

section.text: An agreement by a migrant agricultural worker to waive or modify a right of the migrant agricultural worker under this title is void as contrary to public policy.

To the extent practicable, the Commissioner shall reduce duplication of the licensing requirements and enforcement procedures under this title and any applicable federal law through an agreement with the United States Secretary of Labor that establishes a cooperative program to coordinate licensing and enforcement activities under this title with any coextensive program that the Department of Labor administers.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall administer and enforce this title.
To administer or enforce this title, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: conduct necessary investigations; and
enter, at reasonable times, without delay:

subparagraph.text: a migratory labor camp;
a place of employment; or
housing that a farm labor contractor provides to a migrant agricultural worker.

subsection.text: To administer or enforce this title, the Commissioner may administer oaths and depose witnesses.

paragraph.text: To administer or enforce this title, the Commissioner may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of books, documents, papers, and records.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection or fails to testify on any matter on which the person lawfully may be interrogated, on a complaint filed by the Commissioner, the circuit court for the county where the person resides or is then present may pass an order directing compliance with the subpoena or compelling testimony.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: may accept from any source a grant to carry out this title; and
to administer or enforce this title, may certify to official acts.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner shall keep a central public registry of all licensed farm labor contractors.

section.text: The Commissioner may delegate any power or duty of the Commissioner under this title.
On request of the Commissioner, the Attorney General may proceed in a court or before a federal unit to enforce:

paragraph.text: a decision of the Commissioner made under this title;
a subpoena issued under this title;
an order of the Commissioner passed under this title; or
the collection of a civil penalty assessed under this title.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Commissioner before the individual may perform a farm labor contracting service in the State for consideration.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: an application on the form that the Commissioner provides; and
two recent, passport sized, color photographs of the applicant; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Commissioner an application fee of $25.

subsection.text: The application shall state:

paragraph.text: the permanent place of residence of the applicant;
each address where the applicant expects to reside while in the State;
each farm labor contracting service that the applicant will perform for consideration;
the name and address of each agricultural operation for whom the applicant will perform a farm labor contracting service, in the State, for consideration;
the name and permanent address of each person who will act as custodian of records of wages that are required under this title to be kept;
the number of migrant agricultural workers that the applicant expects to use in the State to perform a farm labor contracting service for consideration;
if the applicant will provide housing or cause housing to be provided to a migrant agricultural worker:

subparagraph.text: the name of each person who will provide the housing; and
each address where the housing will be provided;

paragraph.text: if registration is required under the federal Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act, the registration identification number of the applicant;
the name of a resident agent who is acceptable to the Commissioner;
the consent of the applicant to service of process on the resident agent whenever the applicant leaves the State or otherwise is unavailable to accept service; and
other relevant information that the Commissioner requires.

subsection.text: If information required under subsection (b) of this section changes, the applicant or, if a license has been issued, the licensee shall give the Commissioner notice of the change within 10 days after the applicant or licensee knows or should have known of the change.

Information in an application or in a notice of change may not be used to imply legal responsibility on an agricultural operation for the care, custody, or activities of a migrant agricultural worker whom a farm labor contractor provides.
The Commissioner shall make application forms reasonably available at convenient locations throughout the State.

section.text: On receipt of an application for a license, the Commissioner shall investigate, as appropriate, to determine whether the applicant is entitled to be licensed.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Commissioner shall attach to each license issued under this section a photograph of the licensee.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to perform farm labor contracting services for consideration.
A license expires on the first March 1 after its effective date.
While a licensee is performing a farm labor contracting service in the State, the licensee shall:

paragraph.text: carry the license; and
show the license:

subparagraph.text: to each person with whom the licensee intends to deal as a farm labor contractor; and
on request, to an authorized employee or official of the State.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 7-309 of this subtitle, the Commissioner may deny a license to any applicant or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
knowingly makes any misrepresentation in the application;
is not the real party in interest in the application for a license and the real party in interest:

subparagraph.text: has been refused a license;
has had a license suspended or revoked; or
otherwise fails to qualify under this section for a license;

paragraph.text: fails to comply with any provision of this title;
fails to comply with any regulation that the Commissioner adopts;
fails to comply with an order that the Commissioner passes;
fails to satisfy a judgment that the Commissioner obtains under this title;
knowingly gives a migrant agricultural worker who is recruited or hired false or misleading information about the existence or conditions of employment;
fails, without just cause, to comply with any agreement or arrangement with an agricultural operation or with a migrant agricultural worker;
is found by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene to have violated a regulation of the Secretary on housing, sanitation, or safety for migrant agricultural workers;

has had a farm labor contractor registration certificate suspended or revoked by the United States Department of Labor or by another state for a reason that would justify suspension or revocation of a license in this State;
has been convicted of a felony under a law of the State or under federal law; or
during the past 5 years, has been convicted of a misdemeanor in connection with performing a farm labor contracting service if the misdemeanor relates to:

subparagraph.text: gambling;
sale, distribution, or possession of an alcoholic beverage; or
sale, distribution, or possession of a controlled dangerous substance.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article or in § 7-310 of this subtitle, before the Commissioner takes any final action under § 7-308 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Commissioner.
The Commissioner shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Commissioner may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: The Commissioner may suspend a license summarily pending the determination of a hearing under § 7-309 of this subtitle if the Commissioner finds suspension necessary to prevent abuse of or injury to a migrant agricultural worker.

subsection.text: If, after an investigation, the Commissioner has reason to believe that a person is performing a farm labor contracting service for consideration in the State without a license, the Commissioner may pass an order to require the person immediately to cease performing the farm labor contracting service.
The Commissioner shall give notice of the order and, if requested under subsection (d) of this section, hold a hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
An order passed under this section shall be:

paragraph.text: served personally; or
sent by certified mail to the last known address of the person.
Within 7 days after service of an order under this section, the person may submit to the Commissioner a written request for a hearing.
Unless a person requests a hearing in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection, the order is final.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Commissioner may require a farm labor contractor to post a surety bond or other security if the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: finds that the farm labor contractor has violated a provision of this title or any order that the Commissioner passes or regulation that the Commissioner adopts; or
receives a certified record of the finding of a unit of another state or the United States that the farm labor contractor has violated any law that relates to:

subparagraph.text: registration as a farm labor contractor; or
the employment of, provision of housing for, or transportation of a migrant agricultural worker.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may not require security on the basis of an administrative decision that a court nullifies.
The Commissioner may require security in an amount that the Commissioner considers adequate to ensure compliance with the laws of the State.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Commissioner in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: In accordance with this section, each farm labor contractor shall disclose to each migrant agricultural worker:

subparagraph.text: each place of employment in the State;
a description of the crops and activities involved;
each condition of employment at each place of employment, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the wage to be paid;
the person who will pay the wage; and
when the wage is due;

subparagraph.text: the housing, insurance, or transportation that will be provided to the migrant agricultural worker;
any cost that will be charged to the migrant agricultural worker for housing, insurance, or transportation; and
each labor dispute that the farm labor contractor knows exists at a place of employment.

paragraph.text: Each farm labor contractor shall disclose to a migrant agricultural worker the information required under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: before the farm labor contractor causes the migrant agricultural worker to enter the State to perform agricultural work;
if the migrant agricultural worker is recruited in the State, before the farm labor contractor recruits the migrant agricultural worker to perform agricultural work; or

if the farm labor contractor is in the State with a migrant agricultural worker and has recruited the migrant agricultural worker when an agricultural operation asks the farm labor contractor to perform a farm labor contracting service, before the farm labor contractor performs the service.

subsection.text: Each farm labor contractor who provides housing for a migrant agricultural worker, by agreement with an agricultural operation or otherwise, shall ensure that all of the conditions of occupancy are posted conspicuously while the migrant agricultural worker stays in the housing.
Information that a farm labor contractor is required to disclose under this section shall be:

paragraph.text: in writing; and
in English or, as necessary and reasonable for migrant agricultural workers who are not fluent or literate in English, in Spanish or another language common to the migrant agricultural workers.

subsection.text: On request, the Commissioner shall make available to a farm labor contractor forms to be used to disclose information as required under this section.

section.text: Unless there is just cause for noncompliance, each farm labor contractor shall comply with:

paragraph.text: each written agreement with an agricultural operation that relates to performing a farm labor contracting service or to protecting a migrant agricultural worker under this title;
each written agreement or working arrangement with a migrant agricultural worker; and
each written description of conditions of employment, housing, or transportation that is required under this subtitle to be disclosed to migrant agricultural workers.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may require, by regulation, a farm labor contractor to keep records of:

paragraph.text: wages owed to each migrant agricultural worker for agricultural work performed in the State; and
wages paid to each migrant agricultural worker for agricultural work performed in the State.

subsection.text: A farm labor contractor shall keep all of the records required under subsection (a) of this section even if the farm labor contractor is not responsible for paying a migrant agricultural worker.

Each farm labor contractor shall ensure that each vehicle that the farm labor contractor uses or causes to be used to transport a migrant agricultural worker in the State meets applicable federal and State standards for safety.

Each farm labor contractor shall ensure that the driver of each vehicle that the farm labor contractor uses or causes to be used to transport a migrant agricultural worker in the State is authorized under Title 16 of the Transportation Article to drive the vehicle.

paragraph.text: Each farm labor contractor shall ensure that the owner of each vehicle that the farm labor contractor uses or causes to be used to transport a migrant agricultural worker in the State has a policy that insures against liability for bodily injury and damage to property that arises from the ownership or operation of the vehicle.

The Commissioner shall set, by regulation, the minimum amount of insurance coverage required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, but the amount may not exceed the coverage required under federal law.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not perform a farm labor contracting service in the State for consideration unless licensed by the Commissioner.

Unless authorized under this title to perform a farm labor contracting service for consideration, a person may not represent to the public, by the use of a title, including “licensed farm labor contractor”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to perform a farm labor contracting service in the State for consideration.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not use a farm labor contractor to perform a farm labor contracting service unless the person ascertains that the farm labor contractor is licensed by:

paragraph.text: requesting confirmation from the Commissioner that the farm labor contractor is licensed; or
examining the license.
Whenever a person makes a request under subsection (a)(1) of this section, the Commissioner shall inform the person whether the farm labor contractor is licensed.
Within 5 working days after a person makes a request under subsection (a)(1) of this section, the Commissioner shall respond in writing.
If the status changes during the term of the license, the Commissioner shall give the person who made the request written notice of the change.

If the Commissioner fails to provide the notice required under this subsection, a person is not liable for hiring a person who is not authorized to perform farm labor contracting services in the State.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (b)(4) of this section, a person may not hire or continue to use a farm labor contractor to perform a farm labor contracting service after the person receives notice from the Commissioner or otherwise learns that the farm labor contractor is not licensed.

section.text: A person may not interfere with or intimidate an official or other employee of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation assigned to carry out a function under this title.
A person may not assign or transfer a license.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this section, the Commissioner may assess a civil penalty against a person who willfully or repeatedly violates:

paragraph.text: any provision of this title;
any order passed under this title; or
any regulation adopted to carry out this title.

subsection.text: A civil penalty under this section may not exceed $5,000 for each violation.

paragraph.text: Before the Commissioner assesses a civil penalty against an agricultural operation, the Commissioner shall consider the appropriateness of the penalty in relation to:

subparagraph.text: the size of the business;
any good faith effort to comply with § 7-503 of this subtitle; and
the history of previous violations.

paragraph.text: Before the Commissioner assesses a civil penalty against a farm labor contractor, the Commissioner shall consider the appropriateness of the penalty in relation to:

subparagraph.text: the size of the business;
the gravity of the violation;
the good faith of the farm labor contractor; and
the history of previous violations in this State or in any other state that relate to licensing or to the treatment of a migrant agricultural worker.

section.text: A farm labor contractor who willfully violates any provision of this title or any regulation adopted to carry out this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject:

paragraph.text: for a first offense, to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both; and
for a subsequent offense, to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or both.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Base period” means:

paragraph.text: the first 4 of the last 5 completed calendar quarters immediately preceding the start of the benefit year; or

the 4 most recently completed calendar quarters immediately preceding the start of the benefit year only if the individual applying for benefits does not qualify for any benefits under § 8–802 of this title using the definition in item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: “Base period employer” means an employing unit who paid wages to an individual during the base period of the individual for covered employment.
“Benefit year” means a 1–year period that begins:

paragraph.text: on the 1st day of the 1st week for which an individual first files a claim for benefits; or
if an individual already has had a benefit year, on the 1st day of the 1st week for which the individual files a claim for benefits after the termination of the preceding benefit year.

subsection.text: “Benefits” means the money that is payable under this title to an individual who is unemployed.
“Board of Appeals” means the Board of Appeals of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Calendar quarter” means the period of 3 consecutive calendar months ending on March 31, June 30, September 30, or December 31, except as otherwise provided by the Secretary by regulation.
“Child support” means an obligation that is enforced under a plan that:

paragraph.text: is described in § 454 of the Social Security Act; and
has been approved by the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services under Part D of Title IV of the Social Security Act.

subsection.text: “Child support enforcement unit” means a unit of a state or political subdivision of a state that operates under a plan that:

paragraph.text: is described in § 454 of the Social Security Act; and
has been approved by the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services under Part D of Title IV of the Social Security Act.

subsection.text: “Claimant” means an individual who submits a claim for benefits.
“Contributions” means money required to be paid to the Unemployment Insurance Fund under § 8–607 of this title.
“Covered employment” means work that an individual performs for an employing unit that is the basis for benefits.
“Department” means the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

paragraph.text: “Educational institution” means an institution that offers participants, students, or trainees an organized course of study or training that is academic, technical, trade–oriented, or preparatory for gainful employment in a recognized occupation.
“Educational institution” includes an institution of higher education.

subsection.text: “Employer” means a person or governmental entity who employs at least 1 individual within the State.
“Employing unit” means:

paragraph.text: an employer that has at least 1 employee engaged in covered employment for at least part of a day;
an employer that has elected to become subject to this title under § 8–203 of this title; or
an employer that is not otherwise subject to this title but that:

subparagraph.text: within the current or preceding calendar year, is liable for any federal tax against which credit may be taken for contributions required to be paid into a State unemployment fund; or
as a condition for approval for full credit of contributions against the tax imposed by the Federal Unemployment Tax Act, is required by that Act to be an employing unit.

subsection.text: “Governmental entity” means:

paragraph.text: a governmental unit as defined in § 1–101 of this article; or
an instrumentality of:

subparagraph.text: 1 or more states;
1 or more political subdivisions of a state; or
1 or more states and political subdivisions of states.

subsection.text: “Hospital” has the meaning stated in § 19–301 of the Health – General Article.

paragraph.text: “Institution of higher education” means an educational institution that:

subparagraph.text: is a public or other not for profit institution;
is authorized to provide in the State a program of education beyond high school; and
admits as regular students only individuals with a certificate of graduation from high school or a recognized equivalent certificate for:

sub-subparagraph.text: training preparatory for employment in a recognized occupation;
work for credit toward a bachelor’s degree; or
postgraduate or postdoctoral study.

paragraph.text: “Institution of higher education” includes each college and university in the State.

subsection.text: “Lower Appeals Division” means the Lower Appeals Division of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Not for profit organization” means an organization that is:

paragraph.text: described in § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code; and
exempt from income tax under § 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: “Part–time worker” means an individual:

paragraph.text: whose availability for work is restricted to part–time work; and
who worked at least 20 hours per week in part–time work for a majority of the weeks of work in the base period.

subsection.text: “Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

paragraph.text: “State” has the meaning stated in § 1–101 of this article.

“State” does not include a territory of the United States unless the territory enacted an unemployment insurance law that complies with the standards adopted by the Secretary of Labor of the United States under the Federal Unemployment Tax Act or Title III of the Social Security Act.

subsection.text: “Tip” means compensation that:

paragraph.text: an individual receives from a customer of the individual’s employer while performing covered employment; and
is included in a written statement provided to the employer under § 6053(a) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Wages” means all compensation for personal services except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection.
“Wages” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bonus;
a commission;
a tip; and
the cash value of all compensation in any medium other than cash.

paragraph.text: “Wages” does not include:

subparagraph.text: the amount of any payment made to or on behalf of an employee or any dependent of an employee under a plan or system established by an employing unit that provides for employees generally or for their dependents or for a class of employees and their dependents on account of:

sub-subparagraph.text: retirement;
sickness or accident disability payments under a workers’ compensation law;
medical or hospitalization expenses in connection with sickness or accident disability;
a cafeteria plan as defined in 26 U.S.C. § 125, if the payments would not be treated as wages outside a cafeteria plan;
dependent care assistance to the extent that the assistance payments would be excludable from gross income under the provisions of 26 U.S.C. § 127 or § 129; or
death;

subparagraph.text: any amount that an employing unit pays for insurance or an annuity or into a fund to provide for a payment described in item (i) of this paragraph;

any payment on account of sickness or accident disability or medical or hospitalization expenses in connection with sickness or accident disability made by the employing unit to or on behalf of an employee at least 6 calendar months after the last calendar month in which the employee worked for the employing unit;
any payment made to or on behalf of an employee or beneficiary of the employee:

sub-subparagraph.text: from or to a trust exempt from tax under § 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code at the time of the payment, unless the payment is made to an employee of the trust as compensation for services rendered as an employee and not as beneficiary of the trust; or
under or to an annuity plan that, at the time of payment, meets the requirements of § 401(a)(3) through (6) of the Internal Revenue Code;

subparagraph.text: with respect to compensation paid to an employee for domestic service in a private home of the employing unit or for agricultural labor, the payment by an employing unit without deduction of the tax imposed on an employee under § 3101 of the Internal Revenue Code;
any payment required from an employee under a state unemployment insurance law;
compensation paid in any medium other than cash to an employee for service not in the course of the trade or business of the employing unit;

any payment other than vacation or sick pay made to an employee after the month in which the employee becomes 65 years old if the employee did not work for the employing unit in the period for which the payment is made;
