any payment, including an amount paid into a fund to provide for any payment by an employing unit to or on behalf of an employee under a plan or system that an employing unit establishes that provides for employees of the employing unit generally or a class or group of employees to supplement unemployment benefits;
any payment to an individual as compensation for serving or being called to serve on a jury; or

any payment to an individual as allowance or reimbursement for travel or other expenses incurred on the business of the employer up to the amount of expenses actually incurred and accounted for by the individual to the employer.

subsection.text: “Week” means a period of 7 consecutive days, as the Secretary sets by regulation.
This section is a guide to the interpretation and application of this title.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: economic insecurity due to unemployment is a serious menace to the health, morals, and welfare of the people of the State;

involuntary unemployment is a subject of general interest and concern that requires appropriate action by the General Assembly to prevent the spread of involuntary unemployment and to lighten its burden, which often falls with crushing force on the unemployed worker and the family of the unemployed worker;
the achievement of security for society requires protection against involuntary unemployment, which is the greatest hazard of our economic lives; and

security for society can be provided by encouraging employers to provide more stable employment and by the systematic accumulation of funds during periods of employment to provide benefits for periods of unemployment, maintaining the purchasing power, and limiting the serious social consequences of poor relief assistance.

subsection.text: The General Assembly declares that, in its considered judgment, the public good and the general welfare of the citizens of the State require the enactment of this title, under the police powers of the State, for the compulsory setting aside of unemployment reserves to be used for the benefit of individuals unemployed through no fault of their own.

To the extent necessary to ensure that the United States Secretary of Labor certifies this title under § 3304 of the Internal Revenue Code and unless this title clearly indicates an intent to the contrary, this title shall be construed in a manner consistent with the relevant provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, the Federal Social Security Act, the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970, and the Federal Trade Act of 1974.

If implementation of a provision of Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article (Administrative Procedure Act - Contested Cases) affects federal funds otherwise available under this title, the Department shall advise the Governor and request appropriate action under § 10-225 of the State Government Article.

section.text: With the advice and help of the State and local advisory councils, the Secretary shall take all appropriate steps to:

paragraph.text: reduce and prevent unemployment;
encourage and assist in the adoption of practical methods of vocational training, retraining, and guidance;

advise, assist, and conduct investigations regarding the establishment and operation by a county, a municipality, or the State, of reserves for public works to be used in times of business depression and unemployment;
promote the reemployment of unemployed workers throughout the State in each other way that may be feasible; and
conduct investigations and research studies and publish the results.

section.text: Unless a report or other written or oral communication that is made or delivered in connection with this title is false and malicious, a person may not bring an action for abusive or wrongful discharge, libel, or slander based on the report or communication from:

paragraph.text: an employee to an employer;
an employer to an employee; or
an employee or an employer to the Secretary or Board of Appeals or any agent, employee, or representative of the Secretary or Board of Appeals.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section or otherwise required by law, information provided to the Secretary under § 8–1001(b)(3) of this title for purposes of determining whether a claimant left employment as a result of domestic violence shall be confidential and not subject to disclosure to any party.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may notify the employing unit in general terms that a claimant has left employment as a result of domestic violence.
The Secretary may not disclose information provided to the Secretary under § 8–1001(b)(3)(ii) of this title to the employing unit unless the employing unit can establish that:

subparagraph.text: the employing unit has a legitimate need to question the veracity of the information;
the employing unit’s need for the information outweighs the claimant’s personal privacy interest; and
the employing unit is unable to obtain the information from any other source.

paragraph.text: Before disclosing information under this section, the Secretary shall:

subparagraph.text: notify the claimant; and
redact unnecessary identifying information.

paragraph.text: An employing unit that receives information under this section may not further disseminate the information.

subsection.text: Information related to the status of a claimant or a claimant’s spouse, minor child, or parent as a victim of domestic violence is not public information subject to disclosure as part of the appeals process.
The Secretary may adopt regulations to further protect the privacy of the claimant.

paragraph.text: An agreement by an individual to commute, release, or waive a right to benefits under this title is void.
An agreement by an employee to pay all or part of the contributions that an employing unit is required to make under this title is void.
An assignment or pledge of an individual’s right to benefits under this title is void.
A right to benefits under this title is not subject to attachment, execution, levy, or any other remedy provided by law for collection of debts.
After an individual receives benefits, unless they are commingled with other money of the individual, the benefits are exempt from any remedy provided by law for collection of debts.
A waiver of any exemption under this subsection is void.

subsection.text: An individual who performs services for an employer that maintains more than 1 establishment is deemed to be employed by a single employer.

If an employer has actual or constructive knowledge that an individual is employed to perform or assist in performing the work of any agent or employee of the employer, the individual is deemed to be employed by the employer regardless of whether the individual was hired or paid directly by the employer or the agent or employee of the employer.
Employment is presumed to be covered employment if:

paragraph.text: regardless of whether the employment is based on the common law relation of master and servant, the employment is performed:

subparagraph.text: for wages; or
under a contract of hire that is written or oral or express or implied; and

paragraph.text: the employment is performed in accordance with § 8–202 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: To overcome the presumption of employment, an employing unit shall establish that the person performing services is an independent contractor in accordance with § 8–205 of this subtitle or is specifically exempted under this subtitle.
In this section, “knowingly” means having actual knowledge, deliberate ignorance, or reckless disregard for the truth.
An employer may not fail to properly classify an individual as an employee.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary determines that an employing unit has failed to properly classify an individual as an employee, any and all contribution or reimbursement payments resulting from the failure to properly classify that are due and unpaid shall accrue interest as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

An employer who fails to pay the contribution or reimbursement payments within 45 days shall be assessed interest at the rate of 2% per month or part of a month from the first due date following notice of the misclassification until the Secretary receives the contribution or payment in lieu of contributions and interest.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall consider, as strong evidence that an employer did not knowingly fail to properly classify an individual, whether the employer:

subparagraph.text: classifies all workers who perform the same or substantially the same tasks for the employer as independent contractors; and
reports the income of the workers to the Internal Revenue Service as required by federal law; and

paragraph.text: has received a determination from the Internal Revenue Service that the individual or a worker who performs the same or substantially the same tasks for the employer is an independent contractor.

subsection.text: If the Secretary determines that an employing unit has knowingly failed to properly classify an individual as an employee, the employing unit shall be subject to a civil penalty of not more than $5,000 per employee.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly advise an employing unit or a prospective employing unit to take action for the purposes of violating this section.
A person found in violation of this subsection shall be subject to a civil penalty of not more than $20,000.

subsection.text: An employing unit found to have knowingly violated this section who has also been found previously to have knowingly violated this section by a final order of a court or administrative unit may be assessed double the administrative penalties set forth in subsection (d) of this section for the new violation.

paragraph.text: An employing unit may be assessed civil penalties by only one order of a court or administrative unit for the same actions constituting a knowing failure to properly classify an individual as an employee.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, an employing unit may be ordered to make restitution, pay any interest due, and otherwise comply with all applicable laws and regulations by orders of a court, the Secretary, and all other relevant administrative units, including the Comptroller, the Workers’ Compensation Commission, the Insurance Administration, and the Division of Labor and Industry.

subsection.text: If the Secretary determines that an employing unit has failed to properly classify an individual as an employee, the Secretary shall promptly notify the Workers’ Compensation Commission, the Division of Labor and Industry, the Insurance Administration, and the Comptroller.

As authorized by State and federal law, units within the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the Department of Budget and Management, the Secretary of State, the Comptroller, the Insurance Administration, and other State agencies shall cooperate and share information concerning any suspected violation of this title.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.
The regulations shall:

subparagraph.text: require that the Secretary provide an employer with the factual basis for any violations charged;
establish procedures regarding the audit process and any agency level review available before appeal; and
provide guidance as to what constitutes the evidence relevant to the determination of whether an employer knowingly failed to properly classify an individual as an employee.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“American aircraft” means an aircraft registered under the laws of the United States.
“American employer” means:

subparagraph.text: a corporation organized under the laws of a state;
a partnership, if at least two-thirds of the partners are residents of the United States;
a resident of the United States; or
a trust, if all of the trustees are residents of the United States.

paragraph.text: “Vessel” means:

subparagraph.text: a vessel that is documented or numbered under the laws of the United States; or
a vessel that is not documented or numbered under the laws of the United States and is not documented under the laws of any foreign country whose crew performs service solely for:

sub-subparagraph.text: a citizen or resident of the United States; or
a corporation organized under the laws of a state.

subsection.text: Employment that otherwise meets the requirements of § 8-201 of this subtitle is covered employment if the employment is:

paragraph.text: performed in the State, including:

subparagraph.text: employment performed on land that the United States government holds or owns; and
employment performed in interstate commerce; or

paragraph.text: deemed to be performed in the State under an election made by an employer and approved by the Secretary under a reciprocal arrangement between the Secretary and a unit of another state or the federal government in accordance with Subtitle 7 of this title.

subsection.text: Employment that otherwise meets the requirements of § 8-201 of this subtitle and is performed partly in this State is covered employment in its entirety if:

paragraph.text: the employment that is performed outside this State is incidental to the employment that is performed in this State, including employment that is temporary or transitory or that consists of isolated transactions;
the employment that is performed in this State is not incidental to employment that is performed in any particular state but:

subparagraph.text: the base of operations is in this State; or
the place from which the employment is controlled or directed is in this State; or

paragraph.text: the employment:

subparagraph.text: is performed by an individual who is a resident of this State; and
is not performed in part in a state in which the employment is controlled or directed or in which the base of operations is located.

subsection.text: Employment that otherwise meets the requirements of § 8-201 of this subtitle is covered employment if:

paragraph.text: the employment is:

subparagraph.text: controlled or directed from this State;
performed in any state, the Virgin Islands, or Canada; and
not insured under the unemployment insurance law of any other state, the Virgin Islands, or Canada;

paragraph.text: notwithstanding § 8-210(a) of this subtitle and except as provided in § 8-210(b) of this subtitle, the employment is performed by an officer or crew member of a vessel or American aircraft on or in connection with it if:

subparagraph.text: the office from which the operations of the vessel on navigable waters or the American aircraft are conducted is within this State; or
the operation of the vessel or American aircraft within this State or both in and outside the United States ordinarily and regularly is controlled and directed from in this State; or

paragraph.text: the employment is performed by a citizen of the United States for an American employer outside of the United States, the Virgin Islands, and Canada and is not otherwise covered under this section if the American employer:

subparagraph.text: has its principal place of business in the United States located in this State;
does not have a place of business in the United States, but the American employer is:

sub-subparagraph.text: a resident of this State;
a corporation that is organized under the laws of this State; or
a partnership or a trust and a plurality of the partners or trustees are residents of this State;

subparagraph.text: has elected coverage under this title; or

has failed to elect coverage in any state and, not being covered under the unemployment insurance law in any other state, the employee has filed a claim for benefits under the law of this State based on the employment.

subsection.text: An employer may submit to the Secretary a written election that employment that otherwise is not covered under this title is covered employment if:

paragraph.text: payments are not required for the employment under an unemployment insurance law of another state or the federal government; and
the employment is performed for the employer by an individual in a distinct establishment or place of business.
The Secretary shall approve or disapprove the election in writing.
If the Secretary approves an election, the employment included in the election shall be covered employment from the date stated in the approval.

subsection.text: An election under this subsection shall be for at least 2 calendar years.

The provisions of § 8–909 of this title with respect to rights to benefits based on service for State and not for profit institutions of higher education shall apply to service that is covered employment under an election under this section.

The employment shall cease to be covered employment as of January 1 of the calendar year following the end of the 2 calendar year period during which the employment has been covered if, by January 31 of that year:

paragraph.text: the employing unit has submitted a written notice of termination to the Secretary; or
the Secretary has given notice of termination of the coverage.

subsection.text: In this section, “pay period” means a period of not more than 31 consecutive days for which a payment of wages ordinarily is made to an individual by the employer of the individual.
This section does not apply to employment that an individual performs for an employer in a pay period in which any of the employment is exempted under § 8-213(b) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If employment that an individual performs for an employer during at least one-half of a pay period is covered employment, then all of the employment during that pay period is covered employment.
If employment that an individual performs for an employer during more than one-half of a pay period is not covered employment, then none of the employment during that pay period is covered.

subsection.text: Work that an individual performs under any contract of hire is not covered employment if the Secretary is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the individual who performs the work is free from control and direction over its performance both in fact and under the contract;
the individual customarily is engaged in an independent business or occupation of the same nature as that involved in the work; and
the work is:

subparagraph.text: outside of the usual course of business of the person for whom the work is performed; or
performed outside of any place of business of the person for whom the work is performed.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations to provide:

paragraph.text: general guidance about the application of subsection (a) of this section; and
specific examples of how subsection (a) of this section is applied to certain industries, including the construction industry, the landscaping industry, and the home care services industry.

subsection.text: Work is not covered employment when performed by a licensed barber or licensed cosmetologist who leases a chair or booth from a holder of a barbershop permit, a beauty salon permit, or an owner–manager permit who operates a barbershop or beauty salon, if the Secretary is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the barber or cosmetologist as lessee and the permit holder have entered into a written lease that is in effect;
the lessee pays a stipulated amount for use of the chair or booth and is not required to make any further accounting of income to the permit holder;
the lessee has access to the premises at all hours and may set personal work hours and prices; and
the lease expressly states that the lessee knows:

subparagraph.text: of the responsibility to pay State and federal income taxes and make contributions to Social Security for self–employment; and
that the work is not covered employment.

subsection.text: Work that a direct seller performs is not covered employment if the Secretary is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the direct seller is engaged in the trade or business of selling consumer products:

subparagraph.text: in the home or at any other location outside of a permanent retail establishment; or

to a buyer on a buy–sell basis, a deposit–commission basis, or any similar basis for resale by the buyer or any other person in the home or at any other location outside of a permanent retail establishment;

paragraph.text: the direct seller and the person for whom the work is performed have entered into a written agreement that is currently in effect;
substantially all of the compensation for the employment is related directly to sales or other output, including the performance of a service, rather than to the number of hours worked; and
the written agreement states that the direct seller will not be treated as an employee for the purpose of State and federal income taxes with respect to the employment performed under the agreement.

subsection.text: Work that an individual performs is not covered employment if the Secretary is satisfied that the individual:

paragraph.text: is engaged in the trade or business of delivering or distributing newspapers or shopping news, including any services directly related to the delivery or distribution of newspapers or shopping news; and
meets the requirements for a direct seller under subsection (b)(2), (3), and (4) of this section.
In this subsection, “messenger service business” means a business that:

subparagraph.text: principally and primarily offers and provides to the public or commercial establishments expedited, time critical, and same day as requested delivery service;
does not make, produce, sell, or distribute what it delivers; and
does not have an exclusive contractual delivery arrangement with an individual or a commercial establishment.

paragraph.text: Work that a messenger service driver performs for a person who is engaged in the messenger service business is not covered employment if the Secretary is satisfied that:

subparagraph.text: the driver and the person who is engaged in the messenger service business have entered into a written agreement that is currently in effect;
the written agreement under item (i) of this paragraph does not prohibit the driver from performing for more than one person who is engaged in the messenger service business;
the driver is free to accept or reject delivery jobs from the person who is engaged in the messenger service business;
the driver personally provides the vehicle;
compensation is by commission only;
the driver may set personal work hours; and
the written agreement states expressly and prominently that the driver knows:

sub-subparagraph.text: of the responsibility to pay estimated Social Security taxes and State and federal income taxes;
that the Social Security tax the driver must pay is higher than the Social Security tax the driver would pay otherwise; and
that the work is not covered employment.

paragraph.text: A messenger service driver for a messenger service business whose work is not covered employment under paragraph (2) of this subsection may deliver to the public or commercial establishments on foot, by bicycle, or by motor vehicle:

subparagraph.text: individually addressed mail, messages, and documents in paper or magnetic format; and

emergency medical supplies, records, parcels, or similar items if the messenger service business provides to the Secretary evidence of a worker status determination from the Internal Revenue Service or other evidence that the messenger service driver is excluded from coverage under the Federal Unemployment Tax Act.

subsection.text: Work is not covered employment when performed by a taxicab driver who uses a taxicab or taxicab equipment of a taxicab business that is carried on by the holder of a taxicab permit if the Secretary is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the driver and permit holder have entered into a written agreement that is currently in effect for the use of the taxicab or taxicab equipment;
the driver pays a stipulated amount for the use of the taxicab or taxicab equipment and is not required to make any further accounting to the permit holder;
the driver has access to the taxicab or taxicab equipment at all hours and, subject to the Public Utilities Article, may set personal work hours and places; and
the agreement states expressly that the driver knows:

subparagraph.text: of the responsibility to pay State and federal income taxes; and
that the work is not covered employment.
This subsection applies to an individual who is an owner operator of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a Class F (tractor) vehicle, described in § 13–923 of the Transportation Article; or

except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a Class E (truck) vehicle, as described in § 13–916 of the Transportation Article, including a Class E (truck) vehicle described in § 13–919 of the Transportation Article.

subparagraph.text: This subsection does not apply to an individual who is an owner operator of a vehicle registered as a Class T (tow truck) vehicle under § 13–920 of the Transportation Article.

paragraph.text: Work is not covered employment when performed by an owner operator if the Secretary is satisfied that:

subparagraph.text: the owner operator and a motor carrier have entered into a written agreement that is currently in effect for permanent or trip leasing;
under the agreement:

sub-subparagraph.text: there is no intent to create an employer–employee relationship; and
the owner operator is paid rental compensation;

subparagraph.text: for federal tax purposes, the owner operator qualifies as an independent contractor; and
the owner operator:

sub-subparagraph.text: owns the vehicle or holds it under a bona fide lease arrangement;
is responsible for the maintenance of the vehicle;
bears the principal burden of the operating costs of the vehicle, including fuel, repairs, supplies, vehicle insurance, and personal expenses while the vehicle is on the road;
is responsible for supplying the necessary personnel in connection with the operation of the vehicle; and

generally determines the details and means of performing the services under the agreement, in conformance with regulatory requirements, operating procedures of the motor carrier, and specifications of the shipper.

subsection.text: Work is not covered employment when performed by a home worker if the Secretary is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the work is performed according to specifications furnished by the person for whom the services are performed;
the work is performed on textiles furnished by the person for whom the services are performed; and
the textiles must be returned to the person for whom the services are performed or that person’s designee.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Officiating services” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: overseeing the play of a sports event;
judging whether the rules of the event are being followed; and
penalizing participants for fouls or infringements of the rules.

“Recreational sports official” means an umpire, a referee, or a judge who contracts with a governmental or nongovernmental entity to perform officiating services at amateur sports events sponsored by:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a unit of county government;
a unit of a municipal corporation; or
an entity associated with a county government or a municipal corporation.

sub-subparagraph.text: “Recreational sports official” does not include any individual who performs officiating services in covered employment under § 8–208(a) or § 8–212(c) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Work that consists of officiating services performed by a recreational sports official is not covered employment.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agricultural work” includes employment for a wage that is performed:

subparagraph.text: on a farm in connection with:

sub-subparagraph.text: cultivating the soil; or
raising or harvesting any agricultural or horticultural commodity, including caring for, feeding, managing, raising, shearing, or training livestock, poultry, bees, furbearing animals, or wildlife;

subparagraph.text: for the owner, tenant, or other operator of a farm in connection with:

sub-subparagraph.text: conserving, improving, maintaining, managing, or operating the farm or its equipment or tools; or
salvaging timber or clearing land of brush and other debris left by a hurricane if the majority of the employment is performed on a farm;

subparagraph.text: in connection with:

sub-subparagraph.text: producing or harvesting an agricultural commodity as defined in § 15(g) of the Agricultural Marketing Act;
ginning cotton; or
operating or maintaining canals, ditches, reservoirs, or waterways that are not owned or operated for profit and are used exclusively for supplying and storing water for farming purposes;

subparagraph.text: for a farmer, group of farm operators, or cooperative in which farmers are members in drying, freezing, grading, handling, packing, planting, processing, storing or delivering to storage, market, or a carrier for transportation to market any agricultural or horticultural commodity if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the commodity is in its unmanufactured state;
the farmer, group, or cooperative produced more than one-half of the commodity with respect to which the employment is performed; and

the employment is not performed in connection with commercial canning or commercial freezing or in connection with an agricultural or horticultural commodity after its delivery to a terminal market for distribution or consumption; and

subparagraph.text: on a farm operated for profit if the employment is not in the course of the trade or business of the employer.

paragraph.text: “Farm” includes:

subparagraph.text: a dairy farm;
a fruit farm;
a furbearing animal farm;
a greenhouse or similar structure used primarily for raising agricultural or horticultural commodities;
a nursery;
an orchard;
a plantation;
a poultry farm;
a ranch;
a range;
a stock farm; and
a truck farm.

paragraph.text: “Crew leader” means an individual who:

subparagraph.text: provides individuals to perform agricultural work for any person;
on behalf of the crew leader or person for whom the agricultural work is performed, pays the individuals for their agricultural work; and

has not entered into a written agreement with the person for whom the agricultural work is performed under which the individuals who perform the agricultural work are designated as employees of that person.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, agricultural work, including agricultural work performed by an alien admitted to the United States to perform agricultural work under §§ 101(a)(15)(h) and 214(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, is not covered employment.
Agricultural work is covered employment if performed for a person who:

paragraph.text: during a calendar quarter of the current or preceding calendar year, pays cash wages of at least $20,000 to individuals who perform agricultural work; or

for a part of a day in each of 20 consecutive or nonconsecutive weeks during the current or preceding calendar year, employs at least 10 individuals in agricultural work, regardless of whether the individuals are employed at the same moment.
The crew leader is the employing unit for an individual employed in agricultural work who is not an employee of another employing unit if:

subparagraph.text: the crew leader holds a valid certificate of registration under the federal Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act;
substantially all of the individuals maintain or operate tractors, mechanized harvesting or cropdusting equipment, or any other mechanized equipment that the crew leader provides; or
the individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: performs custom poultry work, including harvesting, breeding, debeaking, sexing, and health services; and
is not required to be away from the individual’s permanent place of residence other than during normal working hours.

paragraph.text: If the crew leader is not the employing unit for an individual employed in agricultural work under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the person to whom the crew leader provides the individual is the employing unit of the individual.

subsection.text: If under subsection (d)(2) of this section the crew leader is not the employing unit for an individual employed in agricultural work, any cash wages that the crew leader pays to the individual shall be considered cash wages paid by the person who is the employing unit for the individual and to whom the crew leader provides the individual.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, employment is covered employment if the employment is:

paragraph.text: performed for a charitable, educational, religious, or other organization; and
excluded from the definition of “employment” in the Federal Unemployment Tax Act solely by § 3306(c)(8) of the Act.

subsection.text: Employment is not covered employment if the employment is performed for:

paragraph.text: a church or an association or convention of churches; or
an organization that is:

subparagraph.text: operated primarily for religious purposes; and
controlled, operated, principally supported, or supervised by a church or an association or convention of churches.

subsection.text: Employment is not covered employment if the employment is performed by:

paragraph.text: a commissioned, licensed, or ordained minister of a church in the exercise of the ministry; or
a member of a religious order in the exercise of duties required by the order.

subsection.text: During any calendar quarter in which the compensation is less than $50, the employment is not covered employment if it is performed for an organization that is exempt from income tax under:

paragraph.text: § 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code unless the organization is described in § 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code; or
§ 521 of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: Work that an insurance producer performs for payment solely by commission is not covered employment.

To the extent that work is exempted under federal law, the work that an associate real estate broker or real estate salesperson performs for a licensed real estate broker for payment by commission is not covered employment.
Work that a yacht salesperson performs for a licensed trader for payment solely by commission is not covered employment.

Except as provided in § 8-202(d)(2) of this subtitle, employment performed by a crew member or officer of a vessel on the navigable waters of the United States is not covered employment if the vessel has a capacity of 10 net tons or less.
Employment is not covered employment if:

paragraph.text: performed by a crew member or officer of:

subparagraph.text: a vessel with a capacity of 10 net tons or less; or
a fishing boat that has a crew that normally consists of fewer than 10 individuals;

paragraph.text: the crew member or officer is engaged in the farming or taking of any aquatic life; and
the crew member or officer is paid on a share basis and not by a salary.

section.text: Domestic employment in a private home, local college club, or local chapter of a college fraternity or sorority is not covered employment unless during any calendar quarter of the current or preceding calendar year, the employer pays cash wages of at least $1,000 to individuals performing the employment.

subsection.text: Employment is not covered employment if the employment is performed for the United States government or except to the extent that Congress permits to be covered, the employment is performed for an instrumentality of the United States that is exempt under the United States Constitution from contributions.

paragraph.text: Employment performed for a foreign government, including employment as a consular or other officer or employee or nondiplomatic representative, is not covered employment.
Employment performed for an instrumentality that a foreign government wholly owns is not covered employment if:

subparagraph.text: the employment is of a character similar to that performed in the foreign country by employees of the United States government or an instrumentality of the United States government; and

the Secretary finds that the United States Secretary of State has certified to the United States Secretary of the Treasury that the foreign government whose instrumentality claims exemption from the tax imposed by this title grants an equivalent exemption for similar employment performed in the foreign country by employees of the United States government and instrumentalities of the United States government.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in this subtitle, employment performed for a governmental entity of a state is covered employment if the employment is excluded from the definition of “employment” in the Federal Unemployment Tax Act solely by § 3306(c)(7) of the Act.
Employment performed for a governmental entity is not covered employment if performed:

subparagraph.text: as an elected official;
as a member of a legislative body, a judicial body, the State National Guard, or the Air National Guard;
as a temporary employee in case of an earthquake, flood, fire, snow, storm or similar emergency;
in a position that, under the laws of the State, is designated a major nontenured advisory or policymaking position;
in an advisory or policymaking position that ordinarily requires 8 hours or less of work each week; or

as an election official or election worker if the amount of remuneration received by the individual during the calendar year for services as an election official or election worker is less than $1,000.

paragraph.text: Employment is not covered employment if performed:

subparagraph.text: for an employer that is determined to be subject to the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act by a unit authorized by federal law to make that determination; or
as an employee representative who is determined to be subject to the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act by the unit.

paragraph.text: If the Railroad Retirement Board determines that a person is engaged principally in a business other than the carrier business, the exclusion from insurance under paragraph (1) of this subsection applies only to employment for the identifiable and separable enterprise of the person that the Secretary determines to be considered the employer.

subsection.text: Employment is not covered employment if performed for an employer that is determined by a unit of the federal government authorized to make the determination to be subject to any other unemployment insurance system established by federal law.

section.text: Employment that an individual performs that is not in the course of the business or trade of the individual’s employer is not covered employment unless:

paragraph.text: during a calendar quarter, the employer pays cash compensation of at least $50 for the employment; and

the employment is performed by an individual whom the employer regularly employs to perform the employment during a part of each of at least 24 days during the calendar quarter or the preceding calendar quarter.

section.text: Employment is not covered employment if performed:

paragraph.text: for a child or spouse; or
for a parent, by a child under the age of 21 years.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, employment is not covered employment if performed:

paragraph.text: in a facility that:

subparagraph.text: carries out a program of rehabilitation for individuals whose earning capacity is impaired by age, physical or mental disability, or injury; or
provides compensated work for individuals who, because of their physical or mental disability, cannot be employed readily in the competitive labor market; and

paragraph.text: by an individual who receives that rehabilitation or compensated work.

subsection.text: Employment is covered employment if performed by a blind or other severely handicapped employee of Blind Industries and Services of Maryland.
Employment that an inmate of a custodial or penal institution performs for a not-for-profit organization or a governmental entity is not covered employment.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, employment that an inmate of a custodial or penal institution performs for a private, for-profit employer is not covered employment.

Employment that an inmate of a custodial or penal institution performs for a private, for-profit employer is covered employment if the inmate continues to be employed by the private, for-profit employing unit after being permanently released from the custodial or penal institution, including released by parole.

subsection.text: Employment that an intern performs is not covered employment if:

paragraph.text: the employer is a hospital; and
the intern has completed a 4-year course in a medical school that is chartered or approved under State law.

subsection.text: Employment that a patient of a hospital performs for the hospital is not covered employment.
Employment that a student nurse performs is not covered employment if:

paragraph.text: the employer is a hospital or training school for nurses; and
the student nurse is enrolled in and regularly attending classes in a training school for nurses that is chartered or approved under State law.

section.text: Employment that a minor performs in the delivery or distribution of newspapers or shopping news is not covered employment unless delivery or distribution is to a point for subsequent delivery or distribution.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “full-time student” means an individual who is:

subparagraph.text: enrolled full-time at an educational institution; or
between academic terms or years if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual was enrolled as a full-time student at an educational institution for the immediately preceding academic term or year; and
there is a reasonable assurance that the individual will be enrolled as a full-time student at an educational institution for the immediately succeeding academic term or year.

paragraph.text: Employment that a full-time student performs in the employ of an organized camp is not covered employment if:

subparagraph.text: the full-time student was employed by the camp for less than 13 calendar weeks in a calendar year; and
the camp:

sub-subparagraph.text: had average gross receipts for any 6 months in the preceding calendar year that were not more than one-third of its average gross receipts for the other 6 months in that year; or
did not operate for more than 7 months in each of the current and preceding calendar years.

subsection.text: Employment performed in an educational institution is not covered employment if:

paragraph.text: the employment is performed by a student who is enrolled and regularly attending classes at that educational institution; or
the employment is performed by the spouse of the student and immediately before beginning to perform the employment, the spouse is advised that:

subparagraph.text: the employment is under a program of the educational institution to provide financial assistance to the student; and
the employment is not covered employment.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, employment is not covered employment if:

subparagraph.text: the individual who performs the employment is enrolled for credit at a not-for-profit or public educational institution that normally has a regular faculty and curriculum and a regularly organized body of students in attendance at the place where its educational activities are carried on;
the employment is an integral part of a full-time program taken for credit at the educational institution that combines academic instruction with work experience; and
the educational institution has certified to the employer the application of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: employment that an individual performs as part of a program that an educational institution establishes for or on behalf of an employer is covered employment.

section.text: Employment is not covered employment if performed:

paragraph.text: as part of an unemployment work relief or work training program assisted or financed wholly or partly by a unit of the federal government or a political subdivision or unit of a state; and
by an individual who receives the work relief or work training.

section.text: Except employment for not-for-profit organizations and governmental entities, employment is not covered employment if performed by a volunteer test subject who is paid on a per study basis for scientific, medical, or drug-related research.

Employment is not covered employment if performed by an individual who is a nonimmigrant alien admitted to the United States under § 1101(a)(15)(f), (j), (m), or (q) of the federal Immigration and Nationality Act.

This title shall be administered under the supervision of the Secretary by 2 coordinate units, the Division of Unemployment Insurance and the Division of Workforce Development, established by the Secretary.

subsection.text: There is a Division of Unemployment Insurance.
The Division of Unemployment Insurance shall perform any function that the Secretary assigns to it to carry out this title.

paragraph.text: “Public employment office” means an employment office that does not charge a fee to provide services and is:

subparagraph.text: operated by the Department; or
maintained as part of a local, State, or federal system of employment offices.

paragraph.text: “Public employment office” includes a branch public employment office.

subsection.text: The General Assembly accepts the provisions of the Wagner–Peyser Act for establishment of a national employment system and for cooperation in promotion of the system in conformity with § 4 of the Act.
The Division of Workforce Development, established under § 11–102 of this article, is the unit of the State designated to carry out § 4 of the Wagner–Peyser Act.
The Secretary shall employ a staff for the Division of Workforce Development in accordance with § 8–304 of this subtitle and regulations adopted by the United States Secretary of Labor.

As necessary for administration of this title, the Division of Workforce Development shall establish and maintain public employment offices that do not charge a fee to individuals who seek employment.
To establish and maintain public employment offices, the Secretary:

paragraph.text: may enter into an agreement with the Railroad Retirement Board or any other federal unit that is responsible for administration of an unemployment insurance law, a political subdivision of the State, or any private not–for–profit organization; and
as part of the agreement, may accept money, services, or office space as a contribution to the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund.

subsection.text: Money in the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund that the State receives under the Wagner–Peyser Act is available to the Division of Workforce Development for use under this section in accordance with that Act.

section.text: The Secretary may delegate to an employee of the Department any power or duty that is reasonable and proper for the administration of this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary may adopt any regulation that is necessary to carry out this title.

paragraph.text: In accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article, the Secretary may employ the staff necessary to carry out this title.
In accordance with the State budget, the Secretary shall set the compensation of staff employed under this subsection.
Subject to other applicable provisions of this title, the Secretary may appoint employees and set their powers and duties as necessary to carry out this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall determine whether an employee who handles money for the Department under this title should be covered under a bond.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall print:

subparagraph.text: this title;
each annual report that the Secretary submits to the Governor; and
any other material that the Secretary considers relevant and suitable.

paragraph.text: On request by any person, the Secretary shall give the person a copy of:

subparagraph.text: any material that the Secretary prints under this subsection; and
the current regulations adopted to carry out this title.

subsection.text: To enforce this title, the Secretary may conduct investigations.
To enforce this title, the Secretary may:

paragraph.text: administer an oath;
certify to an official act; and
take a deposition.
To enforce this title, the Secretary may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of books, correspondence, memoranda, papers, or other records.
A subpoena issued under this subsection shall be served in any manner in which a subpoena of a court may be served.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on a complaint filed by the Secretary, the circuit court for the county where the investigation is being conducted or where the person resides, is present, or transacts business may pass an order directing compliance with the subpoena or compelling testimony.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person may not be excused from complying with a subpoena issued under subsection (c) of this section on the ground that the evidence or testimony required may tend to incriminate the person or subject the person to a forfeiture or penalty.

After claiming the privilege against self-incrimination a person may not be prosecuted or subjected to any forfeiture or penalty because of any matter, thing, or transaction about which the person is compelled to produce evidence or testify except that if the person commits perjury while giving testimony, the person is subject to prosecution for that offense.

subsection.text: In a civil action to enforce this title, the Secretary or Board of Appeals and the State may be represented by:

paragraph.text: the Attorney General; or
any qualified attorney who:

subparagraph.text: is a salaried employee of the Secretary or Board of Appeals; and
on recommendation of the Attorney General, is designated to represent the Secretary or Board of Appeals and the State.

subsection.text: A criminal action for violation of any provision of this title or regulation adopted under this title shall be prosecuted by the State’s Attorney of the county in which:

paragraph.text: the employer has a place of business;
the violator resides; or
the violator has filed for benefits to which the violator was not entitled.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a State Advisory Council.
The State Advisory Council shall consist of:

paragraph.text: an equal number of members who represent employees and who represent employers; and
the number of members who represent the general public that the Secretary sets.

subsection.text: Each member of the State Advisory Council who represents employees or who represents employers shall be an individual who is regarded as a representative of employees or employers because of affiliation, employment, or vocation.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the State Advisory Council is 4 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: Each member of the State Advisory Council is entitled to:

paragraph.text: $50 for each day that the Council is in session, not exceeding $1,500 per year; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The State Advisory Council shall help the Secretary to:

paragraph.text: develop policies and discuss problems related to the administration of this title; and
ensure impartiality and freedom from political influence in the solution of those problems.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall appoint local advisory councils.
Each local advisory council shall consist of:

paragraph.text: an equal number of members who represent employees and who represent employers; and
the number of members who represent the general public that the Secretary sets.

subsection.text: Each member of a local advisory council who represents employees or who represents employers shall be regarded as a representative of employees or employers because of affiliation, employment, or vocation.
A member of a local advisory council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for necessary expenses.

subsection.text: The local advisory councils shall help the Secretary to:

paragraph.text: develop policies and discuss problems related to the administration of this title; and
ensure impartiality and freedom from political influence in the solution of those problems.
In the administration of this title, the Secretary shall cooperate with the United States Secretary of Labor to the fullest extent that this title allows.
The Secretary shall:

subparagraph.text: make each report in the form and containing the information that the Secretary of Labor requires;
comply with each provision that the Secretary of Labor considers necessary to ensure the accuracy of a report; and

comply with each regulation that the Secretary of Labor adopts to govern the expenditure of any money that may be allotted and paid to the State under Chapter 7, Subchapter III of the Social Security Act to assist in the administration of this title.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may afford reasonable cooperation with each federal unit that administers an unemployment insurance law.
On request, the Secretary shall provide to a federal unit that administers public works or assistance through public employment:

subparagraph.text: the name, address, usual occupation, and employment status of each recipient of benefits; and
information about the right of the individual to receive benefits.

subsection.text: The Secretary:

paragraph.text: may make available to the Railroad Retirement Board any record of the State that relates to administration of this title; and
at the expense of the Railroad Retirement Board, may provide to the Board a copy of any record that the Board considers necessary for its purposes.

subsection.text: On or before January 1 of each year, the Secretary shall submit to the Governor an annual report on the administration and operation of this title during the previous fiscal year.
The annual report shall include:

paragraph.text: a balance sheet for the Unemployment Insurance Fund;
a table that shows the amount of any benefit that was ineffectively charged or not charged to the experience rating record of an employer;
the reason for not charging the amount of any benefit to the experience rating record of an employer;
by category of disqualification, the amount of any benefit that was paid after a disqualification under Subtitle 10 of this title; and
any recommendation for an amendment to this title that the Secretary considers proper.

The balance sheet for the Unemployment Insurance Fund that the Secretary includes in the annual report shall include, if possible, a reserve against liability in future years to pay benefits in excess of the then current contributions.

A reserve under this subsection shall be set up by the Secretary in accordance with accepted actuarial principles on the basis of statistics of employment, business activity, and other relevant factors for the longest possible period.

subsection.text: Whenever the Secretary believes that a change in rates of contributions or benefits will become necessary to protect the solvency to the Unemployment Insurance Fund, the Secretary promptly shall inform the Governor and legislature and make recommendations with respect to the change.

section.text: There is an Unemployment Insurance Fund.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall administer the Unemployment Insurance Fund.
The Unemployment Insurance Fund shall be a special fund that is separate from State money.
The Unemployment Insurance Fund shall consist of:

paragraph.text: contributions;
reimbursement payments collected under Subtitle 6, Part III of this title;
interest earned on money in the Fund;
property or securities acquired with money that belongs to the Fund;
money earned from the property or securities;
money received from the Federal Unemployment Account in the Unemployment Trust Fund in accordance with Title XII of the Social Security Act;
money credited to the State Unemployment Trust Fund Account under § 903 of the Social Security Act; and
money received for the Fund from any other source.

subsection.text: Money in the Unemployment Insurance Fund shall be commingled.
The Unemployment Insurance Fund shall be used only for the purposes of this title.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer is custodian of the Unemployment Insurance Fund.
The State Treasurer shall manage the Unemployment Insurance Fund in accordance with regulations that the Secretary adopts.
In the Unemployment Insurance Fund, the State Treasurer shall maintain as separate accounts:

subparagraph.text: a clearing account;
an Unemployment Trust Fund Account; and
a benefit account.

paragraph.text: Under the direction of the Secretary, the Treasurer shall establish the benefit and clearing accounts in any financial institution in which the General Fund of the State may be deposited.

The Unemployment Trust Fund Account shall be the account of the State in the Federal Unemployment Trust Fund that is established and maintained in accordance with § 904 of the Social Security Act notwithstanding any State law to the contrary that relates to administration, deposit, disbursement, or release of money in the custody of the State.
On receipt of any money payable to the Unemployment Insurance Fund, the Secretary shall ensure immediate deposit of the money in the clearing account as required by the State Treasurer.
All money deposited in the clearing account for the payment of fines, interest, or penalties shall be paid to the Special Administrative Expense Fund.
Subject to the direction of the Secretary, the State Treasurer may pay refunds under Subtitle 6, Part V of this title from the clearing account.

Immediately after payments that are made under subsection (c)(2) and (3) of this section have cleared, the State Treasurer shall deposit all money that remains in the clearing account with the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States to the credit of the account of the State in the Unemployment Trust Fund that is established and maintained under § 904 of the Social Security Act.
Money that is requisitioned from the account of the State in the Unemployment Trust Fund shall be placed in the benefit account only for use in accordance with paragraph (3) of this subsection.
Subject to § 8-405 of this subtitle and in accordance with regulations that the Secretary adopts, money in the benefit account:

subparagraph.text: may be used to pay refunds under Subtitle 6, Part V of this title;
shall be used to pay benefits; and
may be used to pay administrative expenses incurred to carry out this title.

subsection.text: The Unemployment Insurance Fund may not be used to pay a deposit insurance premium in a financial institution in which the benefit and clearing accounts are deposited.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall requisition money that is credited to the account of the State in the Unemployment Trust Fund as the Secretary considers necessary for payment of benefits and refunds under this title for a reasonable period in the future.
The amount requisitioned under paragraph (1) of this subsection may not exceed the amount of money in the account.

Laws that require an appropriation or other formal release of money in the custody of State officers do not apply when money that was requisitioned under this subsection is used to pay a benefit or refund from the benefit account or a refund from the clearing account.
After expiration of the period for which a requisition is made under paragraph (1) of this subsection, if money remains unpaid or unclaimed in the benefit account the Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: deduct the amount of the money from estimates for a future requisition under paragraph (1) of this subsection; or
redeposit the money in the account of the State in the Unemployment Trust Fund as provided under § 8-404(d) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If the General Assembly first enacts an appropriation in accordance with paragraph (4) of this subsection, the Secretary may requisition money that is credited under § 903 of the Social Security Act to the account of the State in the Unemployment Trust Fund to pay expenses of administration of this title that will be incurred after enactment of the appropriation.
Money that is appropriated under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall be requisitioned as needed for payment of obligations incurred under the appropriation and shall be deposited in the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund for use of that Fund;
until used, shall remain part of the Unemployment Insurance Fund; and
if not used, promptly shall be returned to the account of the State in the Unemployment Trust Fund.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall keep a separate record of the deposit, obligation, use, and return of money appropriated under this subsection.
An appropriation that is enacted under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: specify the purpose and amount of the appropriation;
limit the period in which the appropriation is obligated to no more than 2 years after its enactment; and

limit the amount of money that may be obligated during a 12-month period beginning on July 1 and ending on the next June 30 to an amount not exceeding the amount by which the total of the money credited to the account of the State in the Unemployment Trust Fund during that and the 34 preceding 12-month periods exceeds the total of the money obligated for payment of administrative expenses and paid for benefits during the same 35 12-month periods.

paragraph.text: An amount that is credited to the State Unemployment Trust Fund Account under § 903 of the Social Security Act and that is obligated for administration or paid out for benefits shall be charged against an equivalent amount that first is credited and that is not already charged.
An amount obligated for administration during a 12-month period may not be charged against an amount that was credited before the 34th 12-month period before that period.

section.text: A check that the State Treasurer issues to pay benefits or refunds shall:

paragraph.text: be issued only on a warrant signed by the Secretary;
bear the signature of the State Treasurer; and
be countersigned by an authorized agent.

subsection.text: In accordance with and to obtain the advantages under Title XII of the Social Security Act the Secretary:

paragraph.text: may apply for an advance to the Unemployment Insurance Fund; and
has responsibility for repayment of the advance.

subsection.text: Interest required to be paid on an advance under subsection (a) of this section:

paragraph.text: shall be paid in a timely manner; and
may not be paid directly or indirectly from contributions or from the Unemployment Insurance Fund.

subsection.text: The provisions of this Part I of this subtitle that relate to the Unemployment Trust Fund shall be effective only while:

paragraph.text: the Unemployment Trust Fund continues to exist; and
the United States Secretary of the Treasury:

subparagraph.text: keeps in the Unemployment Trust Fund a separate account for the State from which no other state is allowed to make withdrawals; and
credits to that Account the State’s share of earnings of the Unemployment Trust Fund.

subsection.text: If the Unemployment Trust Fund ceases to exist or the State Unemployment Trust Fund Account no longer is kept, money, property, and securities that belong to the Unemployment Trust Fund of the State shall be transferred to the State Treasury and deposited in the Unemployment Insurance Fund.
If money is deposited in the Unemployment Insurance Fund under subsection (b) of this section the State Treasurer:

paragraph.text: shall hold, invest, transfer, sell, deposit, and release money in the Unemployment Insurance Fund in a manner that is approved by the Secretary and is in accordance with this title;
shall invest the money in readily marketable bonds or other readily marketable interest bearing obligations of:

subparagraph.text: the United States;
the State; or
a political subdivision of the State;

paragraph.text: shall make investments that are readily convertible into cash when cash is needed to pay benefits; and
may dispose of securities or other property bought with money that belongs to the Unemployment Insurance Fund only under the direction of the Secretary.

section.text: This title does not grant an employer or employee any prior claim or right to money the employer pays into the Unemployment Insurance Fund.
There is an Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund in the State Treasury.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall administer the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund.
The State Treasurer shall keep the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund as a nonlapsing fund separate from other State money.
The Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund shall consist of:

paragraph.text: money received from a unit of the federal government or of another state to pay for a facility or service provided to the unit;

money received under an insurance policy or surety bond or from any other source for loss that the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund sustains or for damage to equipment or supplies bought with money from the Fund;
money transferred from the Special Administrative Expense Fund under § 8-422(d) of this subtitle;
proceeds from the disposal of surplus equipment or supplies that were bought with money from the Fund; and
money received under the Wagner-Peyser Act for use in accordance with that Act and money for administration of this title that:

subparagraph.text: is appropriated by the General Assembly;
subject to § 8-405 of this subtitle, is received from a unit of the federal government; or
is received from any other source.

paragraph.text: Subject to § 8-405 of this subtitle and paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Secretary shall use the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund to pay the administrative costs of this title including the costs of:

subparagraph.text: office space in accordance with § 8-421(c) of this subtitle; and
the surety bond of the State Treasurer under § 5-102.1 of the State Government Article for the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund.

paragraph.text: Money in the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund received from a unit of the federal government or appropriated by the General Assembly to carry out this title may be used only for the purposes and in the amounts that the United States Secretary of Labor finds necessary to administer this title efficiently and properly.

subsection.text: The State Treasurer is custodian of the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund.

paragraph.text: Subject to § 8-405(b) of this subtitle, money shall be deposited, administered, and disbursed from the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund in the same manner as money is deposited and disbursed for other special funds in the custody of the State Treasurer.
Money in the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund shall be secured in accordance with § 6-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: Money in the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund shall be available to the Secretary whenever it is needed for payment of expenses under this title.
The Secretary may transfer money to the Special Administrative Expense Fund in accordance with § 8-422(e) of this subtitle.

If the United States Secretary of Labor finds that money in the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund received under Title III of the Social Security Act or the Wagner-Peyser Act has been lost or spent for purposes other than or in amounts exceeding those found necessary by the United States Secretary of Labor for the proper administration of this title, it is the policy of the State to replace the money with money that is appropriated from the General Fund of the State in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: On receipt of notice that the United States Secretary of Labor has found that money from the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund was misused, the Secretary promptly shall give the Governor notice of the money required for replacement.
At the earliest opportunity, the Governor shall submit to the General Assembly a request for appropriation of the money required.

subsection.text: If money in the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund is used for payment of costs of administration that are found not to be properly chargeable against federal money credited to the Fund, the Secretary shall use money in the Special Administrative Expense Fund to pay for those costs.

section.text: There is a Special Administrative Expense Fund in the State Treasury.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall administer the Special Administrative Expense Fund.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall keep the Special Administrative Expense Fund as a nonlapsing fund.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, money in the Special Administrative Expense Fund may not be transferred to any other fund.

subsection.text: The Special Administrative Expense Fund shall consist of money appropriated in the State budget from:

paragraph.text: fines, interest, and other penalties collected under this title and paid from the clearing account under § 8–404(c) of this subtitle;
money transferred from the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund under § 8–422 of this subtitle; and
any voluntary contribution to the Special Administrative Expense Fund.

Notwithstanding any other provision in this Part III of this subtitle, the Special Administrative Expense Fund may be used as a revolving account to cover costs that are proper under the law for which federal money is requested but not yet received, if the costs are charged against the federal money when received.
Subject to subsection (d) of this section, the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: shall use the Special Administrative Expense Fund for reimbursement of interest on contributions that is collected erroneously;

shall use the Special Administrative Expense Fund to pay for costs of administration that are found to have been improperly charged against federal money credited to the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund; and
may use the Special Administrative Expense Fund:

sub-subparagraph.text: for replacement within a reasonable time of any money that the State receives under § 302 of the Social Security Act and that because of an action or contingency has been lost or has been used for purposes other than or in amounts exceeding those necessary for proper administration of this title; or
for administrative expenses of the Division of Unemployment Insurance and Division of Workforce Development, in accordance with subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (d) of this section, the Secretary may use the Special Administrative Expense Fund for administrative expenses necessary to administer this title.
Administrative expenses include:

subparagraph.text: expenses related to the acquisition of office space required for effective administration of this title, subject to approval by the Board of Public Works;
costs for furnishing, maintenance, repair, improvement, and enhancement of office space;
the purchase, leasing, and maintenance of information technology systems, including equipment, programs, and services;
the purchase, leasing, and maintenance of telecommunications systems, services, and equipment including connectivity costs and ongoing usage costs; and
other administrative costs that the Secretary determines are necessary to administer solely the provisions of this title.

subsection.text: The Special Administrative Expense Fund may not be used in a manner that would result in a loss of federal money that, in the absence of money from the Special Administrative Expense Fund, would be available to pay for administrative costs of this title.
The State Treasurer is custodian of the Special Administrative Expense Fund.
Money in the Special Administrative Expense Fund shall be spent in accordance with appropriations in the State budget.
Money in the Special Administrative Expense Fund shall be available to the Secretary whenever it is needed for use in accordance with this subtitle.

When money is needed for reimbursement of interest and payment of administrative costs under § 8-421(b)(2)(i) and (ii) of this subtitle, the Secretary may make the reimbursement or payment from money that:

paragraph.text: is in the Special Administrative Expense Fund; or
the State Treasurer transfers for that purpose from the Special Administrative Expense Fund to the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund.

subsection.text: When the Secretary acquires, repairs, or maintains office space with money from the Special Administrative Expense Fund that will be reimbursed from federal funds, until the reimbursement, the Secretary may transfer from the Unemployment Insurance Administration Fund to the Special Administrative Expense Fund money in an amount that:

paragraph.text: does not exceed the amount of federal funds specifically made available to the Secretary; and
equals the fair reasonable rental value of:

subparagraph.text: land or buildings that the Secretary acquires to use to carry out this title; or
the proportionate amount of space that the Secretary uses in a building constructed by the State for another unit.

subsection.text: On July 1 of each year, the Secretary shall direct the State Treasurer to transfer to the General Fund of the State the balance in the Special Administrative Expense Fund that:

paragraph.text: the Secretary has not allocated or encumbered; and
exceeds $250,000.

Beginning December 31, 2007, and each year thereafter, the Secretary shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee, the Senate Finance Committee, the House Appropriations Committee, and the House Economic Matters Committee.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: the financial status of the Special Administrative Expense Fund and a summary of its activity for the preceding fiscal year; and
a description of all projects receiving moneys from the Special Administrative Expense Fund in the preceding fiscal year.

section.text: There is a Lower Appeals Division in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall appoint a chief hearing examiner as head of the Lower Appeals Division.
The chief hearing examiner shall be in the professional service in accordance with § 6–402 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

Subject to the approval of the Secretary, the chief hearing examiner shall appoint the number of hearing examiners and other personnel needed for the effective performance of the Lower Appeals Division.
The Secretary shall have administrative authority over all personnel.

section.text: The Lower Appeals Division shall hear and decide appeals from the determinations of the claims examiners.

The Secretary, with the advice of the chief hearing examiner, shall adopt regulations, in accordance with § 10–206 of the State Government Article, to govern appeals and hearings before the hearing examiners.

subsection.text: To enforce this subtitle, a hearing examiner may:

paragraph.text: administer an oath;
certify to an official act; and
take a deposition.
To enforce this subtitle, a hearing examiner may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or for the production of books, correspondence, memoranda, papers, and other records.
A subpoena issued under this subsection shall be served in any manner in which court subpoenas are authorized to be served.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on a complaint filed by the chief hearing examiner or an authorized representative of the chief hearing examiner, the circuit court for the county where the investigation or hearing is conducted or the person is present, resides, or transacts business may pass an order directing compliance with the subpoena or compelling testimony.

subparagraph.text: A person may not be excused from attending a proceeding and testifying or producing books, correspondence, memoranda, papers, and other records before a hearing examiner in obedience to a subpoena issued under this section on the ground that the testimony or evidence required of the person may tend to incriminate the person or subject the person to a penalty or forfeiture.

After having claimed the privilege of the person against self–incrimination, a person may not be prosecuted or subjected to any penalty or forfeiture because of any transaction, matter, or thing about which the person is compelled to testify or produce evidence.
A person may be prosecuted and punished for perjury committed in testifying.

paragraph.text: A hearing examiner shall conduct a hearing or appeal in a manner that ascertains the substantial rights of the parties.

subparagraph.text: A hearing examiner is not bound by statutory or common law rules of evidence or technical rules of procedure.
A hearing examiner shall consider evidence offered in accordance with § 10–213 of the State Government Article.
A hearing examiner may not participate in any proceeding in which the hearing examiner has a direct or indirect interest.
The status of the Secretary as a party to a case may not constitute a direct or indirect interest as to a hearing examiner.
Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, ex parte communications are subject to § 10–219 of the State Government Article.
Section 10–219(d) of the State Government Article does not apply to ex parte communications under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A hearing examiner may consolidate claims by more than one individual or claims by a single individual for 2 or more weeks of unemployment if:

subparagraph.text: the same or substantially similar evidence is relevant and material to the matters at issue; and
in the judgment of the hearing examiner, the consolidation would not be prejudicial to a party.

paragraph.text: When claims are consolidated under this subsection, the hearing examiner may:

subparagraph.text: set the same time and place for considering each claim;
conduct joint hearings;
make a single record of the proceedings; and
consider evidence that is introduced in a proceeding for one claim as having been introduced for another claim.

paragraph.text: A record shall be kept, in accordance with § 10–218 of the State Government Article, of all testimony and proceedings before a hearing examiner.
Testimony shall be transcribed if:

subparagraph.text: judicial review is initiated; or
the hearing examiner or the Board of Appeals orders a transcription.

paragraph.text: A witness who is subpoenaed under this subtitle is entitled to compensation at a rate that the chief hearing examiner sets.
