section.text: ** CONTINGENCY – IN EFFECT – CHAPTER 170 OF 2011 **

subsection.text: In this section, “net costs” means benefits payable under this subtitle and that are reimbursed dollar for dollar to the Unemployment Insurance Fund established under § 8–401 of this title less estimated tax revenue payable in connection with the benefits payable under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: There is an Extended Benefits Fund in the State Treasury.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund may be used only to reimburse net costs for claims filed under § 8–1103(f) of this title.

subparagraph.text: The purpose of the Fund is to reimburse counties and municipal corporations for net costs, as determined by the Secretary.
The Fund may be used to reimburse an association that is voluntary, nonprofit, and controlled and maintained by municipal corporations for net costs, as determined by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Secretary shall administer the Fund.
The Treasurer shall invest and reinvest the Fund in the same manner as other State funds.

subsection.text: The Fund shall consist of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;
investment earnings of the Fund; and
any other money from any other source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall ensure that the money in the Fund is distributed in the manner that best accomplishes the purpose of the Fund.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Affected employee” means an individual who has been continuously on the payroll of an affected unit for at least 3 months immediately before the employing unit submits a work sharing plan.
“Affected unit” means a specific plant, department, shift, or other definable unit of an employing unit:

paragraph.text: that has at least 2 employees; and
to which an approved work sharing plan applies.

subsection.text: “Approved work sharing plan” means a plan that satisfies the purpose under § 8–1202 of this subtitle and receives the approval of the Secretary.
“Employer association” means:

paragraph.text: an association that is a party to a collective bargaining agreement under which it may negotiate a work sharing plan; or
an association authorized by all of its members to become a party to a work sharing plan.

subsection.text: “Normal weekly work hours” means the lesser of:

paragraph.text: the number of hours in a week that an employee usually works for the regular employing unit; or
40 hours.
“Work sharing benefit” means benefits payable to an affected employee for work performed under an approved work sharing plan.
“Work sharing benefit” includes benefits payable to a federal civilian employee or former servicemember under Title 5, Chapter 85 of the United States Code.
“Work sharing benefit” does not include benefits that are otherwise payable under this title.

subsection.text: “Work sharing employer” means an employing unit or employer association for which a work sharing plan has been approved.
“Work sharing plan” means a plan of an employing unit or employer association under which:

paragraph.text: normal weekly work hours of affected employees are reduced; and
affected employees share the work that remains after the reduction.

section.text: The work sharing unemployment insurance program seeks to:

paragraph.text: preserve the jobs of employees and the work force of an employer during lowered economic activity by reduction in work hours or workdays rather than by a layoff of some employees while other employees continue their normal weekly work hours or workdays; and
ameliorate the adverse effect of reduction in business activity by providing benefits for the part of the normal weekly work hours or workdays in which an employee does not work.

subsection.text: An employing unit or employer association that wishes to participate in the work sharing unemployment insurance program shall submit to the Secretary a written work sharing plan that the employing unit or representative of the employer association has signed.
Within 15 days after receipt of a work sharing plan, the Secretary shall give written approval or disapproval of the plan.

paragraph.text: When the Secretary disapproves a work sharing plan, the decision is final and may not be appealed.
After 15 days after the Secretary disapproves a work sharing plan, the employing unit or employer association may submit a new work sharing plan.

section.text: The Secretary shall approve a work sharing plan that meets the following requirements:

paragraph.text: the work sharing plan shall apply to:

subparagraph.text: at least 10% of the employees in the affected unit; or
at least 20 employees in an affected unit in which the work sharing plan applies equally to all affected employees.

paragraph.text: the normal weekly work hours of affected employees in the affected unit shall be reduced by at least 10% but, unless waived by the Secretary, the reduction may not exceed 50%.
a work sharing plan shall:

subparagraph.text: identify the affected unit;
identify each employee in the affected unit by name, Social Security number, and any other information that the Secretary requires;
specify an expiration date that is not more than 6 months after the effective date of the work sharing plan;
specify the effect that work sharing will have on the fringe benefits of each employee in the affected unit including:

sub-subparagraph.text: health insurance for hospital, medical, dental, and similar services;
retirement benefits under benefit pension plans as defined in § 3(35) of the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974;
holiday and vacation pay;
sick leave; and
similar advantages;

subparagraph.text: certify that:

sub-subparagraph.text: each affected employee has been continuously on the payroll of the employing unit for 3 months immediately before the date on which the employing unit or employer association submits the work sharing plan; and

the total reduction in normal weekly work hours is instead of layoffs that would have affected at least the number of employees specified in item (1) of this section and that would have resulted in an equivalent reduction in work hours; and

subparagraph.text: contain the written approval of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the collective bargaining agent for each collective bargaining agreement that covers any affected employee in the affected unit; or
if there is no agent, a representative of the employees or employee association in the affected unit.

paragraph.text: if a work sharing plan serves the work sharing employer as a transitional step to permanent staff reduction, the work sharing plan shall contain a reemployment assistance plan for each affected employee that the work sharing employer develops with the Secretary.
the work sharing employer shall agree to:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Secretary reports that are necessary to administer the work sharing plan; and
allow the Department to have access to all records necessary:

sub-subparagraph.text: to verify the work sharing plan before its approval; and
to monitor and evaluate the application of the work sharing plan after its approval.

paragraph.text: a work sharing plan may not subsidize an employing unit that traditionally has used employees who work less than 30 hours a week.

subsection.text: An approved work sharing plan may be modified if the modification meets the requirements for approval under § 8-1204 of this subtitle and the Secretary approves the modification.
An employing unit may add an employee to a work sharing plan under this section when the employee has been continuously on the payroll for 3 months.
An approved modification of a work sharing plan may not change its expiration date.
An affected employee is eligible under § 8-1207 of this subtitle to receive work sharing benefits for each week in which the Secretary determines that the affected employee:

paragraph.text: is able to work; and
is available for more hours of work or full-time work for the work sharing employer.

An affected employee who otherwise is eligible may not be denied work sharing benefits for failure to actively seek work under § 8-903(a)(1)(iii) of this title from a person other than the work sharing employer.
An affected employee may not be disqualified under § 8-1005 of this title for refusal to apply for or accept suitable work from a person other than the work sharing employer.

subsection.text: An affected employee who is otherwise eligible for benefits:

paragraph.text: is considered to be unemployed for the purpose of the work sharing unemployment insurance program; and
is not subject to the requirement under § 8-801 of this title that an individual be unemployed.

subsection.text: Unless the result would be inconsistent with this subtitle, the provisions of this title that apply to a claim for and payment of other benefits apply to a claim for and payment of work sharing benefits.
Work sharing benefits shall be determined in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: To compute work sharing benefits:

subparagraph.text: the weekly benefit amount of an affected employee under § 8-803 of this title shall be multiplied by the percentage of reduction in the employee’s normal weekly work hours under the approved work sharing plan; and
the hours for which an affected employee receives holiday or vacation pay shall be counted as hours worked.

paragraph.text: The product obtained under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection shall be rounded to the next lower dollar.
An affected employee is eligible to receive not more than 26 weeks of work sharing benefits during each benefit year.
The total amount of benefits payable under Subtitle 8 of this title and work sharing benefits payable under this section may not exceed the total for the benefit year under § 8-808(c) of this title.

subsection.text: An allowance for a dependent is payable to an affected employee in accordance with § 8-804 of this title.
An affected employee who receives a work sharing benefit is not subject to the limitation on benefits for partial unemployment under § 8-803(d) of this title.
During a week in which an individual who otherwise is eligible for benefits does not work for the work sharing employer:

paragraph.text: the individual shall be paid benefits in accordance with Subtitle 8 of this title; and
the week does not count as a week for which a work sharing benefit is received.

During a week in which an employee earns wages under an approved work sharing plan and other wages, the work sharing benefit shall be reduced by the same percentage that the combined wages are of wages for normal weekly work hours if the other wages:

subparagraph.text: exceed the wages earned under the approved work sharing plan; and
do not exceed 90% of the wages the individual earns for normal weekly work hours.

paragraph.text: The computation under paragraph (1) of this subsection applies regardless of whether the employee earned the other wage from the work sharing employer or another employer.

subsection.text: While an affected employee applies for or receives work sharing benefits, the affected employee is not eligible for:

paragraph.text: extended benefits;
supplemental federal unemployment compensation; or
benefits under any other federal or State program.

section.text: The Secretary may revoke approval of an approved work sharing plan for good cause, including:

paragraph.text: conduct or an occurrence that tends to defeat the intent and effective operation of the approved work sharing plan;
failure to comply with an assurance in the approved work sharing plan;
unreasonable revision of a productivity standard of the affected unit; and
violation of a criterion on which the Secretary based approval of the approved work sharing plan.

section.text: A person, for that person or another, may not knowingly make a false statement or false representation or knowingly fail to disclose a material fact to receive or increase a benefit or other payment under this title or an unemployment insurance law of another state, the federal government, or a foreign government.
An employer, its officer or agent, or another person may not:

paragraph.text: knowingly make a false statement or false representation or knowingly fail to disclose a material fact to:

subparagraph.text: prevent or reduce the payment of a benefit to an individual who is entitled to the benefit;
avoid becoming or remaining subject to this title; or
avoid or reduce any contribution or other payment that is required from an employer under this title; or

paragraph.text: willfully fail or refuse to:

subparagraph.text: make a contribution or other payment;
submit a report that is required under this title;
produce records that are required under this title; or
allow those records to be copied or inspected.

section.text: An employing unit, directly or indirectly, may not:

paragraph.text: accept, make, or require a deduction from a wage to pay a contribution that the employing unit is required to pay; or
accept or require from an employee a waiver of a right to which the employee is entitled under this title.

section.text: A person may not, without just cause, fail or refuse to obey a subpoena issued under § 8–306(c) or § 8–5A–06(b) of this title if the person has the power to obey the subpoena.

subsection.text: Unless another penalty is provided by statute, a person who willfully violates a provision of this title or a regulation adopted under this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or both.
In addition to the penalty under subsection (a) of this section, a person who violates § 8–1301 of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: shall make full restitution of the benefit unlawfully received, including interest at a rate of 1.5% a month from the date the Secretary notifies the person of the amount to be recovered; and

from 1 year from the date on which a determination is made that the individual filed a claim involving a false statement, false representation, or failure to disclose a material fact, the individual is disqualified from receiving benefits.

An employing unit or officer or agent of an employing unit who violates § 8–1303 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
A person who violates § 8–5A–08(b) or (d) of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

A person who violates § 8–1304 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor for each day the violation continues and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

An employee of the Secretary or Board of Appeals who violates § 8–625 of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

section.text: A prosecution under § 8-1301, § 8-1302, or § 8-1305(a) of this subtitle shall be instituted within 3 years after the date on which the offense was committed.
This title may be cited as the “Maryland Unemployment Insurance Law”.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following terms have the meanings indicated.
“Former servicemember” means a former member of the federal service as defined in 5 U.S.C. § 8521(a) that:

paragraph.text: is eligible for unemployment insurance benefits for ex-servicemembers under 5 U.S.C. § 8521; and
was in active service in connection with Operation Desert Shield or Operation Desert Storm.

subsection.text: “UCX benefits” means unemployment insurance benefits for ex-servicemembers under 5 U.S.C. § 8521.

section.text: Unless the result would be inconsistent with this subtitle, the provisions of this title that apply to claims for or the payment of regular benefits shall apply to additional benefits for former servicemembers.

subsection.text: The eligibility period of a former servicemember consists of:

paragraph.text: the weeks in the former servicemember’s benefit year that begin during the additional benefit period; and
if the former servicemember’s benefit year ends during the additional benefit period, any week thereafter that begins during the additional benefit period.

subsection.text: To be eligible for additional benefits for a week during an eligibility period, a former servicemember:

paragraph.text: shall be unemployed for the week for which benefits are claimed;
shall meet each requirement of this title for regular benefits that applies to a claim for additional benefits;
may not be subject to disqualification from receiving regular benefits; and
shall have exhausted all UCX benefits to which the former servicemember is entitled.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, with respect to unemployment that occurs during an additional benefit period, a former servicemember who is eligible under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: is entitled to a total amount of additional benefits not exceeding 13 times the former servicemember’s weekly benefit amount; and
for each week for which additional benefits are payable, is entitled to allowances for dependents in addition to the additional benefits.

subsection.text: A former servicemember’s entitlement to additional benefits ceases after having received a total of 26 times the former servicemember’s weekly benefit amount in any combination of UCX or additional benefits.

section.text: A former servicemember who otherwise is eligible for additional benefits may not be denied benefits under § 8-1504 of this subtitle or § 8-1005 of this title because the former servicemember is in training with the approval of the Secretary.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Employee” means all individuals employed full time or part time directly by an employer.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, “employer” has the meaning stated in § 10-905 of the Tax - General Article.
“Employer” does not include the federal government, the State, another state, or a political subdivision of the State or another state.

“Health insurance costs” means the amount paid by an employer to provide health care or health insurance to employees in the State to the extent the costs may be deductible by an employer under federal tax law.

“Health insurance costs” includes payments for medical care, prescription drugs, vision care, medical savings accounts, and any other costs to provide health benefits as defined in § 213(d) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: “Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Wages” has the meaning stated in § 10-905 of the Tax - General Article.

section.text: This title applies to an employer with 10,000 or more employees in the State.

paragraph.text: On January 1, 2007, and annually thereafter, an employer shall submit on a form and in a manner approved by the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: the number of employees of the employer in the State as of 1 day in the year immediately preceding the previous calendar year as determined by the employer on an annual basis;
the amount spent by the employer in the year immediately preceding the previous calendar year on health insurance costs in the State; and
the percentage of payroll that was spent by the employer in the year immediately preceding the previous calendar year on health insurance costs in the State.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations that specify the information that an employer shall submit under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
The information required shall:

subparagraph.text: be designated in a report signed by the principal executive officer or an individual performing a similar function; and
include an affidavit under penalty of perjury that the information required under paragraph (1) of this subsection:

sub-subparagraph.text: was reviewed by the signing officer; and
is true to the best of the signing officer’s knowledge, information, and belief.

subsection.text: When calculating the percentage of payroll under subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section, an employer may exempt:

paragraph.text: wages paid to any employee in excess of the median household income in the State as published by the United States Census Bureau; and
wages paid to an employee who is enrolled in or eligible for Medicare.

subsection.text: An employer that is organized as a nonprofit organization that does not spend up to 6% of the total wages paid to employees in the State on health insurance costs shall pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the difference between what the employer spends for health insurance costs and an amount equal to 6% of the total wages paid to employees in the State.

An employer that is not organized as a nonprofit organization and does not spend up to 8% of the total wages paid to employees in the State on health insurance costs shall pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the difference between what the employer spends for health insurance costs and an amount equal to 8% of the total wages paid to employees in the State.
An employer may not deduct any payment made under subsection (a) or (b) of this section from the wages of an employee.
An employer shall make the payment required under this section to the Secretary on a periodic basis as determined by the Secretary.
Failure to report in accordance with § 8.5-103 of this title shall result in the imposition by the Secretary of a civil penalty of $250 for each day that the report is not timely filed.
Failure to make the payment required under § 8.5-104 of this title shall result in the imposition by the Secretary of a civil penalty of $250,000.

In this section, “health insurance benefits” includes payments for medical care, prescription drugs, vision care, medical savings accounts, and any other costs to provide health benefits, as defined in § 213(d) of the Internal Revenue Code.
On or before March 15 of each year, the Secretary shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on:

paragraph.text: the name of each nonprofit and for profit employer with 10,000 or more employees in the State;
the employer’s definition of full-time employee and part-time employee;
the number of full-time employees;
the number of full-time employees eligible to receive health insurance benefits;
the number of full-time employees receiving health insurance benefits from the employer;
the source of health insurance benefits for those eligible full-time employees not receiving health insurance benefits through an employer subject to reporting under this title;
the number of part-time employees;
the number of part-time employees eligible to receive health insurance benefits;
the number of part-time employees receiving health insurance benefits from the employer; and
the source of health insurance benefits for those eligible part-time employees not receiving health insurance benefits through an employer subject to reporting under this title.

subsection.text: The information required under subsection (b) of this section shall be reported as of the information reporting date determined by the employer under § 8.5-103(a)(1)(i) of this title.

section.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: on an annual basis, based on the information reported under § 8.5-103(a)(1)(i) of this title:

subparagraph.text: verify which employers have 10,000 or more employees in the State; and
ensure that all employers with 10,000 or more employees in the State have made the report required under § 8.5-103 of this title;

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to implement this title; and
pay the revenue from the payroll assessment into the Fund created under § 15-142 of the Health - General Article.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Accidental personal injury” means:

paragraph.text: an accidental injury that arises out of and in the course of employment;
an injury caused by a willful or negligent act of a third person directed against a covered employee in the course of the employment of the covered employee; or
a disease or infection that naturally results from an accidental injury that arises out of and in the course of employment, including:

subparagraph.text: an occupational disease; and
frostbite or sunstroke caused by a weather condition.

subsection.text: “Child” includes:

paragraph.text: an adopted child;
an illegitimate child;
a posthumous child; and
a stepchild.

subsection.text: “Commission” means the State Workers’ Compensation Commission.

paragraph.text: “Compensation” means the money payable under this title to a covered employee or the dependents of a covered employee.
“Compensation” includes funeral benefits payable under this title.

subsection.text: “Covered employee” means an individual listed in Subtitle 2 of this title for whom a person, a governmental unit, or a quasi-public corporation is required by law to provide coverage under this title.
“Occupational disease” means a disease contracted by a covered employee:

paragraph.text: as the result of and in the course of employment; and
that causes the covered employee to become temporarily or permanently, partially or totally incapacitated.

subsection.text: This title shall be construed to carry out its general purpose.
The rule that a statute in derogation of the common law is to be strictly construed does not apply to this title.
Except as otherwise expressly provided in this title, each minor who is a covered employee shall be deemed an adult for purposes of this title.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person other than the minor covered employee does not have a cause of action or right to compensation for an injury to the minor covered employee.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a covered employee or an employer of a covered employee may not by agreement, rule, or regulation:

subparagraph.text: exempt the covered employee or the employer from a duty of the covered employee or the employer under this title; or
waive a right of the covered employee or the employer under this title.

paragraph.text: An agreement, rule, or regulation that violates paragraph (1) of this subsection is void to the extent of the violation.

If federal law provides an exclusive remedy and compensation to an employee of a common carrier by railroad in this State or a dependent of the employee for disability or death caused by an accidental personal injury sustained in interstate or foreign commerce, the carrier and the employee may enter into an agreement that provides:

subparagraph.text: for the payment by the carrier of compensation, in accordance with the federal law, to the employee or a dependent of the employee for disability or death caused by an accidental personal injury sustained in intrastate commerce; and
except as otherwise provided in the agreement, that the carrier may not be civilly liable for the disability or death of the employee caused by the accidental personal injury.

paragraph.text: To enter into an agreement with any employees of a common carrier by railroad under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the carrier shall:

subparagraph.text: submit, under seal, to the Commission a document that:

sub-subparagraph.text: offers to enter into an agreement with each of its employees in the State under paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
refers to the applicable federal law; and

subparagraph.text: publish notice of the offer once a week for 3 successive weeks after the document is submitted to the Commission:

sub-subparagraph.text: in a newspaper published in each county through which the carrier regularly runs a freight or passenger train; and
if the carrier regularly runs a freight or passenger train within Baltimore City, in 2 newspapers published in Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: Thirty days after a common carrier by railroad submits to the Commission a document making an offer under paragraph (2) of this subsection, each employee of the carrier shall be conclusively presumed to have entered into the agreement unless, within the 30 days, an employee submits to the Commission a written notice declining the offer.

A common carrier by railroad or an employee of the carrier may end an agreement made under this subsection on the part of the carrier or employee by giving the Commission at least 30 days’ written notice of intention to end the agreement.

If a common carrier by railroad or an employee of the carrier gives the Commission notice of intention to end the agreement in accordance with paragraph (4) of this subsection, the agreement shall end on the part of the carrier or employee on the effective date of the notice.

subsection.text: A covered employee who has sustained an injury or partial disability may waive by written contract the rights of the covered employee under this title for any subsequent injury that is naturally and proximately caused by the previous injury or disability if the covered employee:

paragraph.text: voluntarily enters into the contract; and
executes the contract in the presence of 2 individuals who sign the contract as witnesses.

Subject to paragraph (5) of this subsection, as part of a collective bargaining agreement, an employer and a recognized or certified exclusive bargaining representative of employees under the purview of the Building and Construction Trade Council may agree to:

subparagraph.text: an alternative dispute resolution system that modifies, supplements, or replaces all or part of the dispute prevention and dispute resolution processes contained in this title, and that may include but is not limited to mediation and binding arbitration;

the use of an agreed list of health care providers of medical treatment and expertise, which may be the source of all medical and related examinations, treatment, and testimony provided under this title;
the use of an agreed list of health care providers to conduct independent medical examinations;
a light duty, modified job, or return to work program; and
a vocational rehabilitation or retraining program.

All settlements and resolutions of claims under an alternative dispute resolution system shall be submitted to the Commission for approval. The Commission shall approve settlements and resolutions of claims that the Commission determines are in compliance with this title.
All arbitration decisions under an alternative dispute resolution system shall be reviewable in the same manner and under the same procedures as a decision of a commissioner.

paragraph.text: An agreement under this subsection is not valid until it has been filed with the Commission and determined by the Commission to be in compliance with this subsection and this title.
Once an agreement under this subsection has been determined to be in compliance with this subsection and this title by the Commission it is binding on the employer and the bargaining unit.
This subsection does not allow an agreement that:

subparagraph.text: exempts a covered employee or an employer from a duty of the covered employee or employer under this title;
waives or limits a right or benefit of a covered employee or employer under this title, except as otherwise set forth in this subsection;
affects the imposition of an assessment on settlements and resolutions of claims, as described in §§ 9–806 and 9–1007 of this title; or
affects claims made under Subtitle 8 or Subtitle 10 of this title or claims made under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of this article.

paragraph.text: An agreement that violates paragraph (5) of this subsection is void.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection, an injured employee whose injury or treatment is related to a medical condition for which the employee is being or has been treated may continue to seek treatment from the health care provider who is treating or has treated the condition.
An agreement under this subsection shall provide for an appeal mechanism for a covered employee who wishes to use a health care provider who is not on the agreed list of health care providers.
Nothing in this subsection requires an insurer to underwrite a program established under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Before a governmental unit may issue a license or permit to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer might employ a covered employee, the employer shall submit to the governmental unit:

paragraph.text: a certificate of compliance with this title; or
the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.

The Commission shall provide blank application forms to each governmental unit that issues a license or permit under State law for applicants for the license or permit to use to get a certificate of compliance.
The application form shall require information that will allow the Commission to determine whether the employer is in compliance with this title.

subsection.text: To get a certificate of compliance with this title, an employer shall submit to the Commission an application on the form that the Commission provides.
Within 10 days after the Commission receives an application form under this section, the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: determine whether the applicant is in compliance with this title; and
mail to the applicant:

subparagraph.text: a certificate of compliance; or
a notice of rejection, which shall include a statement of the reasons for the rejection.

subsection.text: An applicant who receives a notice of rejection may:

paragraph.text: reapply for a certificate of compliance; or
appeal the rejection in accordance with §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The Commission shall adopt reasonable regulations to administer this section.
Money for the administration of this section shall be included in the annual State budget.

section.text: This title applies to the following employers:

paragraph.text: each person who has at least 1 covered employee; and
each governmental unit or quasi-public corporation that has at least 1 covered employee.

subsection.text: An individual, including a minor, is presumed to be a covered employee while in the service of an employer under an express or implied contract of apprenticeship or hire.
A minor may be a covered employee under this section even if the minor is employed unlawfully.

To overcome the presumption of covered employment, an employer shall establish that the individual performing services is an independent contractor in accordance with the common law or is specifically exempted from covered employment under this subtitle.
Except as otherwise expressly provided, an individual is a covered employee while working for the employer of the individual:

paragraph.text: in this State;
outside of this State on a casual, incidental, or occasional basis if the employer regularly employs the individual within this State; or
wholly outside the United States under a contract of employment made in this State for the work to be done wholly outside of the United States.
An individual is not a covered employee while working in this State for an employer only intermittently or temporarily if:

subparagraph.text: the individual and employer make a contract of hire in another state;
neither the individual nor the employer is a resident of this State;
the employer has provided workers’ compensation insurance coverage under a workers’ compensation or similar law of another state to cover the individual while working in this State;
the other state recognizes the extraterritorial provisions of this title; and
the other state similarly exempts covered employees and their employers from its law.

paragraph.text: If an individual is exempted from coverage under this subsection and injured in this State while working for the employer of the individual, the sole remedy of the individual is the workers’ compensation or similar law of the state on which the exemption is based.

A certificate from an authorized officer of the workers’ compensation commission or similar unit of another state certifying that the employer is insured in that state and has provided extraterritorial insurance coverage for the employees of the employer while working within this State is prima facie evidence that the employer carries that compensation insurance.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided, an individual who is employed wholly outside of this State is not a covered employee.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, with the approval of the Commission, an individual who otherwise would not be a covered employee and the employer of the individual may elect to make the individual a covered employee by filing a joint election with the Commission.
The right to make an election under this subsection for an individual may be exercised by:

subparagraph.text: an individual who is at least 16 years old; or
a parent or guardian of an individual who is less than 16 years old.

subsection.text: An individual who is not a covered employee due to § 9-223(c) of this subtitle and the employer of the individual may not make an election under this section if prohibited by federal law.

section.text: A casual employee is not a covered employee.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, an officer of a corporation or a member of a limited liability company is a covered employee if the officer or member provides a service for the corporation or limited liability company for monetary compensation.
An individual who otherwise would be a covered employee under this section may elect to be exempt from coverage if:

paragraph.text: the individual:

subparagraph.text: is an officer of a close corporation, as defined in § 4–101(b) of the Corporations and Associations Article; or
is an officer of a close corporation, as defined under the laws of the jurisdiction in which the corporation is incorporated;

paragraph.text: subject to subsection (c)(3) of this section, the individual is an officer of a corporation, other than a close corporation;
the individual:

subparagraph.text: is an officer of a corporation that earns at least 75% of its income from farm operations; and
owns at least 20% of the outstanding capital stock of the corporation;

paragraph.text: the individual:

subparagraph.text: is an officer of a professional corporation, as defined in § 5–101(c) or (f) of the Corporations and Associations Article;
owns at least 20% of the outstanding capital stock of the corporation; and
performs for the corporation a professional service, as defined in § 5–101(g) of the Corporations and Associations Article; or

paragraph.text: the individual:

subparagraph.text: is a member of a limited liability company, as defined in § 4A–101(l) of the Corporations and Associations Article; and
owns at least 20% of the outstanding interests in profits of the limited liability company.

paragraph.text: A corporation or limited liability company shall submit to the Commission and to the insurer of the corporation or limited liability company a written notice that names the individual who has made an election to be exempt under subsection (b) of this section.
An election under subsection (b)(1) or (b)(4) of this section is not effective until a corporation or limited liability company complies with this subsection.
No more than five officers of a corporation described in subsection (b)(2) of this section may elect to be exempt under subsection (b)(2) of this section.

subsection.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.
A registered crew member, a paid law enforcement employee, or an individual engaged for fire fighting by the Department of Natural Resources is a covered employee.

Notwithstanding § 9-203 of this subtitle, an individual engaged for fire fighting who otherwise would be a covered employee under subsection (a) of this section is a covered employee even if the fire fighting takes place outside of the State.
Notwithstanding § 9-205 of this subtitle, an individual who otherwise would be a covered employee under subsection (a) of this section is a covered employee even if engaged temporarily or part time.
For the purpose of this title, the Department of Natural Resources is the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this section.
An individual is a covered employee if the individual regularly distributes or sells newspapers:

paragraph.text: on the street; or
to customers at their homes or places of business.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this title, the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this section is:

paragraph.text: each independent news agency for which the covered employee sells newspapers; and
each publisher who engages the covered employee to distribute or sell its newspapers.

subsection.text: An individual who is employed as a domestic worker in a private home is a covered employee with respect to a household if the individual earns at least $1,000 in cash in a calendar quarter from that household.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, an individual and the employer of the individual may elect to make the individual a covered employee by filing a joint election with the Commission, if the individual:

subparagraph.text: is employed as a domestic worker in a private home; and

would not be a covered employee with respect to a household under the provisions of subsection (a) of this section because the individual earns less than $1,000 in cash in a calendar quarter from that household.

paragraph.text: The right to make an election under paragraph (1) of this subsection for an individual may be exercised by:

subparagraph.text: an individual who is at least 16 years old; or
a parent or guardian of an individual who is less than 16 years old.

paragraph.text: For an individual who is not a covered employee due to § 9–223(c) of this subtitle, an employer may not make an election under this subsection if prohibited by federal law.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Farmer” includes a dairy farmer.

subparagraph.text: “Migrant farm worker” means an individual who is engaged in seasonal or other temporary agricultural employment and who is:

sub-subparagraph.text: absent overnight from the permanent residence of the individual; or
transported to and from the place of employment of the individual by a day-haul operation.

subparagraph.text: “Migrant farm worker” does not include an individual who performs a service included in subsection (b) of this section if the individual:

sub-subparagraph.text: does not operate equipment or machinery; and
is employed:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: within 25 miles of the permanent residence of the individual; and
for not more than 13 weeks a year.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an individual, including a migrant farm worker, is a covered employee if:

paragraph.text: the individual receives compensation from a farmer for any service other than office work, including:

subparagraph.text: operating a machine connected with animal, crop, or soil management;
constructing or repairing a fixture or machine; or
handling an animal or crop with or without a machine; and

paragraph.text: the farmer has:

subparagraph.text: at least 3 full-time employees; or
an annual payroll of at least $15,000 for full-time employees.

subsection.text: An individual, other than a migrant farm worker, who receives compensation from a farmer for a service is not a covered employee if:

paragraph.text: the individual customarily is engaged in an independent business occupation of the same nature as that of the service performed;
the individual is free from control and direction over the individual’s performance of the service;
the individual provides the individual’s own equipment, materials, and tools; and
the farmer is not required to withhold Social Security, unemployment, State, or federal taxes from the compensation paid to the individual.

section.text: An individual is a covered employee if the individual is employed as a helper of another covered employee with the actual or constructive knowledge of the employer of the other covered employee, whether paid by the other covered employee or the employer.

paragraph.text: This section applies to each jockey licensed by the State Racing Commission to ride a thoroughbred horse.
This section applies only at a thoroughbred racing association or training facility under the jurisdiction of the State Racing Commission.

subsection.text: A jockey is a covered employee while performing a service in connection with racing or training a thoroughbred race horse.

paragraph.text: For the purposes of this title, the joint employers of a jockey who is a covered employee under this section while performing a service in connection with racing are:

subparagraph.text: the Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc.; and

each licensed owner or trainer who is subject to assessment under § 11-906 of the Business Regulation Article at the time of any occurrence for which benefits are payable to the jockey under this title.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this title, the employer of a jockey who is a covered employee under this section while performing a service in connection with training is the trainer for whom the service is performed.
This subsection does not affect any other provision of law or practice.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, this section may not be construed to bar an action by a jockey against a third party.
An individual on jury duty in a circuit court of a county is a covered employee.
For the purposes of this title, the State is the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this section.

section.text: An individual who is employed to do maintenance, remodeling, repairs, or similar work is not a covered employee if:

paragraph.text: the individual is employed for not more than 30 consecutive work days; and
the work is done:

subparagraph.text: in or about the private home of the employer; or
for an employer with no other covered employee, in or about the premises where the employer carries on a business, profession, or trade.

subsection.text: In this section, “organized militia” includes members of the Maryland Defense Force described under § 13-203 of the Public Safety Article.
Each officer or enlisted member of the organized militia of the State is a covered employee in peace time, while the member is:

paragraph.text: training as part of the Maryland State Guard; or
on active military duty in the organized militia under order of the Governor in time of:

subparagraph.text: civil disorder;
labor disorder;
natural disaster; or
other events that require the support of the State Militia.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this title, the State is the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Mine” includes a drift, shaft, slope, tunnel, underground room, and any other underground places or workings.
“Mineral” includes clay, coal, and iron.

subsection.text: An individual is a covered employee while working in or about a mine to extract minerals.

An individual who is a covered employee under subsection (b) of this section is deemed to be employed entirely within this State if the mouth, principal entrance, or tipple of the mine in or about which the individual works is within this State, even if:

paragraph.text: a drift, shaft, slope, or other underground tunnel extends into an adjoining state; and
the individual is injured or killed while working in the mine within the adjoining state.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each appointed or elected official of a political subdivision is a covered employee while performing an official duty.
A nonsalaried member of a board or commission in Allegany, Carroll, Cecil, Charles, Frederick, Garrett, Queen Anne’s, St. Mary’s, Somerset, Washington, or Worcester County is not a covered employee.

paragraph.text: This section applies to an individual who is an owner operator of:

subparagraph.text: a Class F (tractor) vehicle, as described in § 13-923 of the Transportation Article; or

except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a Class E (truck) vehicle, as described in § 13-916 of the Transportation Article, including a Class E (truck) vehicle described in § 13-919 of the Transportation Article.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to the owner operator of a vehicle registered as a Class T vehicle under § 13-920 of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: An individual who is an owner operator is not a covered employee if:

paragraph.text: the individual and motor carrier make a written agreement for permanent or trip leasing;
under the agreement:

subparagraph.text: there is no intent to create an employer-employee relationship; and
the individual is paid rental compensation; and

paragraph.text: for federal tax purposes, the individual qualifies as an independent contractor.
A motor carrier who enters into an agreement under subsection (b) of this section is considered a principal contractor under § 9-508 of this title.
An individual who is an owner operator and enters into an agreement under subsection (b) of this section is:

subparagraph.text: considered a subcontractor under § 9-508 of this title;
for purposes of being a subcontractor, not considered a covered employee of the entity that the individual operator owns; and
not entitled to compensation from a principal contractor under § 9-508 of this title.

subsection.text: An individual who is an owner operator and enters into a written agreement under subsection (b) of this section shall provide proof of insurance for any covered employee of the individual as may be required by this title.
Unless an election is made in accordance with this section, a partner of a partnership is not a covered employee.
A partnership may elect to make a partner a covered employee if the partner devotes full time to the business of the partnership.

An election under this section is not effective until the partnership submits to the Commission and to the insurer of the partnership a written notice that names the individual to be a covered employee.

paragraph.text: Each auxiliary police officer for Baltimore County is a covered employee while on duty as defined in the Baltimore County Police Manual of Rules, Regulations, and Procedures.
Each auxiliary police officer for Howard County is a covered employee while on duty as defined in the Howard County Police Department’s General Orders.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each member of a volunteer police department is a covered employee.
A member of a volunteer police department in Allegany, Carroll, Cecil, Charles, Garrett, Queen Anne’s, St. Mary’s, Somerset, Washington, or Worcester County is not a covered employee.
For the purposes of this title, the political subdivision of the State where the department is organized is the employer of the covered employee in the department.

subsection.text: A prisoner is a covered employee while the prisoner is:

paragraph.text: working for a board of county commissioners, a county council, or a county roads board if:

subparagraph.text: the county pays the prisoner a wage or stipulated sum; and
the prisoner sustains permanent partial or permanent total disability or dies, as a result of an accidental personal injury; or

paragraph.text: engaged in work while under the supervision of Maryland Correctional Enterprises in the Federal Prison Industry Enhancement Program as provided in § 10-308(d) of the Correctional Services Article.

subsection.text: In Allegany, Anne Arundel, Charles, Montgomery, Washington, and Wicomico counties, payment of a stipend or other money into an account that a correctional institution administers for a prisoner does not constitute payment of a wage or stipulated sum under subsection (a)(1)(i) of this section.

section.text: An individual is not a covered employee if the individual:

paragraph.text: is a licensed real estate salesperson or a licensed associate real estate broker;
is affiliated with a licensed real estate broker under a written agreement;
is compensated solely on a commission basis; and
for federal tax purposes, qualifies as an independent contractor.

subsection.text: An individual is not a covered employee if the individual is eligible under a federal law, other than the Social Security Act, for benefits for an accidental personal injury or occupational disease.
An individual for whom federal law provides a rule of liability for injury or death is not a covered employee.

Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b) of this section, if an individual for whom federal law provides a rule of liability or method of compensation and the employer of the individual engage both in intrastate commerce and in foreign or interstate commerce, the individual is a covered employee when engaged in intrastate commerce to the extent that the mutual connection of the individual and the employer with intrastate commerce is clearly distinguishable and separable from foreign or interstate commerce.
An individual is a covered employee while the individual is assigned to a job under:

paragraph.text: general public assistance to employables; or
a work experience program that the Department of Human Resources administers as part of its employment initiatives project.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this title, the Department of Human Resources is the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this section.

section.text: A resident in a facility as defined in § 10-101(e) of the Health - General Article is not a covered employee.

subsection.text: A volunteer aide under § 6-106 of the Education Article is a covered employee.

For the purposes of this title, the Board of School Commissioners of Baltimore City or the board of education for any other county is the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this section in that county.
Unless an election is made in accordance with this section, a sole proprietor is not a covered employee.
A sole proprietor may elect to be a covered employee if the proprietor devotes full time to the business of the proprietorship.

An election under this section is not effective until the proprietor submits to the Commission and to the insurer of the proprietor a written notice that names the individual who is to be a covered employee.

paragraph.text: A student with a disability as defined in § 8–401(a)(2) of the Education Article is a covered employee while working for an employer without wages in a work assignment in accordance with § 8–402 of the Education Article.
For the purposes of this title, the employer for whom the student with a disability works is the employer of that student.
An individual is a covered employee while working as a student intern or student teacher under § 6–107 of the Education Article.

For the purposes of this title, the Board of School Commissioners of Baltimore City or the board of education for any other county is the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this subsection in that county.

A student is a covered employee when the student has been placed with an employer in an unpaid work–based learning experience coordinated by a county board or private noncollegiate institution under § 7–114 of the Education Article.
For purposes of this title, the employer for whom the student works in the unpaid work–based learning experience is the employer of that student.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“DORS” means the Division of Rehabilitation Services in the State Department of Education.
“DORS consumer” has the meaning stated in § 21–310 of the Education Article.

paragraph.text: A DORS consumer is a covered employee when the individual has been placed by DORS with an employer in an unpaid work–based learning experience.
For purposes of this title, the employer for whom the DORS consumer works in the unpaid work–based learning experience is the employer of the DORS consumer.

section.text: An individual who is a covered employee while regularly employed or while serving an apprenticeship continues to be a covered employee while the individual receives instruction or training outside the regular work hours of the individual that relates to the employment or apprenticeship of the individual.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Ridesharing” has the meaning stated in § 11-150.1 of the Transportation Article.
“Vanpool operation” has the meaning stated in § 11-175.1(a) of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: This section applies only with respect to a vanpool operation in which the vehicle:

paragraph.text: is leased, operated, or owned by an employer for ridesharing;
operates between the residence and place of employment of the passengers; and
is insured in accordance with § 13-422 of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: An individual is a covered employee while operating a vehicle in a vanpool operation as part of the duties of the individual for the employer.
A passenger in a vanpool operation is not a covered employee.

section.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided by law, a volunteer worker for a unit of a political subdivision in Allegany, Carroll, Cecil, Charles, Frederick, Garrett, Queen Anne’s, St. Mary’s, Somerset, Washington, or Worcester County is not a covered employee.

subsection.text: A volunteer worker for a unit of State government is a covered employee.
For the purposes of this title, the State is the employer of an individual who is a covered employee under this section.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, benefits provided under this section shall consist only of medical services and treatment under Subtitle 6, Part IX of this title for a compensable injury.
Each regularly enrolled volunteer member or trainee of the Maryland Emergency Management Agency established under the Maryland Emergency Management Agency Act is a covered employee.
For the purposes of this title, the State is the employer of each individual who is a covered employee under this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Civil defense volunteer” means an individual who is precertified or preregistered with a unit of State government to provide services at the request of the State during an emergency.
“Civil defense volunteer” includes a credentialed or registered member of a professional volunteer health corps established by a unit of State government.
“Emergency” has the meaning stated in § 14-101(c) of the Public Safety Article.
“Emergency” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: a catastrophic health emergency as defined in § 14-3A-01 of the Public Safety Article; and
any event for which the State provides volunteer services in accordance with:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the provisions for a state of emergency under § 14-107 or § 14-108 of the Public Safety Article;
the Interstate Emergency Management and Civil Defense Compact under § 14-602 of the Public Safety Article; or
the Emergency Management Assistance Compact under § 14-702 of the Public Safety Article.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a civil defense volunteer is a covered employee if the individual sustains an injury in the course of providing services at the request of the State during an emergency while the emergency may reasonably be considered to be in existence, or during scheduled emergency training.

A civil defense volunteer is not entitled to workers’ compensation benefits under this section if the individual is otherwise covered by workers’ compensation insurance for services performed at the request of the State during an emergency or scheduled emergency training.
A civil defense volunteer must file a claim in this State to be eligible for benefits under this section.
For the purpose of computing the average weekly wage of a civil defense volunteer who is covered under this section, the wages of the covered employee shall be:

subparagraph.text: for a covered employee who received a salary or wages from other employment at the time of the accidental personal injury or last injurious exposure, the salary or wages from the other employment; or
for a covered employee who did not receive a salary or wages from other employment at the time of the accidental personal injury or last injurious exposure:

sub-subparagraph.text: if the covered employee derived income from a source other than salary or wages at the time of the accidental personal injury or last injurious exposure, an amount that allows the maximum compensation under this title;

if the covered employee was not engaged in a business enterprise at the time of the accidental personal injury or last injurious exposure, the weekly income last received by the covered employee when engaged in a business enterprise; or

if the covered employee had never been engaged in a business enterprise at the time of the accidental personal injury or last injurious exposure, an amount that allows the minimum compensation under this title.

subsection.text: Each volunteer deputy sheriff of Cecil County is a covered employee while performing work assigned by the sheriff of the county.

Each volunteer police officer of Frederick County is a covered employee entitled to medical benefits under §§ 9–660 and 9–661 of this title while performing work assigned by the Sheriff of Frederick County.
Each auxiliary volunteer of the Charles County Sheriff’s Office is a covered employee while performing work assigned by the Sheriff of the county.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “On duty” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: fighting a fire;
performing a duty of a member of an advanced life support unit or an ambulance, first aid, or rescue squad in a volunteer company;
except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, performing a duty that the volunteer company assigns to the member;
performing a duty that a written bylaw or rule of government adopted for the volunteer company assigns to the member;
going to or from performing a duty included under item 1, 2, 3, or 4 of this subparagraph;
accompanying an accident or fire victim while being transported to a hospital in a helicopter;
returning to the home station of the individual after accompanying a victim under item 6 of this subparagraph;
performing a duty assigned to a member of a fire company appointed as a deputy sheriff under § 7–302 or § 7–303 of the Public Safety Article; or
performing a duty assigned to an individual appointed to serve as a member of the fire police in Washington County under § 7–304 of the Public Safety Article.

subparagraph.text: “On duty” does not include attendance of a member of a volunteer company at a social function unless a written bylaw or rule of government adopted for the volunteer company requires the attendance or participation of the member.

paragraph.text: “Volunteer company” means:

subparagraph.text: a volunteer advanced life support unit;
a volunteer ambulance company or squad;
a volunteer fire company or department;
a volunteer rescue company, department, or squad; and
a volunteer fire police unit.

subsection.text: An individual who is a covered employee under subsection (h)(2), (k), (n), (o)(2), (p)(1)(ii), (r)(3), (v), or (x)(1) of this section continues to be a covered employee while:

paragraph.text: accompanying an accident or fire victim who is being transported to a hospital in a helicopter; and
returning to the home station of the individual after accompanying a victim under item (1) of this subsection.
Unless an election is made under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in Allegany County is not a covered employee.
The Board of County Commissioners for Allegany County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.

subsection.text: A member of a volunteer company in Anne Arundel County is a covered employee while on duty.
A member of a volunteer company in Baltimore County is a covered employee while on duty.
A member of a volunteer company in Calvert County is a covered employee while on duty.
A member of a volunteer company in Caroline County is a covered employee while on duty.

paragraph.text: Unless an election is made in accordance with this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in Carroll County is not a covered employee.
A volunteer fire company in Carroll County may elect to make its members covered employees.
A volunteer fire company that elects to make its members covered employees shall pay the premium for the coverage.
A member of a volunteer company in Cecil County who meets the guidelines set under paragraph (2) of this subsection is a covered employee while on duty.
The Board of County Commissioners of Cecil County may set guidelines to determine the eligibility of members of a volunteer company in the county for coverage under this subsection.
The guidelines under paragraph (2) of this subsection may not limit the number of covered employees in a volunteer company.
Unless an election is made in accordance with this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in Charles County is not a covered employee.
The Board of County Commissioners of Charles County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.

subsection.text: A member of a volunteer company in Dorchester County is a covered employee.
A member of a volunteer company in Frederick County is a covered employee while on duty.

paragraph.text: Unless an election is made under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in Garrett County is not a covered employee.
The Board of County Commissioners for Garrett County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.

subsection.text: A member of a volunteer company in Harford County is a covered employee.
An individual is a covered employee:

paragraph.text: while on duty as an actively participating member of a volunteer company in Howard County; or
if not covered under item (1) of this subsection, while a member of a volunteer company in Howard County participating in the activities of the volunteer company.
An individual is a covered employee:

subparagraph.text: while on duty as an actively participating member of a volunteer company in Kent County; or
if not covered under item (i) of this paragraph, while a member of a volunteer company in Kent County.

paragraph.text: The Board of County Commissioners of Kent County shall impose annually a tax on assessable property in the county in an amount that is sufficient to pay for coverage under this subsection.
The Board of County Commissioners of Kent County may limit the number of members in a volunteer company in the county.

subsection.text: A member of a volunteer company in Montgomery County is a covered employee while on duty.
An individual is a covered employee:

paragraph.text: while on duty as a member of the Laurel volunteer rescue squad in Prince George’s County; or
while a member of a volunteer company in Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: A member of a volunteer company in Queen Anne’s County is a covered employee while on duty.

paragraph.text: Unless an election is made under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in St. Mary’s County is not a covered employee.
The Board of County Commissioners for St. Mary’s County may provide by resolution for the members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.
Unless an election is made under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in Somerset County is not a covered employee.
The Board of County Commissioners for Somerset County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.
A member of a volunteer company in Talbot County is a covered employee.
The County Council of Talbot County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.
Unless an election is made under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in Washington County is not a covered employee.
The Board of County Commissioners for Washington County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.
A member of a volunteer company in Wicomico County is a covered employee.
The County Council of Wicomico County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.
Unless an election is made under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member of a volunteer company in Worcester County is not a covered employee.
The Board of County Commissioners for Worcester County may provide by resolution for members of a volunteer company in the county to be covered employees while on duty.

For the purposes of this title, a member of a volunteer company who is a covered employee under this section is an employee of the political subdivision of the State where the volunteer company is organized.
A member of a volunteer company shall be covered while on duty by a policy of workers’ compensation insurance.

subsection.text: A member of a volunteer company who is a covered employee under this section may not be considered a paid covered employee of the volunteer company for receiving as a membership benefit a yearly stipend of $5,200 or less to help offset out–of–pocket expenses.

section.text: An individual is not a covered employee while performing a service only for aid or sustenance from a charitable or religious organization.

An individual is a covered employee while performing a service for compensation in the course of the business, occupation, profession, or trade of an employer if, in relation to the service, the individual:

paragraph.text: does not maintain a separate business;
neither represents to the public that the individual provides the service nor provides the service to the public; and
does not have a covered employee.

section.text: There is a State Workers’ Compensation Commission established as an independent unit of the State government.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of 10 members, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Commission:

subparagraph.text: at the time of appointment, shall be at least 30 years old; and
for at least 5 years immediately before appointment, shall have been a resident of the State.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: be a resident of the State;
be a citizen and qualified voter of the State;
have been admitted to practice law in the State; and
be distinguished for integrity, sound legal knowledge, and wisdom.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Commission shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 12 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 1991.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Subject to the hearing requirements of this subsection, the Governor may remove a member from office for:

subparagraph.text: inefficiency;
neglect of duty; or
malfeasance in office.

paragraph.text: Before the Governor removes a member, the Governor shall give the member:

subparagraph.text: a copy of the charges against the member; and
an opportunity for a public hearing.

paragraph.text: At least 10 days before the hearing, the Governor shall give the member notice of the time and place of the hearing.
The member may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
In this subsection, “former commissioner” means a commissioner who previously served as a member of the Commission.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Chairman may assign a former commissioner to conduct hearings if the former commissioner:

subparagraph.text: served, in the aggregate, at least 3 years as a commissioner;
meets the standards established by this section as well as any additional standards established by rules of the Commission; and
consents to the temporary assignment.

paragraph.text: A former commissioner may not be recalled for temporary assignment if the commissioner:

subparagraph.text: was removed or involuntarily retired from the Commission pursuant to the Constitution or laws of this State;
voluntarily retired by reason of disability; or
had the most recent service as a commissioner terminated by rejection of confirmation by the Senate.
A former commissioner recalled under this section may not be temporarily assigned for more than 120 working days in any calendar year.

If on the 120th working day in a calendar year that a former commissioner has served in a temporary assignment under this section the hearing on the case then being heard by the commissioner is not concluded, the Commission may extend the commissioner’s assignment until that case is concluded.

paragraph.text: A former commissioner temporarily assigned under this section has all the power and authority of a member of this Commission.

sub-subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding the receipt of a retirement allowance, a former commissioner temporarily assigned under this section shall receive per diem compensation for each day actually engaged in the discharge of Commission duties.
The per diem shall be based on the current annual salary of a member of the Commission and computed on the basis of 246 working days a year.

If the sum of the per diem payments received by a former commissioner in any one calendar year, when added to the retirement allowance the former commissioner is entitled to receive during that calendar year, equals the annual salary of a member of the Commission, no further per diem may be paid to the former commissioner in that calendar year.
A deduction may not be withheld for health benefits or retirement purposes from the compensation paid to a former commissioner during the time of the temporary assignment.
A commissioner on temporary assignment does not earn additional creditable service under the State retirement or pension system.

subparagraph.text: In addition to the per diem compensation provided for in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, a former commissioner shall be reimbursed for reasonable expenses actually incurred by reason of the temporary assignment, in accordance with Standard State Travel Regulations.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations consistent with those for the recall of former circuit and District Court judges.

subsection.text: From among the members of the Commission, the Governor shall appoint a chairman.

paragraph.text: The Chairman is the administrative and executive head of the Commission.
Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Chairman has final authority over:

subparagraph.text: the administrative work of the Commission and its employees; and
the assignment of cases for hearing.

paragraph.text: The Chairman does not have final authority over:

subparagraph.text: the adoption of regulations by the Commission; or
the conduct of hearings and the determination of cases by the other members of the Commission.

subsection.text: The Chairman shall conduct hearings unless the hearings interfere with the adequate and efficient performance of the administrative and executive functions of the Chairman.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Commission shall devote full time to the duties of office.
While on the Commission, a member may not:

subparagraph.text: practice law;
hold any political employment under State or federal law; or
hold any other position or engage in any business that interferes or is inconsistent with any duty of office.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Commission is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: the salary provided in the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: The annual salary of a member of the Commission:

subparagraph.text: shall at least equal the salary provided in the State budget for a judge of the district court; and
for the Chairman, shall be at least $1,500 more than the salary of the other members.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection, a member of the Commission may not receive a fee or perquisite for the discharge of any duty of office.
The Chairman of the Commission may employ a staff for the Commission in accordance with the State budget.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the staff is in the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: perform each duty that the Chairman of the Commission assigns; and
keep, at the principal office of the Commission, a public record of:

subparagraph.text: each proceeding of the Commission, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: each claim that the Commission considers; and
each award that the Commission allows to an employee or any person for a service;

subparagraph.text: each document required to be submitted by the Commission or by a regulation of the Commission;
each decision of the Commission; and
each order passed by the Commission.

subsection.text: The Chairman may designate another employee of the Commission to exercise the powers and carry out the duties of the Secretary whenever the Secretary is absent.

section.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: shall have its principal office in Baltimore City; and
may have in the State any branch offices that the Chairman considers necessary to carry out this title.

subsection.text: Except for legal holidays, the Commission shall be in session continuously and open for business during business hours Monday through Friday.
Each session shall be open to the public.
The Commission may adjourn without recording notice of the adjournment in the record of proceedings.
Any member of the Commission may conduct a hearing or other investigation for the Commission.
A decision or order of a member of the Commission shall be considered a decision or order of the Commission.
The Commission may adopt regulations to carry out this title.
To carry out this title, a member of the Commission, the Secretary of the Commission, a special examiner, or an inspector may:

paragraph.text: administer an oath; or
certify to an official act.
