The Commission shall direct payment of an assessment under subsection (a) or (b) of this section into the Fund.
Payments under this section are in addition to the payment of compensation to a covered employee or the dependents of a covered employee under this title.
This section does not apply to an award against the Subsequent Injury Fund.

The Commission shall impose an assessment of 10%, not exceeding $4,500, against compensation awarded or likely to be awarded against an insured or self-insured employer and not paid if the Commission determines that the compensation is not awarded or is abated because of:

paragraph.text: death; or
lack of a covered employee or a dependent of a covered employee eligible for the compensation.

subsection.text: On expiration of the time period within which a claim may be filed under this title, the Commission shall assess the insurer or self-insured employer $4,500 if a covered employee dies:

paragraph.text: due to an accidental personal injury or occupational disease; and
without any surviving dependent.

subsection.text: The Commission shall direct payment of an assessment under subsection (b) or (c) of this section into the Fund.
When the Commission imposes an assessment on an employer under this subtitle, the Commission shall mail the employer notice of the assessment.
An employer shall pay an assessment under this subtitle into the Fund within 10 days after the date that notice of the assessment is mailed to the employer.

If an employer fails to pay an assessment in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, the default constitutes a default in payment of compensation and judgment shall be entered as in a case of default in payment of compensation.

Except for fines collected under § 9-1108 of this title, all money collected from an uninsured employer with respect to any claim for compensation but not payable from the Fund, whether collected before or after entry of a judgment against the employer, shall be:

paragraph.text: first, considered payment of and applied to any compensation or benefits due or security demanded from the employer in connection with the claim; and
second, considered payment of and applied to assessments imposed under this subtitle.

subsection.text: All money recovered from uninsured employers on judgments entered for failure to pay assessments and for failure to pay compensation and benefits that were paid from the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.
An assessment that is payable under this subtitle is a lien against the assets of the employer who is liable for the assessment.
A lien under subsection (a) of this section is subordinate to:

paragraph.text: claims for unpaid wages; and
prior recorded liens.
When the amount of the Fund equals at least $5,000,000, the payment of assessments by employers and insurers is suspended.
The Director shall notify each self-insured employer and insurer of the suspension of the payment of assessments under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
Payment of assessments shall be resumed if:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the Fund becomes less than $3,000,000 because of payments made under § 9-1002 of this subtitle or other payments; or
the Director determines that payments that are likely to be made from the Fund in the next 3 months will reduce the amount of the Fund to less than $3,000,000.

paragraph.text: When payment of assessments is to be resumed under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Director shall notify each self-insured employer and insurer that payment of assessments is to:

subparagraph.text: resume on a specified date; and
continue until the amount of the Fund becomes at least $5,000,000.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, the Director shall notify an employer by certified mail, return receipt requested, that the license or permit of the employer to do business in the State may be suspended if the employer fails to:

subparagraph.text: reimburse the Fund for payment of an award under § 9-1002 of this subtitle; or
pay an assessment under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Director shall send a copy of the notice to each State, county, or municipal unit that has issued a license or permit to the employer for an activity for which workers’ compensation coverage is required by law.
Within 15 days after receipt of the notice, the licensing unit shall provide the employer with the notice and opportunity for a hearing as otherwise may be required by law.
If law requires the licensing unit to hold a hearing, the licensing unit shall send written notice of the hearing date to the Director.
The licensing unit shall suspend the license or permit of the employer if the licensing unit finds that the employer has failed to:

subparagraph.text: reimburse the Fund for payment of an award under § 9-1002 of this subtitle; or
pay an assessment under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A suspension of a license or permit under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall continue until the employer:

subparagraph.text: reimburses the Fund for payment of an award under § 9-1002 of this subtitle;
pays the assessment due to the Fund; or
agrees to reimburse the Fund for payment of an award or to pay the assessment due to the Fund in a manner approved by the Board.

paragraph.text: If the Director considers compromise to be in the best interest of the Fund, the Director may compromise the amount of a judgment against an employer under this subtitle.
A compromise under paragraph (1) is not required to be approved by any other State official to be effective.

subsection.text: A compromise under this section may not reduce the amount of benefits payable to or for a covered employee or the dependents of a covered employee.
A judgment may be modified to reflect a compromise under this section.

section.text: Unless the Director gives written consent, a covered employee or the dependents of the covered employee may not settle a cause of action for an amount less than the amount that the Fund paid to or for the covered employee or dependents.

subsection.text: A jockey who is a covered employee under § 9–212 of this title while performing a service in connection with training or the dependents of the jockey may apply for payment from the Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc. if the employer of the jockey is in default on a claim under § 9–1002(b) of this subtitle.
On receipt of an application for payment, the Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc. shall pay the award.

paragraph.text: If the Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc. makes payment under this section to a covered employee or the dependents of the covered employee as directed by the Commission, the Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc. is subrogated to the rights of the covered employee or dependents against the uninsured employer.
The Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc. may:

subparagraph.text: institute a civil action against the uninsured employer to recover the money paid under the award;
refer the matter to the Maryland Racing Commission for suspension or revocation of the occupational license of the uninsured employer;
refer the matter to the appropriate authority for prosecution under § 9–1108 of this title; or
take action under any combination or all of items (i) through (iii) of this paragraph.

subsection.text: An employer may not deduct any part of the premium that the employer pays for workers’ compensation insurance from the salary or wages of a covered employee.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $200.

section.text: An employer who fails to report an accidental personal injury within the time required under § 9-707(a) of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50.

subsection.text: An employer, superior, union official, member of a union, guild, or similar group, or another person connected with the employment of a covered employee entitled to benefits under this title may not attempt to influence, directly or indirectly, the choice of a lawyer by the covered employee:

paragraph.text: through corruption;
by threat or force; or
for personal gain.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.
An employee of the Commission may not disclose to any person other than a member of the Commission any information that the employee obtains about the business, property, or transactions of another.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction:

paragraph.text: is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 18 months; and
is disqualified from appointment to or employment by the Commission.

subsection.text: An employer may not discharge a covered employee from employment solely because the covered employee files a claim for compensation under this title.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
A person may not knowingly affect or knowingly attempt to affect the payment of compensation, fees, or expenses under this title by means of a fraudulent representation.
A person who violates this section, on conviction:

paragraph.text: is subject to the penalties of § 7-104 of the Criminal Law Article; and
may not receive compensation, fees, or expenses under this title.

subsection.text: An employer who self insures under § 9–405 of this title or participates in a governmental self–insurance group under § 9–404 of this title and fails to apply to the Commission for approval of the self–insurance plan of the employer or governmental self–insurance group in accordance with § 9–403 of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

An employer who is subject to this title and fails to secure payment of compensation in accordance with § 9–402 of this title or fails to pay an award of compensation is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

If the employer is a corporation, the officer of the corporation who has responsibility for the general management of the corporation in the State is subject to the fine and imprisonment specified in subsection (a) or (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: A fine imposed on an employer under this section shall be:

subparagraph.text: paid to the State Treasury and credited to the Commission; and
used to pay, wholly or partly, an award made against the employer by the Commission.

paragraph.text: A disbursement under this subsection shall be made in the same manner as a disbursement of other money of the Commission.
Any part of the fine that is not required to pay an award shall be transferred to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: A court may remit a penalty only if the employer who is in default:

paragraph.text: secures payment of compensation in accordance with § 9–402 of this title; and
pays or secures payment of all compensation and other benefits awarded against the employer under this title.

subsection.text: An employer who fails to secure payment of compensation in accordance with § 9-402 of this title that will be in force on the date a cancellation of a contract of workers’ compensation insurance becomes effective is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

If the employer is a corporation, the officer of the corporation who has responsibility for the general management of the corporation in the State is subject to the fine and imprisonment specified in subsection (a) of this section.
A fine imposed against and collected from an employer under this section shall be paid into the Uninsured Employers’ Fund.

section.text: This title may be cited as the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Maryland Insurance Administration.
“Board” means the Board for the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.
“Commissioner” means the Maryland Insurance Commissioner.
“Fund” means the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.
“Policyholder” means an employer who holds a policy of insurance under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Wage” means all earnings that are due to an employee for employment.
“Wage” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bonus;
overtime pay;
a share of profits; and
if, at the time of hiring, an employer and employee set a dollar value for board or a similar advantage, the advantage.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Maryland Insurance Administration.
“Board” means the Board for the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.
“Commissioner” means the Maryland Insurance Commissioner.
“Company” means the Chesapeake Employers’ Insurance Company established under Title 24, Subtitle 3 of the Insurance Article.
“Fund” means the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.

section.caption: NOT IN EFFECT
section.text: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

paragraph.text: There is an Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.
The Fund is an instrumentality of the State.

subsection.text: On and after October 1, 2013, the Company, and not the Fund, shall serve as the workers’ compensation insurer of last resort for workers’ compensation insurance.
On and after October 1, 2013, the Fund:

paragraph.text: shall continue to exist; but
may not issue new policies or otherwise engage in the business of insurance.

subsection.text: On and after October 1, 2013, the Fund may continue to be the third party administrator for the State’s Self–Insured Workers’ Compensation Program for State Employees under a contract with the State.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (f) of this section, in the operation of the Company, the Company shall utilize employees of the Company.
In the operation of the Fund, the Fund shall utilize employees of the Fund.
The Fund shall:

subparagraph.text: maintain a payroll and human resources system; and
be responsible for paying:

sub-subparagraph.text: the employer portion of any payroll or other taxes and retirement or pension contributions for employees of the Fund; and
for any health or other employee benefits that are available to employees of the Fund.

paragraph.text: Employees of the Fund may be assigned to perform functions of the Company under a contract between the Fund and the Company.
The Company and the Fund shall annually execute an agreement that lists the employees of the Fund who have been assigned to perform duties on behalf of the Company.
The agreement shall:

subparagraph.text: specify the employees who will be utilized by the Company and the Fund;
provide that, except with respect to assets necessary for the Fund to perform its duties under this subtitle, all assets and liabilities of the Fund are the assets and liabilities of the Company; and
be filed with the Administration.

section.caption: NOT IN EFFECT
section.text: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: On and after October 1, 2013:

paragraph.text: the Fund may not hire new employees; and
employees of the Fund:

subparagraph.text: may remain employees of the Fund;
shall continue to be State employees only if they remain employees of the Fund;
may not be required to be employees of the Company;
shall be subject to each law that applied to employees of the Fund immediately before October 1, 2013;
shall be subject to the same terms and conditions of employment as existed immediately before October 1, 2013, including benefits, leave, and pay grade;
shall remain in the State retirement system only if they remain employees of the Fund;
except for changes in benefits or compensation applicable to State employees generally, may not be denied any compensation or benefit provided to employees of the Fund as of October 1, 2013;
may not be denied a promotion, based on the employee’s status as an employee of the Fund; and
subject to subsection (b) of this section, may elect to be an employee of the Company.

subsection.text: If an employee of the Fund intends to elect to be an employee of the Company under subsection (a)(2)(ix) of this section, the Company shall:

paragraph.text: require the employee to make the election in writing; and
provide the employee with information that:

subparagraph.text: states that the election of the employee to become an employee of the Company is voluntary and irrevocable; and
fully discloses the terms of employment with the Company.

subsection.text: An employee of the Company may not elect to be an employee of the Fund.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: There is an Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2013 **

subsection.text: The Fund is independent of all State units.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection and elsewhere in this subtitle, the Fund is not subject to any law, including § 6–106 of the State Government Article, that affects governmental units.
The Fund is subject to:

subparagraph.text: Title 10, Subtitle 6, Part III of the State Government Article;
Title 12 of the State Government Article;
the Maryland Public Ethics Law; and
Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not affect the exemption from property tax under § 7–210 of the Tax – Property Article.

subsection.text: Except for Title 3, Subtitle 1, Title 8, Subtitle 3, and Title 11 of the Insurance Article and as otherwise provided by law, the Fund is subject to the Insurance Article to the same extent as an authorized domestic workers’ compensation insurer.

Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the Fund shall register with the Commissioner and be subject to the provisions of Title 8, Subtitle 3 of the Insurance Article if the Fund operates as an administrator, as defined in § 8–301 of the Insurance Article.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

paragraph.text: There is a Board for the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.
The Board shall manage the business and affairs of the Fund as an instrumentality of the State in accordance with State law.

subsection.text: The Board is the Board for the Company established under Title 24, Subtitle 3 of the Insurance Article.
Members of the Board that were appointed to the Board as of October 1, 2012, shall:

paragraph.text: continue to serve their current terms on the Board; and
serve on the Board for the Company under the same terms and conditions as if they were appointed to the Board for the Company under Title 24, Subtitle 3 of the Insurance Article.

subsection.text: The Board:

paragraph.text: shall be subject to the rules, bylaws, and procedures that the Board for the Company adopts under Title 24, Subtitle 3 of the Insurance Article; and
may adopt any policy to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Fund shall operate in a manner similar to an authorized domestic workers’ compensation insurer.
The Fund shall:

paragraph.text: serve as a competitive insurer in the marketplace;
guarantee the availability of workers’ compensation insurance in the State;
serve as the workers’ compensation insurer of last resort; and
engage only in the business of workers’ compensation insurance in accordance with State law.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

paragraph.text: The Board shall appoint a President of the Fund.
The President of the Fund shall be the President of the Company.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, employees of the Fund are special appointments.

A classified employee of the Fund hired before July 1, 1990 in a nonprofessional or nontechnical position shall remain a member of the classified service or its equivalent in the State Personnel Management System as long as the employee remains in a nonprofessional or nontechnical position with the Fund.
The Board shall set compensation for its employees.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an employee of the Fund is not subject to any law, regulation, or executive order governing State employee compensation, including furloughs, salary reductions, or any other General Fund cost savings measure.
This subsection does not apply to the layoff of an employee because of lack of work.
An employee of the Fund may not be permanently removed unless:

subparagraph.text: written charges are filed;
the employee has an opportunity for a hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article; and
there is cause for removal.

subsection.text: The Fund is independent of all State units.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection and elsewhere in this subtitle, the Fund is not subject to any law, including § 6–106 of the State Government Article, that affects governmental units.
The Fund is subject to:

subparagraph.text: Title 10, Subtitle 6, Part III of the State Government Article;
Title 12 of the State Government Article;
the Maryland Public Ethics Law; and
Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not affect the exemption from property tax under § 7–210 of the Tax – Property Article.

subsection.text: The Fund is a member of the Property and Casualty Insurance Guaranty Corporation.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **
section.text: Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, the Fund shall remain in existence until it:

paragraph.text: no longer has any employees; and
is terminated by the repeal of this subtitle.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: The State has no interest in the assets of the Fund.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**
There is a Board for the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Board consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years.

At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve for more than:

subparagraph.text: two full terms; or
a total of 10 years.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a secretary.
The manner of election of officers shall be as the Board determines.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Board may not act on any matter unless at least 5 members concur.
Each member of the Board shall devote the time needed to carry out the duties of office.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Board is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: the salary provided in the budget of the Board; and
reimbursement for reasonable expenses:

sub-subparagraph.text: incurred in the performance of the Board member’s duties; and
as provided in the budget of the Board.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Board shall be paid biweekly.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Board:

paragraph.text: shall appoint a President of the Fund;
shall appoint or employ attorneys to advise and represent the Fund in all legal matters and, where necessary, to sue or defend suits in the name of the Fund; and
may employ other staff.

The Board shall set compensation for its employees.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an employee of the Fund is not subject to any law, regulation, or executive order governing State employee compensation, including furloughs, salary reductions, or any other General Fund cost savings measure.
This subsection does not apply to the layoff of an employee because of lack of work.
An employee of the Fund may not be permanently removed unless:

subparagraph.text: written charges are filed;
the employee has an opportunity for a hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article; and
there is cause for removal.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Board may adopt any policy to carry out this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Board shall have a plan to promote the services of the Fund to employers in the State.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**
The Board:

paragraph.text: shall use the Fund to insure employers against liability under Title 9 of this article; and
may use the Fund:

subparagraph.text: to provide employer’s liability insurance; and
on behalf of a policyholder, to pay benefits equal to benefits allowed under:

sub-subparagraph.text: a compensation law of another state; or
a federal compensation law.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Fund shall consist of:

paragraph.text: premiums for insurance that the Fund issues;
income from investments under § 10–122 of this subtitle;
interests on deposits or investments of money from the Fund; and
the money that is collected under § 10–133(b) of this subtitle on debts.

subsection.text: The Fund shall include each security or other property that is acquired with money of the Fund.
The Board shall use the Fund to pay all of the expenses under this subtitle, including losses on insurance that the Fund issues.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Board shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Board shall prepare capital and operating budgets for the Fund.
For information only, the Board shall submit the budgets to the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and the House Appropriations Committee.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue receipts for money that the Fund receives.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**
The Board shall keep reserves and surplus in accordance with the Insurance Article.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: Consistent with minority business purchasing standards applicable to units of State government under the State Finance and Procurement Article and consistent with the fiduciary duties of the Board, the Board shall attempt to use to the greatest extent feasible minority business enterprises to provide brokerage and investment management services to the Board.
For purposes of this section, brokerage and investment management services shall include services relating to all allocated asset classes.

paragraph.text: To assist it in achieving the goal described under subsection (a) of this section, the Board shall undertake measures to remove any barriers that limit full participation by minority business enterprises in brokerage and investment management services opportunities afforded by the Fund.

The measures undertaken by the Board shall include the use of a wide variety of media, including the Board’s website, to provide notice to a broad and varied range of potential providers about the brokerage and investment management services opportunities afforded by the Fund.

subsection.text: In conjunction with the Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs, the Board shall develop guidelines to assist it in identifying and evaluating qualified minority business enterprises in order to help the Fund achieve the objective for greater use of minority business enterprises for brokerage and investment management services.
On or before September 1 each year, the Board shall submit a report to the Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on:

paragraph.text: the identity of the minority business enterprise brokerage and investment management services firms used by the Board in the immediately preceding fiscal year;

the percentage and dollar value of the Fund assets that are under the investment control of minority business enterprise brokerage and investment management services firms in each allocated asset class; and
the measures the Board undertook in the immediately preceding fiscal year in accordance with subsection (c)(2) of this section.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Fund shall be examined by the Commissioner in accordance with Title 2, Subtitle 2 (Enforcement) of the Insurance Article.

As part of an examination under § 2–205 of the Insurance Article, the Commissioner shall, at least once every 5 years, determine whether the Fund’s rate making practices produce actuarially sound rates.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: Within 90 days after the close of each fiscal year, the Board shall submit to the Governor an annual report that includes a detailed statement of:

paragraph.text: the condition and expenses of the Fund in detail;
growth of the Fund;
changes in earned premiums of the Fund;
changes in the number of policyholders of the Fund;
the degree of the Fund’s personnel flexibility;
trends in the overall market share; and
trends in the premium to expense ratio.
On or before October 1 of each year, the Fund shall submit to the Governor:

subparagraph.text: a copy of each policy form that the Fund will use during the next calendar year;
the schedule of premium rates that the Fund will charge for the next calendar year;
information about provision for claim payment, as defined in § 11–330(a) of the Insurance Article, for each class for which the Fund writes coverage; and
other information that the Governor requests about premium rates, including classes, financial information, and losses.
Information required under paragraph (1)(ii) through (iv) of this subsection shall be submitted on the form that the Governor requires.
The form shall conform as closely as possible to the form that a rating organization uses to comply with §§ 11–307, 11–329, and 11–330 of the Insurance Article.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The State has no interest in the assets of the Fund.
All revenues, money, and assets of the Fund belong solely to the Fund and are held by the Fund in trust for the policyholders, injured workers and their families, and creditors of the Fund.
The State may not borrow, appropriate, or direct payments from the revenues, money, or assets of the Fund for any purpose.
The Fund may not be dissolved.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt a schedule of premium rates in accordance with sound actuarial practices and shall ensure that the rates are not excessive, inadequate, or unfairly discriminatory.
The Commissioner shall review the Fund’s rates as part of an examination under § 2–205 of the Insurance Article to determine whether the Fund’s rate making practices produce actuarially sound rates.

paragraph.text: The Board shall determine the schedule by:

subparagraph.text: classifying all of the policyholders on the basis of the respective level of hazard of their enterprises; and
setting a premium rate for each class on the basis of:

sub-subparagraph.text: its level of hazard; and
incentives to prevent injuries to employees.

paragraph.text: To determine the schedule, the Board shall use the rating system that, in the opinion of the Board:

subparagraph.text: most accurately measures the level of hazard for each policyholder on the basis of the number of injuries that occur in the enterprises of the policyholder;
encourages the prevention of injuries; and
ensures the solvency of the Fund from year to year.

paragraph.text: The Board may set minimum premium rates.
The Board shall state premium rates as a percentage of the gross annual wages of employees to whom Title 9 of this article applies.
For employees who work partly in and partly outside the State, the premium shall be based on wages for employment in the State.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the schedule of premium rates in effect at the beginning of a calendar year remains in effect for the year.

The Board shall adjust classes and rates as often as the Board determines to be just and advantageous to meet the criteria under subsection (c)(2) of this section and to reflect changes in levels of hazards.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**
An employer shall apply for insurance under this subtitle in accordance with the policies of the Board.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

Each employer who applies and is eligible for insurance under this subtitle shall be assigned, after consideration of the number of employees and the relative hazards of the various types of work performed in the enterprise of the employer:

paragraph.text: to the class that includes the work; or
if more than 1 class clearly applies to the work, to each applicable class.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt policies that provide procedures and standards for the payment of premiums.

paragraph.text: In accordance with § 19–406 of the Insurance Article, the Fund may:

subparagraph.text: cancel the insurance of a policyholder who fails to pay a premium due to the Fund; and
pursue collection of the debt of any policyholder whose insurance is being canceled under this paragraph.

paragraph.text: If the Fund considers settlement to be in the best interest of the Fund, a debt may be settled.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**
The Board shall issue a certificate of insurance.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: The Board may:

paragraph.text: adopt requirements for uniform payroll; and
require each policyholder to conform to the requirements.

subsection.text: In accordance with the requirements that the Board adopts, each policyholder shall submit a report on wages or other documentation to the Board at intervals that the Board sets.
The Board or its authorized employee or agent may inspect at any time the payroll of a policyholder.
In accordance with § 19–406 of the Insurance Article, the Fund may cancel the insurance of a policyholder who:

paragraph.text: fails to comply with subsection (b) of this section; or
refuses to allow an inspection authorized under subsection (c) of this section.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**
A policyholder may cancel a policy under this subtitle, if the policyholder:

paragraph.text: gives the Fund written notice; and
promptly pays all premiums owed to the Fund.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**
If the Board considers an account to be uncollectible, the account may be charged from the books of the Fund.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the President of the Fund may settle a claim that the Fund has against a governmental unit or person who is alleged to be liable for an accident for which the Fund pays compensation.
The President may settle a claim under this section only if:

paragraph.text: the Workers’ Compensation Commission consents; and
for a settlement that will prejudice any right of an injured employee, the employee consents.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012**

subsection.text: An employer may not with fraudulent intent misrepresent to the Board the wages on which a premium under this subtitle is based.
A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Subsequent Injury Fund Board.
“Fund” means the Subsequent Injury Fund.

section.text: There is a Subsequent Injury Fund.
There is a Subsequent Injury Fund Board.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 3 members, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the 3 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall represent labor;
1 shall represent management; and
1 shall represent the general public.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
Subject to the State budget, each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation for each day that the member is engaged in duties of the office; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The Fund shall have a staff in accordance with the State budget.

paragraph.text: The Board shall appoint a Director for the Fund.
The Director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Attorney General is the legal adviser to the Board and Fund.
With the approval of the Board, staff whom the Attorney General assigns to represent the Fund may hire each expert who is needed to defend an action into which the Fund is impleaded.
The Fund shall consist of:

paragraph.text: the money credited to the Fund under Title 9 of this article;
income from investments that the State Treasurer makes for the Fund;
interest on deposits or investments of money from the Fund;
money that the Fund acquires by gift; and
money that the federal government pays as reimbursement for a payment from the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall include each security that the Fund acquires.
The Fund shall be used to pay:

paragraph.text: each award under Title 9 of this article charged against the Fund; and
other expenses authorized in the State budget.

section.text: The State Treasurer shall keep the Fund as a special indemnity fund.

subsection.text: The Board shall supervise the administration of the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund annually shall submit to the Governor a proposed budget for the Fund, for inclusion in the budget bill to be submitted to the General Assembly.
The proposed budget shall include an appropriation from the Fund for its budget.

section.text: If sale of a security in which money of the Fund is invested is in the best interest of the Fund, the State Treasurer shall sell the security.

subsection.text: Disbursement from the Fund for paying benefits to claimants or dependents shall be made by the Treasurer only on written order of the Workers’ Compensation Commission.
Disbursement from the Fund for any purpose other than paying benefits shall be made by the Treasurer only at the direction of the Director for the Fund under authority of the Board.

paragraph.text: As often as the Board requests but at least quarterly, the State Treasurer shall advise the Board about the amount of the Fund in the custody of the State Treasurer.
The State Treasurer annually shall submit to the Board a statement that, for the preceding calendar year:

subparagraph.text: states the balance on January 1;
states the income and each source of income;
itemizes each payment; and
states the balance on December 31.

subsection.text: On or before October 1 of each year, the Board shall submit to the Governor an annual report that includes a detailed statement of the balances and expenses of the Fund.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Uninsured Employers’ Fund Board.
“Fund” means the Uninsured Employers’ Fund.

section.text: There is an Uninsured Employers’ Fund.
There is an Uninsured Employers’ Fund Board.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 3 members, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the 3 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall represent labor;
1 shall represent management; and
1 shall represent the general public.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
Subject to the State budget, each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation for each day that the member is engaged in duties of the office; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: appoint a Director for the Fund; and
review the Director’s administration of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Director:

paragraph.text: shall have immediate supervision and direction over the administration of the Fund;
may employ staff in accordance with the State budget; and
shall serve as the appointing authority for all staff.

subsection.text: An employee may appeal a disciplinary action taken by the Director to the Board.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General is the legal adviser to the Director and Fund.
The Attorney General may represent the Fund in any case that does not involve the rights of the Fund against another individual who:

subparagraph.text: is in the same employ as the employee who received benefits under Title 9 of this article; and
caused the injury or death of the employee.

subsection.text: Staff whom the Attorney General assigns to represent the Fund may not represent another party in a claim under Title 9 of this article.

Staff whom the Attorney General assigns to represent the Fund may apply to the Director for authority to hire and, within an amount that the Director sets, to pay each expert or witness who is needed to defend a claim properly.
The Director shall assign to help the staff of the Attorney General each employee of the Fund who is needed to represent the Fund.

section.text: The Director may adopt any reasonable regulation to process and pay an award charged against the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall consist of:

paragraph.text: the money credited to the Fund under Title 9 of this article;
income from investments that the State Treasurer makes for the Fund; and
interest on deposits or investments of money from the Fund.

subsection.text: The Director shall use the Fund to pay:

paragraph.text: each award under Title 9 of this article charged against the Fund;
the amount that the Director authorizes for an expert or witness hired under § 10–310(c) of this subtitle;
other proper charges that the Director authorizes; and
whenever an employer who is self–insured in accordance with § 9–404 or § 9–405 of this article becomes insolvent, any outstanding obligations of the employer.

subsection.text: The liability of the Board, Director, Fund, State Treasurer, and State for all proper charges against the Fund is limited to the assets of the Fund.
The State Treasurer is custodian of the Fund.
The State Treasurer shall keep the Fund separate from State money.
The Director shall supervise the administration of the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund annually shall submit to the Governor a proposed budget for the Fund, for inclusion in the budget bill to be submitted to the General Assembly.
The proposed budget shall include an appropriation from the Fund for its budget.

section.text: The Board may establish reserves to meet potential losses of the Fund.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall invest surplus money of the Fund in any security in which a savings bank may invest under State law.
If the State Treasurer invests in a certificate of deposit, it shall:

subparagraph.text: be interest bearing;
be issued by:

sub-subparagraph.text: a bank located and authorized to do business in the State;
a national banking association located in the State; or
a trust company located and authorized to do business in the State; and

subparagraph.text: be secured in full by a pledge of a direct obligation of the State or United States.

subsection.text: If sale of a security in which money of the Fund is invested is in the best interest of the Fund, the State Treasurer may sell the security.

section.text: The State Treasurer shall disburse money from the Fund only on a voucher that is signed by the Director for the Fund.

subsection.text: The State Treasurer annually shall submit to the Director for the Fund a statement that:

paragraph.text: for the fiscal year for which the statement is made:

subparagraph.text: states the balance of the Fund on the last day of the year;
states the income of the Fund; and
summarizes the payments from the Fund; and

paragraph.text: states the balance of the Fund on the last day of the preceding fiscal year.

subsection.text: On or before October 1 of each year, the Board shall submit to the Governor an annual report that includes a detailed statement of the balances and expenses of the Fund.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
There is a Division of Workforce Development and Adult Learning within the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
The Division has the powers, duties, responsibilities, and functions provided in the laws of this State.
The Division has the general purpose of advancing the economic welfare of the people by coordinating the State’s public and private resources for adult learning, employment, and job training.
The Division shall:

paragraph.text: promote apprenticeship and training programs;
administer job training, placement, and service programs;
implement the provisions of the Workforce Investment Act;
administer adult education and literacy services programs;
conduct educational and job skills training programs in adult correctional facilities;
oversee any other units established pursuant to State or federal employment, training, or manpower statutes; and
administer those programs assigned to the Division by law or designated by the Secretary.

subsection.text: The Division shall meet and confer on a regular basis with representatives of the State’s community colleges, appointed by the Maryland Association of Community Colleges, and the adult education community, appointed by the Maryland Association for Adult Continuing and Community Education, to assure that adult education and literacy services and job training activities and resources are effectively coordinated.

section.text: For the purpose of establishing compensation rates and basic rates for vacation and sick leave credit earnings, professional personnel who were employed by a county school system or the public library system in the State and who are subsequently appointed to positions in the Department to provide services in accordance with Subtitles 8 and 9 of this title shall be given credit as employees of the Department for their years of service as employees of the county school system or the public library system from which they transferred.

subsection.text: The Department shall establish a program for the retraining and placement of hospital employees who are unemployed or who may become unemployed as a result of the closing, delicensing, downsizing, or possible downsizing of a hospital or the merging of hospitals under § 19-325 of the Health - General Article.
The Secretary and the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene shall adopt regulations to implement this section.
There is a Hospital Employees Retraining Fund. The Fund shall be used:

paragraph.text: for the purposes described in this section; and
to pay any and all expenses of the Department in administering this section.

subsection.text: Any unexpended funds remaining in the Hospital Employees Retraining Fund at the end of the fiscal year may not revert to the General Fund of the State.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Employer” means any person, corporation, or other entity that employs at least 50 individuals and operates an industrial, commercial, or business enterprise in the State.
“Employer” does not include the State or its political subdivisions or any employer who has been doing business in the State less than 1 year.

subsection.text: “Reduction in operations” includes:

paragraph.text: the relocation of a part of an employer's operation from 1 workplace to another existing or proposed site; or

the shutting down of a workplace or a portion of the operations of a workplace that reduces the number of employees by at least 25 percent or 15 employees, whichever is greater, over any 3-month period.
“Workplace” includes a factory, plant, office or other facility where employees produce goods or provide services.
“Workplace” does not include a construction site or other temporary workplace.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to reductions in operations if the reduction:

paragraph.text: results solely from labor disputes;
occurs in a commercial, industrial, or agricultural enterprise operated by this State or its political subdivisions;
occurs at construction sites or other temporary workplaces;
results from seasonal factors that are determined by the Department to be customary in the industry; or
results when an employer files for bankruptcy under federal bankruptcy laws.

section.text: There shall be a quick response program to provide both employers and employees with services to assist in mitigating the impact on employees that occurs with a reduction in operations.

subsection.text: The State’s quick response program is under the direction of the Secretary.
The Secretary in cooperation with the Workforce Investment Board shall develop voluntary guidelines for employers faced with a reduction in operations. These guidelines shall include:

paragraph.text: the appropriate length of time for advance notification to employees that an employer expects to terminate due to a reduction in operations. Whenever possible and appropriate, at least 90 days notice shall be given;
the appropriate continuation of benefits, such as health, severance, and pension, that an employer should provide to employees who will be terminated due to a reduction in operations; or
the specific mechanisms that employers can utilize to ask for the assistance of the State’s quick response program.

subsection.text: The Department shall maintain the capacity to provide employment and training services through the quick response program. This capacity shall include, but not be limited to:

paragraph.text: on–site unemployment insurance bulk claims registration: for incidents where 25 or more workers are laid off at 1 time, taking initial unemployment insurance claims at the employee’s place of business;

registration for federal Trade Readjustment Act services: if the business closing is due to foreign competition, assisting workers in seeking federal training benefits and additional unemployment insurance compensation benefits;

provision of labor market and retraining information: in conjunction with local service providers, providing both local labor market information and retraining information that can assist the workers to obtain reemployment and/or retraining;
job placement services: through the regular office services or through special on–site services, providing a range of job placement services utilizing the “job bank”;
job seeking and finding information: providing 1–day workshops to assist job seekers in learning how to seek and secure jobs; or

referral to retraining opportunities: through liaisons with the private industry councils/service delivery areas and the community college network, providing referrals for dislocated workers for retraining opportunities.

subsection.text: The Department shall distribute the reduction in operations guidelines to all employers in the State every 2 years. The distribution shall begin no later than July 1, 1986.

The Department shall monitor layoff and employment patterns and payments of unemployment compensation contributions to identify employers that are likely to experience large losses in employment or a reduction in operations.

If the Department identifies an employer that is likely to experience large losses in employment or a reduction in operations, the Department shall confidentially contact the employer and offer the assistance of the Department in providing alternative employment and retraining opportunities, including coordinating the delivery of available State and federal resources and services.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to implement the provisions of this subtitle.

section.text: The intent, purposes and objectives of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: encourage the development of an apprenticeship and training system through the voluntary cooperation of management, labor, and interested State agencies in cooperation with other states and the federal government;
provide for the establishment and furtherance of standards of apprenticeship and training to safeguard the welfare of apprentices and trainees;

contribute to a healthy economy by aiding in the development and maintenance of a skilled labor force sufficient in numbers and quality to meet the expanding needs of Maryland industry and to attract new industry;
open to young people the opportunity to obtain training in skilled trades and other on-the-job occupations which will equip them for profitable employment and citizenship;
establish an apprenticeship and training council and authorize the appointment of a Director;
set up a program of planned apprenticeship under registered agreements, meeting standards established by the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training, U.S. Department of Labor;
promote employment opportunities for young people under conditions providing adequate training and reasonable earnings; and
subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, provide for periodic reports to the Governor, the General Assembly, and the public regarding the status of apprenticeship training in this State.

section.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, provisions of this subtitle creating the Apprenticeship and Training Council and related to the regulation of apprentices and trainees are of no effect after July 1, 2014.

paragraph.text: There is an Apprenticeship and Training Council as part of the Division of Labor and Industry. The Council consists of 12 members all of whom shall be appointed by the Governor of Maryland, with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate of Maryland.
Four of the members shall be representatives of employee organizations; one shall be an employee; five shall be representatives of employers and two shall be appointed from the general public.

The membership of the Council shall include representation by black and female persons and individuals with disabilities. Consultants to the Council shall include representation by black and female persons and individuals with disabilities.
In advising the Governor, the Secretary shall give consideration to a balanced geographic representation from all of Maryland and a representative sampling and mix of Maryland industry.

One member shall be appointed as Chairman by the Governor, with the advice of the Secretary, and serve as Chairman at the pleasure of the Governor. The Assistant State Superintendent, Career and Technology Education, and the Maryland State Director of the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training, U.S. Department of Labor, shall serve as consultants to the Council without vote.
The Governor, with the advice of the Secretary may appoint up to three additional consultants to the Council from the public at large.

subsection.text: All appointments as members of the Council shall be for terms of 4 years.

section.text: The members of the Council shall receive per diem compensation as provided in the State budget for each day actually engaged in the discharge of their official duties as well as reimbursement for expenses in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations. The Director of Apprenticeship and Training shall act as secretary.

subsection.text: The duties of the Council shall be to:

paragraph.text: determine the apprenticeability of trades in the State of Maryland;
encourage the establishment of local apprenticeship committees where such committees are needed and approve their programs;

formulate and adopt standards of apprenticeship which safeguard the welfare of apprentices, being guided, but not controlled, by the standards of apprenticeship recommended by the federal committee on apprenticeship and provide guidance and counsel on the establishment of other forms of on-the-job training;
formulate policies for the overall apprenticeship program;
register standards of apprenticeship of such groups or employers as elect to conform with the provisions of this subtitle;
register apprenticeship agreements which conform to the standards of apprenticeship adopted by the Council;
issue certificates of completion of apprenticeship to apprentices who are registered with the Council when such apprentices have completed successfully their apprenticeship;
seek all information pertaining to apprenticeship training in the State;
prescribe its rules of procedure and duties of the Chairman, Director, and Secretary subject to the provisions of this law; and
perform such other functions as the Governor or the Secretary may direct or as may come within the scope of the Council.

No person, firm, or corporation may offer, establish, maintain, or operate an apprenticeship or on-the-job training program for any occupation recognized as an apprenticeable occupation by the Council for which tuition, charges, or fees are charged to or are payable by an enrollee or student, or which is financed in whole or in part by State funds, unless the program is first approved by the Council.

The Council shall issue a certificate of approval to an applicant operating or proposing to operate the program if it is satisfied that the conditions of entrance, the qualifications of the administrators and instructors, the content of the program, the facilities, and the financial aspects of the program are adequate and appropriate for the purpose of the program.
The Council, after notice and hearing, may suspend or revoke its approval of a program or course if it finds that the program or course has ceased to meet the conditions of approval.

Any person, firm, or corporation whose application for approval is rejected or whose certificate of approval is suspended or revoked has a right of judicial review as provided in the Administrative Procedure Act.

Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Council, after notice and hearing, may adopt rules and regulations for the implementation of this section, including, but not limited to, rules and regulations requiring the furnishing of periodic relevant information about approved and proposed programs and the operator or proposed operator thereof.

Any person, firm, or corporation that knowingly offers, establishes, maintains, or operates a program in violation of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than $1,000 or be imprisoned for not more than one year, or both.
The Council, in addition, shall apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction restraining violations of this section.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the Council may not deny any otherwise qualified application where apprentices constitute a number equal to or less than 25 percent of the total number of apprentices and journeymen employed.

For the purpose of equal opportunity employment, the Council may not deny any otherwise qualified application where apprentices constitute a number equal to or less than 50 percent of the total number of apprentices and journeymen employed.

subsection.text: The Council may negotiate and adopt agreements permitting reciprocity with apprenticeship and training councils of another state, or the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training.

section.text: The Secretary shall appoint a Director of Apprenticeship and Training. The Director of Apprenticeship and Training shall have the responsibility of promoting apprenticeship and other forms of on-the-job training and shall obtain the assistance of the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training, U.S. Department of Labor, and other federal and State agencies in this function. The Director’s duties shall include, but shall not be limited to:

paragraph.text: encouragement and promotion of the standards established in accordance with this subtitle and with the basic standards of the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training, U.S. Department of Labor;
bringing about the settlement of differences arising out of apprenticeship programs and agreements when the differences cannot be adjusted locally or in accordance with established trade procedure;
supervision of the execution of agreements and the maintenance of standards;
registration of apprenticeship programs and agreements;
keeping a record of apprenticeship agreements and programs, and upon performance thereunder issuing certificates of completion of apprenticeship;
encouragement of liaison and cooperation between all private, State, and federal agencies concerned with apprenticeship, trade, and industrial training;
promotion of public awareness of apprenticeship and other occupational training; and
keeping a record of the progress of apprenticeship and training programs initiated in accordance with the provisions of this subtitle and informing the Council periodically as to the results.

section.text: All apprenticeship and training programs established under this subtitle shall conform to the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 29, Part 30, and any subsequent applicable provisions. In order to effectuate conformity with these provisions, a State plan shall be drafted which will indicate in detail evidence of consistency in the operation of the Maryland apprenticeship and training law with the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 29, Part 30.

In order to assure compliance with federal laws governing wages, hours, and working conditions, the Maryland Apprenticeship and Training Council will request recognition of its standards and activities by the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training, U.S. Department of Labor, and if necessary, make such adjustments in its standards and procedures as will assure conformity.
This subtitle may be referred to as the “Maryland Workforce Investment Act”.

subsection.text: It is State policy to coordinate all the resources available from federal, State and local governments, business, labor, and community based organizations to foster and promote a balanced, equitable, and cost–effective employment and training system. To effectuate this policy there shall be consultation between the Governor and the General Assembly in implementing the federal Workforce Investment Act and this subtitle.
It is the State’s goal to assist its citizens in obtaining gainful employment and in reducing dependence on public assistance and unemployment insurance programs by:

paragraph.text: preparing unskilled youth and adults who are economically disadvantaged for entry into the work force;
retraining those who have lost jobs or who must upgrade or replace their work skills or both; and
providing training and related services, including supportive services for low–income individuals, to increase the employability of those who encounter barriers to employment.

subsection.text: It is also the State’s goal to develop a well trained productive work force which meets the needs of a changing economy by:

paragraph.text: developing and ensuring maximum utilization of timely statewide labor market information;
linking employment and training services with economic development efforts;
providing enhanced employment and training capabilities specially designed to meet the needs of business and industry, including industries that utilize advanced technology applications; and
encouraging and initiating innovative employment and training strategies.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the definitions set forth in § 101 of the federal Act shall apply; definitions set forth below shall have the meanings indicated.
“Dislocated worker” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: is unlikely to return to a previous industry or occupation and:

subparagraph.text: has been terminated or laid off or has received a notice of termination or layoff from employment;
is eligible for or has exhausted entitlement to unemployment compensation; or

has been employed for a duration sufficient to demonstrate, to the appropriate entity at a one–stop center referred to in § 134(c) of the federal Act, attachment to the workforce, but is not eligible for unemployment compensation due to insufficient earnings or having performed services for an employer that were not covered under State unemployment compensation law;

paragraph.text: has been terminated or laid off, or has received a notice of termination or layoff, from employment as a result of any permanent closure of, or any substantial layoff at, a plant, facility, or enterprise;
is employed at a facility at which the employer has made a general announcement that the facility will close within 180 days;

for purposes of eligibility to receive services other than training services described in § 134(d)(4) of the federal Act, intensive services described in § 134(d)(4) of the federal Act, or supportive services, is employed at a facility at which the employer has made a general announcement that the facility will close;

was self–employed (including employment as a farmer, a rancher, or a fisherman) but is unemployed as a result of general economic conditions in the community in which the individual resides or because of natural disasters; or
is a displaced homemaker.

subsection.text: “Federal Act” means the federal Workforce Investment Act.
“Governor’s plan” means the State plan as provided in § 112 of the federal Act.
“Individual with a disability” means any individual who has a physical or mental disability which for the individual constitutes or results in a substantial handicap to employment.

“Local plan” means the comprehensive 5–year local plan required for each local workforce investment area as provided in § 118 of the federal Act and any final plan or modification as provided in the federal Act.
“Low–income individual” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: receives, or is a member of a family which receives, cash welfare payments under a federal, State, or local income–based public assistance program;

received an income, or is a member of a family that received a total family income for the 6–month period prior to application for the program involved (exclusive of unemployment compensation, child support payments, payments described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, and old age and survivors insurance benefits received under Section 202 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. § 402)) that, in relation to family size, does not exceed the higher of:

subparagraph.text: the poverty level for an equivalent period; or
70 percent of the lower living standard income level for an equivalent period;

paragraph.text: is a member of a household that receives food stamps or has been determined within the 6–month period prior to application for the program involved to be eligible to receive food stamps pursuant to the Food Stamp Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. § 2011 et seq.);
is a foster child on behalf of whom State or local government payments are made;

in cases permitted by regulations promulgated by the Secretary, is an adult individual with a disability whose own income meets the requirements of a program described in paragraph (1) or (2) of this subsection, but who is a member of a family whose income does not meet such requirements; or
qualifies as a homeless individual, as defined in subsections (a) and (c) of § 103 of the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act (42 U.S.C. § 11302).

subsection.text: “Participant” means an individual who has been determined eligible to participate in and who is receiving services (except follow–up services authorized under this title) under a program authorized under this title.
“Performance standards” means the basic measures of performance for training programs to be prescribed by the Secretary and such variations of the standards as the Governor may prescribe.
“Secretary” means the United States Secretary of Labor.
“State Workforce Investment Board” means the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board, as provided in § 111 of the federal Act.

“Supportive services” means services such as transportation, child care, dependent care, housing, and needs–related payments that are necessary to enable an individual to participate in activities authorized under the federal Act, consistent with the federal Act.
“Training organization” means an entity that provides training and employment services to individuals described in § 11–504(b) of this subtitle.
“Workforce investment area” means a geographic area designated by the Governor in accordance with § 116 of the federal Act.
A workforce investment training program is established to implement the federal Act.

paragraph.text: This program shall provide employment, training, supportive and related services for unemployed individuals who are low income, for dislocated workers, and for those who are not low income, but who qualify under the federal Act as having barriers to employment, including, but not limited to, displaced homemakers, school dropouts, teenage parents, individuals with disabilities, older workers, veterans, and other participants as defined by the federal Act.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (iv) of this paragraph, the State Department of Transportation shall issue to training organizations weekly transit passes, in the form of magnetic passes or loaded smart cards, for local bus, light rail, or metro subway service provided by the Maryland Transit Administration.

The training organizations shall provide the weekly transit passes issued under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph to individuals receiving employment and training services under the program established in accordance with subsection (a) of this section.
A training organization shall reimburse the Department of Transportation for the cost of transit passes provided to the training organization under this paragraph.

To be eligible to receive transit passes under this paragraph, a training organization shall include in its contract with the local workforce investment board or local workforce investment agency a provision requiring reimbursement of the training organization for its costs under subparagraph (iii) of this paragraph.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners of Carroll County may appropriate funds necessary to enter into contracts with private or public enterprises for the training or retraining of workers of those enterprises.
The Governor’s Workforce Investment Board is established and shall have the membership as provided in § 111 of the federal Act and U.S. Department of Labor regulations.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (a) of this section, the members of the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall be appointed by the Governor for staggered terms set by the Governor by executive order.
To the extent practicable, the composition of the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall reflect the race, gender, and geographic diversity of the population of the State.

subsection.text: The Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall be funded consistent with §§ 111 and 128 of the federal Act and shall have personnel and appropriations as are provided in the State budget.

The Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall perform the duties and functions identified in § 111 of the federal Act and other functions designated by the Governor as necessary to improve the quality of the State’s workforce.
The Governor’s Workforce Investment Board may adopt any rule or regulations necessary to carry out its powers and duties.

As soon after January 1 of each year as reasonably possible, the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall submit an annual report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall establish an advisory committee to:

subparagraph.text: identify the workforce needs and the education and training requirements of employment fields with available or growing opportunities;
identify the workforce and education and training needs of regions of the State that have high levels of unemployment;
examine the use of individual educational training accounts by other states that assist state residents in paying for education and training programs;
make recommendations regarding an individual educational training account pilot program; and
recommend a pathways for academic career and employment program to provide grants to community colleges for the development of projects in coordination with:

sub-subparagraph.text: institutions of postsecondary education located in the State;
the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the Department of Business and Economic Development; and
the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board.

paragraph.text: The advisory committee shall include representatives from:

subparagraph.text: the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board;
institutions of postsecondary education located in the State, including community colleges and private career schools;
the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the Department of Business and Economic Development;
businesses and industries located in the State, including at least one representative from the biotechnology industry; and
labor organizations located in the State.

paragraph.text: The Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall provide staff for the advisory committee.

subsection.text: On or before June 1 of each year, the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board shall submit a report on its findings and recommendations to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the Senate Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee and the House Committee on Ways and Means on the implementation of this subtitle.

section.text: In accordance with § 112 of the federal Act, the Governor shall submit to the Secretary a State plan that includes the workforce initiatives of State agencies and outlines a 5-year strategy for the statewide workforce investment system of the State. The Governor’s plan shall include, but not be limited to, those items set forth in § 112 of the federal Act.

subsection.text: After receiving recommendations from the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board regarding youth and adult discretionary allocations, as provided for in §§ 128(a) and (b)(1) and (3) and 133(a) and (b)(1) and (3) of the federal Act, the Governor shall allocate federal funds in accordance with §§ 128 and 133 of the federal Act, the State plan, and State budget procedures.

After receiving recommendations from the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board regarding the utilization of federal funds for reservations for State activities under § 133(a) and for dislocated workers under § 133(b)(2)(B) of the federal Act, the Governor, except for funds reserved for State purposes, shall distribute the remainder to the workforce investment areas in accordance with § 133 of the federal Act, the State plan, and State budget procedures.

The Governor may provide State funds in the budget to qualify for funds under the federal Act, and for other purposes to promote the workforce development system to implement § 11-508 of this subtitle.
Funds provided under the federal Act shall only be used for activities which are in addition to those which would otherwise be available in the area in the absence of such funds.

Nothing in this section is intended to limit the ability of the State to use private resources and to contract with private or public entities to provide employment and training services or supportive services.

section.text: To the extent that State funds become available and subject to the procedures in § 11-505(d) of this subtitle, after receiving recommendations from the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board regarding the utilization of State funds to supplement federal funds for employment and training services, supportive services, and for related services such as training allowances and stipends, the Governor may allocate an amount for such purposes in accordance with State budget procedures.

subsection.text: In this section, “private sector entity” means a person that the Maryland Apprenticeship and Training Council approves under § 11-405(b) of this title.
There is a Construction Apprenticeship Assistance Program in the Department.
