The purpose of the Construction Apprenticeship Assistance Program is to develop a well-trained, productive construction workforce which meets the needs of the State’s economy.
The Division shall administer the Construction Apprenticeship Assistance Program.
As provided in the State budget, the Construction Apprenticeship Assistance Program shall award grants to eligible private sector entities that operate apprenticeship programs in the State.
The Secretary may adopt regulations necessary to carry out this section.
By regulation, the Secretary shall establish:

paragraph.text: criteria to determine the eligibility of private sector entities; and
an application process for determining eligibility.

subsection.text: A grant awarded by the Construction Apprenticeship Assistance Program under subsection (e) of this section shall be based on the number of participants in a program operated by an eligible private sector entity.
A grant shall consist of a maximum of $1,000 for each apprentice in an eligible private sector entity.
The Construction Apprenticeship Assistance Program shall distribute a grant awarded to a private sector entity:

paragraph.text: at the end of a Program year; and
only to the extent that each apprentice has completed the Program year.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Local area” means the local workforce investment areas established in this State under the federal Workforce Investment Act of 1998.
“Low income” means not more than 150% of the federal poverty level.
“Program” means the Maryland Summer Youth Connection Program.
“Summer” means the period beginning June 1 of each year and ending September 30 of each year.
There is a Maryland Summer Youth Connection Program in the Division.

subparagraph.text: The purpose of the Program is to provide summer jobs for youth who are not less than 14 years of age and not more than 21 years of age.
The Program priorities are to provide jobs for youth who:

sub-subparagraph.text: are 14 years old and 15 years old;
are from low-income families;
have a disability;
have a special need; or
otherwise encounter barriers in the labor market.

subsection.text: The Director shall:

paragraph.text: make grants in furtherance of the Program objectives to fiscal agents for local areas in accordance with the allocation formulas established under the federal Workforce Investment Act;
adopt regulations to carry out the Program; and
evaluate the performances of the local areas in carrying out the purposes of the Program.

subsection.text: Under the Program, the local areas shall:

paragraph.text: develop meaningful and well supervised work experiences in:

subparagraph.text: public and private nonprofit, community-based sites; and
private for-profit sites, if the experiences developed in the private for-profit sites:

sub-subparagraph.text: serve not more than 20% of the participants in the Program; and
expose Program participants to occupations for which there is high demand in the labor market;

paragraph.text: provide activities to enhance job skills, including basic skills, computer skills, occupational skills, and basic employability skills;
provide career-exposure activities, including field trips, guest speakers, job shadowing, aptitude and interest assessment, and college fairs;
provide sufficient oversight and monitoring of work sites to ensure a quality experience for each participant;
submit a plan to the Director detailing the local area’s plan for summer activities; and
submit an end-of-summer report.

subsection.text: A local area’s allowable Program costs may include:

paragraph.text: wages paid to participants in the Program;
the costs of supervision;
the costs of materials and supplies related to the work provided;
reasonable transportation costs to, from, and around the work site;
related training costs; and
reasonable administrative support costs, not exceeding 10% of the funding granted the local area.

subsection.text: A participating youth shall be paid not less than the federal minimum wage for each hour worked.
There is an Adult Education and Literacy Services Office in the Division of Workforce Development and Adult Learning of the Department.
The Adult Education and Literacy Services Office shall be the sole agency in the State responsible for administering and supervising policy and funding for adult education and literacy.

section.text: The Adult Education and Literacy Services Office, with the approval of the Secretary, may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: There is a Workforce Creation and Adult Education Transition Council in the Department to coordinate the Integration of Adult Education and Literacy Services with the Division of Workforce Development and its programs.
The Transition Council shall consist of the following members:

paragraph.text: one member of the Senate, appointed by the President;
one member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker;
the Secretary, who shall serve as Cochair;
the Secretary of the Department of Business and Economic Development;
the Secretary of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
the State Superintendent of Schools, who shall serve as Cochair;
the Secretary of Higher Education;
the Chancellor of the University System of Maryland;
a representative of the Maryland Association for Adult Community and Continuing Education;
a representative of the Maryland Workforce Development Association;
a representative of the Maryland Association of Community Colleges;
the Chair of the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board; and
ten members appointed by the Governor, including representatives from the following communities of interest:

subparagraph.text: family literacy;
adult basic education;
career and technical education;
workplace literacy;
correctional education;
community libraries;
English as a second language providers;
organized labor;
employers; and
nonprofit organizations involved in programs to promote economic self–sufficiency.

subsection.text: The Transition Council shall:

paragraph.text: develop a plan for the seamless transition of the adult education, literacy, and correctional education programs from the State Department of Education to the Department;
actively assist in the development of a new State plan for adult education;
identify existing adult education programs in other units of State government and develop strategies to make the agencies part of a coordinated program;
recommend a framework for a new State system of delivering adult education and workforce programs through the Department that:

subparagraph.text: provides for the effective alignment of adult education, literacy, and correctional education programs with workforce development programs;
tracks outcomes of adult education students; and
is consistent with applicable federal laws;

paragraph.text: review the overlapping responsibilities of correctional education as they relate to implementation of adult correctional education and juvenile services education;

determine the advisability of transferring correctional education services in light of the potential negative impact the transfer could have on the effective operation of juvenile services education; and
recommend the composition and responsibilities of a State Advisory Council on Adult Education, Literacy, and Workforce Development.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide staff to the Transition Council.

paragraph.text: On or before December 31, 2008, the Transition Council shall complete its work and shall report to the Governor and, subject to the provisions of § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly, on its activities and recommendations.
The report shall include a summary of the plan for the seamless transition of the adult education, literacy, and correctional education programs from the State Department of Education including:

subparagraph.text: strategies for ensuring program continuity for clients of the affected programs;
strategies for ensuring continuity in the State administration of affected grant programs;

provisions regarding affected employees, including a specific analysis of the transfer of employees with shared responsibilities for adult correctional education and juvenile services education such as grant managers and program coordinators;
strategies for coordinating the activities and responsibilities of units of State government involved in administering the transferred programs; and

strategies for addressing potential challenges to implementing the transition of the affected programs in a manner that ensures the continued delivery of quality content to clients of the affected programs.

section.text: The Department shall be responsible for the development of the State plan for adult education and literacy services and its submission to the federal Department of Education.

subsection.text: In accordance with the applicable rules and regulations of the Department, each county board of education may establish and maintain day and evening schools for adults.
The purpose of these schools for adults is to provide:

paragraph.text: a general program of continuing education for the improvement of the civic, occupational, and general intelligence of adults; and
programs to enable adults to make a wise use of their leisure time.

subsection.text: A full–time student, at the student’s own expense, may register for adult education courses, if space is available, and if that student secures the written permission of the superintendent of schools, or the superintendent’s designee, of the county in which the student registers.

paragraph.text: The Adult Education and Literacy Services Office shall distribute competitive grants for adult education and literacy services in accordance with the State plan for adult education and family literacy.
The grants distributed under this section shall be based on need and performance.
Grants under this section may be used for adult education and literacy services, including:

subparagraph.text: GED instruction;
the Maryland Adult External High School Program under § 11–807 of this subtitle;
Workplace Literacy Services;
English for speakers of other languages;
family literacy; and
literacy instruction.

subsection.text: Funding for the competitive grants under this section shall be as provided in the State budget.
On or before August 1 each year, the Department shall:

paragraph.text: compile a list by county of adult education and literacy services offered to the public;
distribute the list to the county board and county superintendent or chief executive officer of each local school system in the State; and
post the list on its public website.

subsection.text: In this section, “Program” means the Maryland Adult External High School Program established for the citizens of Maryland under regulations adopted by the Secretary in consultation with the State Board of Education.

paragraph.text: The Department and the State Board of Education recognize demonstrated competencies in adults, whether or not those competencies were acquired in a formal school setting.
In response to its recognition of competencies, the Department shall provide alternative requirements and methods of obtaining a Maryland high school diploma.
The State Board of Education shall award diplomas to the individuals meeting the requirements of this subtitle.

For each fiscal year the Governor shall include in the annual budget bill submitted to the General Assembly, including any proposed supplemental budget, a General Fund appropriation for the Maryland Adult External High School Program in an amount not less than the amount of the Governor’s General Fund appropriation for the Program in fiscal year 2006.

In each annual budget, the Governor shall include federal funds, to the extent available, for the Program in an amount not less than the amount of the Governor’s federal fund appropriation for the Program in fiscal year 2006.

subsection.text: An individual may obtain a high school diploma by examination as provided in this section if the individual:

paragraph.text: has not obtained a high school diploma;

has resided in this State or on a federal reservation in this State for at least 3 months, provided that the Secretary may waive the residence requirement if the Secretary considers the waiver justified;
is 16 years old or older; and
has withdrawn from a regular full–time public or private school program.

subsection.text: The Department shall offer examinations to individuals who are pursuing a high school diploma under this subtitle at least twice each year at places throughout the State that are reasonably convenient for the applicants.
The examination shall:

paragraph.text: be offered in appropriate high school subject areas; and
be of a comprehensive nature as determined by the State Board of Education.

subsection.text: An individual who fails an examination may repeat taking the examination.
A member of the armed forces may earn a Maryland high school diploma by taking the examinations furnished by the United States Armed Forces Institute and given by the appropriate service officer.
The diploma shall be awarded in accordance with the regulations adopted by the Secretary and the State Board of Education.
There is an Education and Workforce Training Coordinating Council for Correctional Institutions under the jurisdiction of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department.

paragraph.text: The Council consists of 14 members.
Four of the members of the Council shall be residents of this State appointed by the Governor for a term of 4 years who each shall serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies as follows:

subparagraph.text: two representing the business community;
a former offender; and
one member of the general public.

paragraph.text: The following officials shall serve ex officio:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the State Superintendent of Schools;
the Secretary of Higher Education;
the Secretary of Business and Economic Development;
the president of a community college in the State;
the Chair of the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board;
the Director of Education and Workforce Skills Training for Correctional Institutions;
an official from a local correctional facility; and
the county superintendent of schools from a county where a correctional institution of the Division of Correction is located, who shall be selected by the State Superintendent.

subsection.text: Each member of the Council:

paragraph.text: serves without compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations.
The Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Secretary shall serve as cochairs of the Council.
The Council:

subparagraph.text: shall meet at least four times per year;
shall designate the time and place of its meetings; and
may adopt rules for the conduct of its meetings.

paragraph.text: The Council shall be within the Department for administrative and budgetary purposes.
The Department shall provide technical and clerical assistance and support to the Council.

subsection.text: The Education and Workforce Training Coordinating Council for Correctional Institutions shall develop and recommend an educational and workforce training program for each correctional institution in the Division of Correction. The programs shall meet the special needs and circumstances of the inmates in each correctional institution.

paragraph.text: The Council shall adopt regulations for all correctional institutions in the Division of Correction for the implementation of a mandatory education program for all inmates who fail to attain a minimum educational standard as set forth in this subsection.
The regulations adopted by the Council shall:

subparagraph.text: require that the educational standard shall be the attainment of a General Educational Development (GED) diploma or a verified high school diploma;
apply only to any inmate who:

sub-subparagraph.text: was received by the Division of Correction after July 1, 1987;
has 18 months or more remaining to be served before a mandatory supervision release date;
is not exempted due to a medical, developmental, or learning disability; and
does not possess a General Educational Development (GED) diploma or a verified high school diploma;

subparagraph.text: require any inmate who is not exempted under item (ii)3 of this paragraph to participate in:

sub-subparagraph.text: the mandatory education program for at least 120 calendar days; or
a workforce skills training program; and

subparagraph.text: the Division of Correction shall report to the Parole Commission the academic progress of an inmate in the mandatory education program.

paragraph.text: The Council shall adopt regulations for all correctional institutions in the Division of Correction for the implementation of a mandatory workforce skills training program for all inmates as provided in this subsection.
The regulations shall apply only to an inmate who:

subparagraph.text: has 18 months or more remaining to be served before a mandatory supervision release date; and
is not exempted due to a medical, developmental, or learning disability.

paragraph.text: The Division of Correction shall report to the Parole Commission the academic progress of an inmate in the mandatory workforce skills training program.

subsection.text: On or before October 30 of each year, the Council shall report its activities to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.

subparagraph.text: The Council shall actively advocate and promote the interests of educational programs and workforce skills training opportunities in correctional institutions.
The Council shall seek to ensure that a quality education, equal educational opportunity, and workforce skills training are available to all inmates at correctional institutions.

paragraph.text: The Council, on a regular basis, shall review the educational and workforce skills training programs at correctional institutions to ensure that the unique educational and training needs of the populations of the correctional institutions are being satisfactorily met.
The Council shall include in its review:

subparagraph.text: curriculum guides;
courses of study;
resource materials;
textbooks;
supplementary readers;
materials of instruction;
visual and auditory aids;
supplies;
teacher performance; and
other teaching aids.

paragraph.text: Based on its review, the Council shall recommend and advocate improvements to the educational and workforce skills training programs at correctional institutions.

subsection.text: The Department is responsible for the provision of education and workforce skills training programs in the adult correctional institutions in the State.
The Secretary shall appoint a Director of Education and Workforce Skills Training for Correctional Institutions.
The Director shall receive the salary provided in the budget of the Department.
The Director shall:

paragraph.text: implement and operate the educational and workforce skills training programs developed by the Council in the correctional institutions;
meet with and advise the Council about the programs; and
consult with the Commissioner of Correction and the warden of each institution about the operation of the programs.

section.text: In this subtitle, “federal acts” means the Acts of Congress that authorize funding for education, library services, and workforce development training for inmates in adult correctional facilities, and any amendments to those acts.

subsection.text: The State of Maryland assents to the federal acts.
The State Treasurer shall:

paragraph.text: be the custodian of any money received under the federal acts; and
disburse this money in accordance with the federal acts.

subsection.text: The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the State Board of Education, as appropriate, shall:

paragraph.text: cooperate with the appropriate federal agencies in administering the federal acts;
do anything necessary to secure the benefits of the federal acts;
facilitate the transfer of funds to the appropriate operational agency; and
represent this State in all matters relating to the administration of the federal acts.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, Patuxent Institution is a correctional institution within the Division of Correction and under the jurisdiction of the Education and Workforce Training Coordinating Council for Correctional Institutions for the funding of educational and workforce skills training programs only.
Funds for the operation of the educational and workforce skills training programs in correctional institutions shall be provided in the budget of the Department.
The Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and other State agencies may contribute to the programs identified under subsection (b) of this section.
Funds appropriated for educational and workforce skills training programs in correctional institutions may not be diverted by budget amendment or otherwise to any other purpose.

section.text: This subtitle does not affect the provisions of law relating to the powers, duties, and authority of the State Board of Education, the State Superintendent of Schools, the Maryland Higher Education Commission, or the Secretary of Higher Education.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the board of directors of the Corporation.
“Corporation” means the Maryland Workforce Corporation.
There is a Maryland Workforce Corporation.
The Corporation is a body politic and corporate and is an instrumentality of the State.
The purpose of the Corporation is to:

paragraph.text: work in coordination with the Department and other State agencies to establish a plan and framework for innovative, demand–driven programs across the State that will give Maryland workers the opportunity to acquire and develop the education and skills needed to participate fully in the workforce;
solicit, acquire, and coordinate private and public funding to assure a reliable funding stream for the programs developed under this subtitle;
obtain resources for the statewide workforce programs developed under this subtitle from private and public sources including:

subparagraph.text: local workforce investment boards;
community colleges;
adult learning programs;
correctional education and vocational programs;
the Department of Human Resources;
the Department of Business and Economic Development;
the Higher Education Commission; and
the Department;

paragraph.text: administer the programs developed under this subtitle in accordance with the plan developed under item (1) of this subsection;
provide grants, funding, and other assistance to support the programs developed under this subtitle;
contract with training providers to conduct education and skills training programs;
act as a research and development resource in finding solutions for new and emerging workforce issues; and
evaluate the effectiveness of the programs developed under this subtitle.
There is a board of directors of the Corporation.
The board shall manage the Corporation and exercise its corporate powers.
The board shall meet at least four times a year.

subsection.text: The board consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: as ex officio members:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary;
the Secretary of Business and Economic Development;
the Secretary of Higher Education;
the Secretary of Human Resources;
the Secretary of Juvenile Services;
the Chancellor of the University System of Maryland;
the State Superintendent of Schools;
the Executive Director of the Maryland Association of Community Colleges; and
the Chair of the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board; and

paragraph.text: fourteen individuals appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate who have knowledge and experience in business and industry, skills training, education, including adult basic education, labor organizations, and minority employment.
To the extent practicable, the members appointed to the board shall reflect the geographic, racial, ethnic, cultural, and gender diversity of the State.
A board member must be a resident of the State.
A board member:

subparagraph.text: serves without compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: The Governor may remove a board member for incompetence, misconduct, or failure to perform the duties of the position.

subsection.text: The Governor shall designate a member of the board as its chair.

paragraph.text: The term of a board member appointed under subsection (b)(2) of this section is 4 years.
The terms are staggered as required by the terms provided for the members on July 1, 2009.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member may be reappointed.
A member who has served two consecutive 4–year terms may not be reappointed until at least 1 year has elapsed after the end of the previous term.
A member who has served less than a full 4–year term may be reappointed to two full terms.

subsection.text: Each member of the board appointed under subsection (b)(2) of this section shall disclose to the State Ethics Commission whether the member is employed by or has a financial interest in an entity that may apply to the Corporation for funding to provide workforce education and skills training.

paragraph.text: The board shall appoint a president with experience and qualifications relevant to the activities and purposes of the Corporation.
The president serves at the pleasure of the board.
The board shall determine the salary of the president.
The president is the chief administrative officer of the Corporation.
The president shall manage the administrative affairs and technical activities of the Corporation in accordance with policies and procedures that the board establishes.

subsection.text: The president, or the president’s designee, shall:

paragraph.text: attend all meetings of the board;
act as secretary of the board;
keep minutes of all proceedings of the board;
approve all salaries, per diem payments, and allowable expenses of the Corporation, its employees, and its consultants;
approve any expenses incidental to the operation of the Corporation; and
perform the other duties that the board directs in carrying out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Corporation shall employ any additional professional and clerical staff as necessary to carry out this subtitle.
The Corporation may retain consultants, agents, and advisers as necessary.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General is the legal adviser to the Corporation.
With the approval of the Attorney General, the Corporation may retain any necessary lawyers.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, in exercising its powers, the Corporation:

subparagraph.text: may carry out its corporate purposes without the consent of any State unit; and
is not subject to the following provisions of the State Finance and Procurement Article:

sub-subparagraph.text: Title 2, Subtitle 2 (Gifts and Grants);
Title 3 (Budget and Management);
Title 3A (Department of Information Technology);
Title 4 (Department of General Services);
Title 6, Subtitle 1 (Studies and Estimates);
Title 7, Subtitle 1 (State Operating Budget), Subtitle 2 (Disbursements and Expenditures), and Subtitle 3 (Unspent Balances); and
Division II (General Procurement Law).

paragraph.text: The Corporation is subject to the Public Information Act and the Open Meetings Act.
The board and the officers and employees of the Corporation are subject to the Public Ethics Law.
The officers and employees of the Corporation are not subject to:

subparagraph.text: Division II of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; or
the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: The Corporation, its officers, and its employees are subject to Title 12, Subtitle 4 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Corporation is exempt from State and local taxes.
The Corporation shall establish a system of financial accounting, controls, audits, and reports.
The fiscal year of the Corporation begins on July 1 and ends on the following June 30.
The exercise by the Corporation of the powers conferred by this subtitle is the performance of an essential public function.
The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws;
adopt a seal;
maintain offices at a place in the State that the Corporation designates;

apply for and accept loans, grants, or assistance in any form from federal, State, or local governments, colleges or universities, or foundations or other private sources to support workforce education and skills training programs;
administer programs that further the goals and objectives of the Corporation;

provide grants, funding, and other assistance to State and local agencies, colleges and universities, employers, administrators of labor/management training and upgrading funds, and nonprofit organizations for education and skills training programs;
contract with training providers to conduct education and skills training programs;
assist training providers by coordinating funding for training programs;
make, execute, and enter into any contracts or legal instruments;
sue or be sued;
seek tax exempt status from the Internal Revenue Service;
exercise a power usually possessed by a private corporation in performing similar functions unless to do so would conflict with the laws of the State; and
do anything necessary or convenient to carry out the powers granted by this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Corporation may not offer or provide educational or skills training unless the Corporation determines that there are no other training providers available.

section.text: The Secretary may allocate funds to the Corporation for its expenses, as provided for in the State budget.

paragraph.text: As soon as practicable after the close of the fiscal year, an independent certified public accountant shall audit the financial books, records, and accounts of the Corporation.
The Corporation shall select an accountant to conduct the audit who:

subparagraph.text: is licensed to practice certified public accountancy in the State;
is experienced and qualified in the accounting and auditing of public entities; and
does not have a direct or indirect personal interest in the fiscal affairs of the Corporation.

Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, on or before November 1 after each fiscal year, the accountant shall report the results of the audit, including the accountant’s opinion, made without reservation, of the presentation of the financial position of the funds of the Corporation, and the results of the financial operations of the Corporation.

If the accountant cannot express an opinion without reservation, the accountant shall explain in detail the reasons for the qualifications and disclaimers, including recommendations for changes that could make future opinions without reservation possible.

subsection.text: The State may audit the books, records, and accounts of the Corporation.
Within 90 days after the start of each fiscal year, the Corporation shall report on its status to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.
The report shall state the complete operating and financial statement covering the Corporation’s operations and summarize the Corporation’s activities during the preceding fiscal year.
Each unit in the Executive Branch of State government and each institution of higher education in the State may work with the Corporation on matters relating to the unit.
Each county, municipal corporation, and local workforce investment board in the State may work with the Corporation on matters relating to the political subdivision or entity.

All debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation, whenever incurred, shall be the debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation only and not of the State, units of State government, other State instrumentalities, or State officers or employees.
The debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation may not be considered a debt of the State or a pledge of the credit of the State.

section.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to carry out its purposes.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Health Care Personnel Training Fund.
There is a Health Care Personnel Training Fund.
The purpose of the Fund is to provide grants to training consortiums that involve labor–management partnerships that train and upgrade the qualifications of health care personnel.
The Department shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall consist solely of:

paragraph.text: money received from the federal government; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund may be used only to provide grants to training consortiums that involve labor–management partnerships that train and upgrade the qualifications of health care personnel.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the Fund.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund:

paragraph.text: may be made only in accordance with the State budget; and
shall be made in consultation with the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board.
